description:
Good wine, good pizza, good company - what more do you need? I've been meaning to try Pizzeria Delfina for years, but never got around to it. When I moved in right down the street, it was fate.

Even on a Tuesday evening, the place is bustling at dinnertime with a line out the door. There were only two of us, so we chose to sit at the bar and avoid the longer wait for a table. Our server was so friendly - she let us taste a couple of wines to help us decide, and we chose the fantastic Nebbiolo.  We ordered a classic margherita pizza, which just melts in your mouth and the crust is unforgettable. One pizza was more than enough for the two of us. Though we were full, we couldn't help but order the chocolate mousse for dessert. 

The place is busy, but the ambience is comfortable. Overall, it was a great night with fantastic food.
author: Apoorva A.

description:
Came in for lunch today 12:15 pm and several empty tables to choose  from 

We shared a Napoletana.  Our waitress highly recommended adding cheese, since this is their only pizza that does not come with cheese ..... (mozzarella).   We said sure.

The pizza arrived. We loved it. Very salty capers anchovies olives. The tomatoes were bright and tasty. She said the tomatoes were from cans

We were befuddled tho, because we couldn't taste or see cheese. I flagged the waitress down. She confirmed there was no cheese. She said "oops sorry"

Weird, since she was the one who  talked us into ordering the cheese!

Also they added a $3.50 sf mandate fee to the bill.   This means for everyone at your table, they pay $1.75 each.  It adds up!!!

So watch it when you tip. There's lots of added fees and taxes to the grand total.  We figured our pizza, no drinks, was $28. That's pretty pricey for a small pizza
author: Foodlover B.

description:
Need to come back. 

Overall thoughts:
*Came here right before the dinner crowd around 5:45 on a Tuesday and got seated right away. Customers who came 15 mins after us had to wait. 

*Food came out quick and service is good

*Crust was one of the best I've ever had with a perfect crisp, tomato sauce tasted so fresh

*Other toppings were good to me but not the best I've had. We ordered a Margherita Pizza but the waiter brought out a pizza and said it was 4 cheese. When we said we ordered Margherita he said "oh yes it is". It didn't look like a typical Margherita but we took it anyway. The arugula and prosciutto pizza was messy to eat but I guess there's nothing you can do about it unless you want to fold the slice in half. I'd like to order the Margherita again since my bf had it prior and said it looked different. Regardless, what we got was good. The crust and sauce sold me. I'd also like to try the clam pizza next time!
author: Sarah W.

description:
We had just walked across and back the bridge and were exhausted. We were hungry and still had to drive back to San Jose. We stoped by this place and put our name on the chalkboard. A group of 10 were ahead of us and were instructed where their table would be once it opened up. 2 tables had opened up, one of which was to be ours and our host confirmed. That party decided to just sit and take the 2 tables that opened up. The host (may have even been the mgr) apologized to us. We were finally seated and ordered. 
We were greeted with a wonderful salad complimentary from the kitchen. We thanked the host. I don't like tomatoes, but these were the sweetest ones on the block and I devoured almost the entire plate single-handedly. I would have loved to save those tomato seeds to grow back home in Hawaii. I ordered the Napoletana pizza as I adore anchovies, olives and capers. I was concerned that the crust was super thin, almost wafer-like. Wrong. The flavor is insane and intense. Best pizza hands down. The man got 4 Formaggi and he and the teen wolfed it down. We ended the night with a dessert similar to pudding but butterscotch, again, compliments of the kitchen. Not overly sweet but hit the spot. Yes, we tipped heavily but the service was exceptional and they kept checking in on us, knowing we had a grueling day. And the food was beyond delicious. Beyond. I have not read reviews on this place as we were in the area and other restaurants didn't seem to catch our eye. I'm glad we chose this place and would return if ever in the area.
author: Ann N.

description: Talk about a pizza experience! This was a cute, intimate cafe style pizzeria. The tables were close together and there were little tables outside. The staff greeted us, and quickly seated us. They explained the menu and gave us a chance to review the menu. The people next to us were enjoying an appetizer, and a salad, and had their pizza delivered while we were thinking about what to order. They definitely over ordered, so we decided to share a pizza. We ordered the prosciutto pizza, and it was topped with an arugula salad, so it was the best of both. The pizza was big enough to share and packed with delicious flavor. The crust was thin and chewy, and a great base for the simple toppings. I love prosciutto and the arugula complimented it so well and balanced the saltiness. We enjoyed every bite and had room left over to try ice cream for dessert.... check out my other review.
author: Sandra V.

description:
When a moon hits your eye like a big pizza pie, that's amore! 

I'm so in love with Pizzeria Delfina. I live in Pac Heights and it has been my go-to pick-up food spot since I moved to the neighborhood over a year ago! While this location can get busy for dinner, pick-up times are fairly quick (lucky for us locals). The location is great - right off of Fillmore and right next to Smitten (wink, wink). I usually get the same pizza, the Margherita. It's delicious and the right size for me if I'm feeling hungry. With a lot of pizza places, I feel tired and sick after eating but I never feel this way after eating Delfina. I would definitely recommend Pizzeria Delfina if you're in the hood and to try some delicious pizza!
author: Katie C.

description:
Standard Neopolitan style pizza. Got in around 6:30 Saturday night and didn't have to wait. Staff was friendly and attentive.

Ordered the standard margherita. Asked the difference between dop and standard margherita and it was the tomato and cheese. Dop used buffalo mozzarella and San marzano tomatoes. We also got a side dish of fresh dried oregano, chili flakes, and parmesan. We also had some tableside thin bread sticks. They are passable unless you want something to tie you over.

The margherita was delicious and crust nice. Tomatoes were sour and had more of a tang with the mozzarella being very mild and bland. My friend got the Dop which I was able to try a slice. The pizza was totally different and I would have much rather gotten that one. If eating here I would 100% say to pay a bit more for the Dop. Tomatoes were much sweeter with less tang and mozzarella seemingly having more flavor. Was a yummy pizza place and would go again. Love the Neopolitan style.
author: Kimberly Y.

description:
Oh how I love Pizzeria Delfina. 

My favorite pizza here is the clam pie ($19): cherrystones, tomato, oregano, pecorino + hot peppers. There's something magical about clams and tomato sauces; a happy marriage of unlikely flavors enhanced by a kick of hot peppers.

I've also had their prosciutto pie ($18.50). It's prosciutto di parma, caciocavallo, mozzarella, panna and topped with arugula. It's good, but I don't love it.

It's super casual here. It's especially nice on warmer days when you can sit toward the front and bask in the sun's warm rays. If you're looking for a quick, noncommittal bite in the neighborhood, I suggest stopping by.
author: Trung N.

description:
I've lived across the street from Pizzeria Delfina for 3 years and probably eat there about once a month.  

Food:  4/5 stars
Value:  2.5/5 stars
Service: 4/5 stars
Wait Time:  1/5 stars

Food: 1) The tricolore salad is one of my favorite things to eat in the Bay Area.  Highly recommend.  2) The pizzas are just "OK".  I don't like pizzas without tomato sauce, and many of them don't come with tomato sauce.  If you like white pies, you may enjoy this place more than I did.  The margherita is decent, and I like the pizza with cherrystone clams. Salsiccia pizza is loaded with too much sausage for the delicate crust, and fennel flavor was overwhelming for me.  Sometimes the crust on pizzas is soggy, if they overload it with toppings or sauce.  3) Mussells with lemon and garlic are good.  4) Deserts aren't anything special.  Smitten, Salt and Straw, and Sift Cupcakes are all close by though.  

Overall the food and service are good.  However -- the wait can be long.  There isn't a comfortable place to wait for a table, so people pack the front entry.  They have a bar area that's too tightly packed and not comfortable at all - they need to remove a chair or two.  I feel like I'm eating with t-rex arms so I don't bump the person next to me.  The tables and booths are better, but is loud at peak times.  

It's not crazy expensive, but for the money, you can get a higher standard of service and a more comfortable visit (try the Elite Cafe around the corner).
author: Holly P.

description:
Yum yum yum!

Location: Tucked away on California off of Fillmore. Inside there is bar, booth, and table seating. Street parking only & near bus stops. 

Service: Quick service & everybody is willing to help! 

Food: The pizzas are all amazing; favorites are purgatorio (special) and salsiccia.
author: Shelley K.

description:
In the search of good pizza at 9:00 pm on a Sunday, Pizza Delfina it was. I liked their ambience and the service overall was great. The pizza itself was what I had to give 3 stars to. 

Now, I am someone who can never finish their food and always asks for boxes to go. This pizza was one I devoured and was still hungry after... I ordered the Margherita pizza which came with 6 slices and it was composed of thin bread, heavy crust, a lot of sauce and blocks of cheese ($16). There wasn't really anything too crazy special for me. I loved the fact of how greasy and thin the pizza was, but that's about it. When I was biting into the pizza, the cheese would slip off and I was just basically eating bread and sauce. Perhaps I need to order a different one next time that's more loaded with toppings. But it's a once a month type of pizza because the price is not cheap.

P.S.: It's worth pointing out that they don't carry Ranch... not a huge deal but some people (like me) grew up dipping their pizza in ranch so I was pretty sad about that.
author: Joscelynne R.

description: Not sure what was going on there tonight.  Been going to this pizzeria about 3-5 times a year for the last 6-7 years.  Tonight was the worst I've ever seen from a restaurant that consistently seems to have very high standards.  Pizza came out very burnt on the top side of the crust.  Bad on the server for bringing it out and shame on me for not sending it back.  Crust tasted more like toast than a pizza.  Staff seemed not on their A-game.
author: Courtney A.

description:
Great service and amazing food! 

For a Saturday night, my friend and I only had to wait 10-15 minutes for a table. We were able to get a glass of wine while we waited though :) We had a delicious and light glass of the Fiano-La Capranera, white white.

For dinner my friend and I split two pizzas: Salsiccia (housemade fennel sausage, tomato sweet peppers, onions, mozzarella--- but asked for spicy marinara instead) and Prosciutto Pie (prosciutto di parma, caciocavallo, mozzarella, Panama, arugula --- but we asked for marina sauce instead of white sauce). Our server did an excellent job making recommendations to tweak the pizzas and red wines to pair with the dish. I was looking for a Pinot Noir so I was suggested Agliancio "Delfina" (earthy) and loved it, while my friend wanted a Cabernet so was suggested Pallagrello Nero blend, and she loved it as well. We each have 1/2 a pizza for leftovers! 

Overall great experience and would recommend to anyone who would like a more upscale pizzeria without having to break the bank. Definitely coming back!
author: Shannon P.

description: It was VERY loud inside on the day we went but the pizza, the meatballs and the beer tasted very good. There were many people before us, so the way they seat the customers is through writing the names of the customers and the number of guests on the board, and as soon as they have seats available for that many people, they call you inside, which was very cool.  Once seated, the services was pretty fast, and the food was very affordable.
author: Sona M.

description:
Oh, man.  This place is definitely worth every carb and is the main reason why I do cardio during the week.  

There's a reason why people are constantly lined up outside to get a taste of Pizzeria Delfina-- it really is THAT GOOD.  Make sure to jot down your name as soon as you arrive.  Also, head to the counter or register and order a glass of wine while you wait.  The staff will gladly accommodate.  

There isn't a ton of room for dining in.  Takeout is kind of the main thing here.  I've experienced both, and this place operates like a well oiled machine.  

The prosciutto pie and the margherita are my favorites.  The seasonal veggie side dishes are also excellent, but the pizza is certainly the star here.
author: Andrea H.

description: San Francisco is a city with perfect pizza weather. It's a little cold, gloomy, and often rainy. What more perfect conditions could exist for pizza enjoyment? That said, Delfina is amazing regardless of the climate. I walked two miles in the cold rain without an umbrella to try this pie. Totally worth it! I went with the margherita and added salame piccante. The crust was perfectly cooked and had the right amount of crispiness. This is a high quality pie, from the cheese to the fresh basil and delicious salame. This is one of the best pizza spots in San Fran, hands down.
author: Sean W.

description:
A must stop for me each time I'm in SF. I always bring CT, NYC and Philly friends and they're always blown away by the elegant simplicity of the restaurant and the menu. The fennel sausage pie is my fav and I would mary it if possible (perhaps someday).  

Expect a wait ('cause it good) and write you're name on the chalkboard when you walk in for a spot in line. The employees are amazingly friendly (California thing?) even though the owners are from the city (that's NYC yo). Don't forget to grab a desert. They're delish too.
author: David P.

description:
Came here for my grandmother's birthday on a Sunday morning at 11:30.  Pretty cool spot.  Love the music and the staff is very nice and bright.

We had 3 pizzas, meatballs and man.. the Saffron Risotto was good.  I had peach soda that they make there too. 

Pretty good, the pizza wasn't the best pizza, but it was good.

The meatballs... the risotto deep fried balls were incredible and the peach soda was definitely something you should try when you are there.

We enjoyed our time there, I'd def go back again to try some of the other pizzas and too have those risotto balls.....
author: Cliff S.

description:
If you come for dinner or on a weekend expect to wait a long while. Do me favor, feel free to leave so I don't have to wait as long. :D

I dream of their margherita pizza, not in a fatass kinda way but more of an American Pie way, I'm not proud of it but it's true.

I ordered the margherita for myself and when it arrived, my partner reached in for a slice. I asked what she was doing and she claimed we were sharing. I told her to think again -- if you are judging me then clearly you haven't tried it so STFU, yeah? -- she went to her standard, get her way response of "but, I love you." Sometimes you just have to draw a line in the sand so I channeled my inner Tina Turner and belted, "what's love got to do, got to with it?" She didn't think it was funny and ate half. :(

Back to the pizza, the tomato sauce is light and sweet, the mozzarella is fresh and delicious, the crust is like a cracker -- and I don't mean a Trump voter. By far the best margherita I've ever had. This is my measuring stick for all others.
author: D T.

description: So, there is usually a line for this pizzeria. I'm used to pizza from NYC & NJ so my bar is high. The pizza was good, but not on the NYC level. The actual crust was a bit soggy on the bottom as opposed to crisp which is a no-no for me. The burrata was so delicious though. I really enjoyed it. A few other times I've ordered in and my preferred pizza is prosciutto pie and that's been a pretty crispy crust for the most part which is why I'm giving Pizzeria Delfino 4 stars.
author: Danielle S.

description:
I'm a big fan of Delfina but I've only been to their Italian restaurant, not the pizzeria. As a fan of pizza of all kinds though, this had been on my radar for awhile. We finally got around to coming in this past Saturday for lunch, as it was a perfect day out for pizza and sparkling wine and the restaurant was not insanely busy (surprisingly!)

We were seated immediately when we got there and munched on free breadsticks that were already at the table when we sat down. It was a hard decision, but we decided on our own pizza each instead of sharing an appetizer and one pizza between us. We chose the Panna for myself (I was intrigued by the addition of cream as a topping) and the Prosciutto for my partner. 

Both pizzas came out at the same time in about 10 minutes (give or take a few minutes). They were steaming hot, requiring us to wait a minute or two for them to cool down just enough so we could dig in without burning our mouths. These were worth the wait though! The sauce was bright and flavourful, the addition of cream added so much richness, and the strips of parmigiana were just enough salt to round out the whole thing (on the Panna pizza). The Prosciutto came out covered in so much arugula, at first we thought it was a salad, but underneath were thin strips of ham, along with delicious fresh mozzarella and tomatoes. We paired our pizzas up with a glass of sparkling wine and a peach bellini (which isn't as sweet as you think it would be). 

We managed to finish off everything without leaving any bits behind. The price was pretty fair considering the location, quality and quantity of the food. I'm annoyed that it's taken me so long to finally get to Pizzeria Delfina, but now that I have, it'll be in my top 3 places to go for fancy pizza.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
It's been about 2.5 years since I moved from the bay (and sadly, 2.5 years since I've eaten at Delfina) but I remember this place fondly and would argue that this is the best pizza in San Francisco.

I got the arancini balls, which were a delight to cut into as they were ooey, gooey and full of cheese. My favorite pizza is the margherita -- a classic done right! I think when trying out a new pizza place it's always fair to use something "basic" as a point of comparison, and Delfina does it justice! The margherita here is anything but basic. It's fantastic. I sometimes add toppings and would recommend the hen of the woods mushrooms. I also love the aesthetic here, it's bright and inviting.

Next time I'm back home, I'll have to come back and try more!
author: Ashley V.

description: The grilled corn, amazing. Best fresh pizza I ever had. My family and I were greeted with smiles
author: Pateika B.

description:
Takeout review. Pizza.

Ordered:
BELFIORE BURRATA (w/ arugula, crostini & extra virgin olive oil)
NEAPOLITAN MEATBALLS IN SUGO (pork, beef & veal meatballs w/ tomato sauce & crostini)
MARGHERITA (Tomato, fior di latte mozzarella, basil)
SALSICCIA (Housemade fennel sausage x2, tomato, mozzarella)

Pizza flavor/toppings - 4
Pizza crust - 3

Overall, "A-OK."
author: Mark O.

description: I ordered s four cheese and it tasted and looked just like the margarita and there was what seemed to me only one kind of cheese I didn't want to make a big deal about it but they should at least put more than one type of cheese but over all the vibe is really cool and the people who work here are really chill
author: Adam L.

description:
We ordered the:

PANNA / 14.50
Tomato sauce, cream, basil, shaved parmigiano

and

4 FORMAGGI / 16.00
Tomato, mozzarella, fontal, provolone, pecorino


The 4 cheese was too salty. It would be a hit if it didn't have that much salt. 

I liked the panna better because the cream was a nice touch.
author: Shruti D.

description: Great late lunch. Excellent pizza - we had the funghi as well as 2 very good appetizers - eggplant and broccoli/kale. Also a good mix of beer and wine by the glass. And service very friendly.
author: john r.

description:
My first question, "will one pizza be enough for two people"? Knowing my savage appetite i figured no though doesn't hurt to hear it from the staff. They answered honestly - unless we ordered a hearty pizza with more toppings or supplemented with other dishes, probably not to be safe. 

I was happy with the Marinated Beet Salad, Clam Pie and Salsiccia. The beets had tangy goat cheese and i only wished they had added more cheese (a common request i make). Would've been nice if the Clam Pie had a 'white' sauce version as well. Loved the Salsiccia. Just the right amount of sauce and toppings for a pie.

There's usually some crust left but i don't let it go to waste. Their dough is so good and not to be left behind. I know many people take it home as a treat for their dogs. I take it home to heat up with some salted scrambled eggs. YUM.
author: Samantha L.

description:
My friend was raving about their pizza for yearrrrrssss and I finally got to try it! I got the peas and peas with burrata - delish! Peas were so crush, the butter made it taste amazing, and the burrata - yum! I got the green garlic pizza - it was a ok, I probably wouldn't order again. My server was so sweet, told me it would pair well with some extra marina sauce, so she brought it out with the pizza. She was so right!

My table also ordered the meatball to share. They were good but CRAZYYYY salty. Like hurt my mouth salty. 

Would definitely come back and order some other things :) perfect place to come for lunch or dinner when the weather is sunny :)
author: Christine L.

description: At first I was a bit concerned this place was a classic case of San Franciscan over-bourgeoisification of the good ol' pizza. I looked at the menu and was concerned that $15+ pizzas were not going to be worth the price, but to my happy surprise I enjoyed every bite of these beauties. The portions were definitely not as I expected -- they were a lot bigger than I thought and filled me up sooner than I had hoped. We ordered the napoletana pizza with the mozzarella as well as the prosciutto pizza - both were super tasty and you can tell the ingredients were very fresh and top notch quality. Definitely coming back - it's one of the few pizza joints worth the price
author: David Y.

description:
This place is amazing :) I have been here several times in the past, but just going here a few days ago seemed to really hit the spot. On a Wednesday night, around 6:30pm, there was a wait of maybe 15 mins, not bad. But geez, I can't believe the place was packed on a weekday night! That's San Francisco for you. 

Highlights:
-Artichoke appetizer - so tender, so perfectly flavored from the olive oil and salt.
-Margherita DOP pizza - double the mozarella cheese! I was breaking down how good this pizza is compared to other pizza places. We just loved the tomato sauce, and how it isn't overcooked. Instead, it just kind of sloughs off in your mouth, bringing the cheese with it. Amazing!
-Salisiccia pizza- housemade fennel sausage, tomato, sweet peppers, onions, mozzarella - whoa. We really just loved the sweetness, and saltiness of the sausage with onions. It's a great pizza that's extremely satisfying. 

Corkage $18, not too bad?

Service was great. We were greeted & led to our table by bubbly personality college girls. They were so sweet! The ambiance is super casual, loud, and buzzing with energy. You will have an amazing experience here. The only thing I wish they had was pastas - but I guess you have to go to the original Delfina for that one.
author: Jocelyn L.

description: I love this place. It is a splurge for us due to the prices but damn it is so good. It gets crowded for sure, but we have eaten there every time we visit the city and it has been fanastic every time. Food is perfect, service is great, and the room is lovely. Thanks for always making great food Delfina.
author: Brad V.

description:
We came here on our last night visiting SF and had a great meal!

The restaurant was quite busy but we placed our names on the chalkboard and were seated outside per our preference within 5 minutes. The weather was a little chilly but the heat lamps they had outside made it perfect.

We were immediately served small breadsticks to snack on as well as various seasonings for our pizza. We weren't super hungry and ordered the sausage and red pepper pizza to share.

The pizza was delicious! We loved the red peppers and the thin and crispy yet soft crust. Our food came in a timely manner and our server was very friendly and knowledgeable. We would definitely come here again to try different pizzas or other entrees as they all looked delicious!

Also, our final bill was about $25 with tip, reasonable for a pizza in this area serving two people.
author: Kelly F.

description:
The sun was out and I was in the area and had a craving for some pizza and beer since Delfina was around the corner it was hard to pass up. They have some outdoor seating which is nice to check out the crowds and get some vitamin D. I like how the tables outside have a rubber mat to prevent things from blowing/moving. Pretty smart guys! 

Ordered the burrata and a margehrita dop pizza. The burrata was on point and the bread that came with it was crispy but soft and chewy. Perfect compliment to the cheese. The pizza had the perfect amount of sauce and cheese and the crust was thing but not flimsy. Delfina always gets it right with their pizzas and the reason I keep coming back.
author: Andrew S.

description: Very unassuming when you walk in, but the pizza is delicious! I got the limited time margarita pizza. Thin crust that was super crispy, just the way I like it. Service was good, our waiter was friendly and helpful when I asked about the difference between the two margarita pizzas they were offering. We ate inside, but a nice touch are the heaters outside above the tables. Perfect for cooler nights when you still want to enjoy the outside weather.
author: Shannon B.

description:
There is always a good selections of well put together vegetables plates.
Cauliflower roasted with capers
Rapini Rabe type greens in season
Meatballs 
The Burrata 
Salads are good.
Pizza is good

They use good ingredients, good olive oils calibre chili
author: Joseph M.

description:
We arrived for lunch and the place was already full with a short line. We were quickly and warmly welcomed and invited in.

I like the open kitchen and openness of the restaurant generally. The kitchen staff were working hard yet were friendly, the service was always helpful and cheerful, and the food was excellent and attractive.

A special shout out for the vegan pizza, which I noticed online though didn't see on the menu. It's simply their pizza with their delicious tomato sauce and any three vegetable toppings (I opted for broccoli rabe, roasted red pepper, and red onion). Outstanding.

Only one downside:

I do not like that they add a line item charge for their SF healthcare expenses. This is as inappropriate as adding a line on the bill for their taxes, wages, rent, electricity, dishwashing, etc. and I generally do not like to patronize or revisit restaurants that pull this scam.
author: Veg V.

description: Everything was illogical from beginning to the end. We were 4 and they made us sit a table for two. They give you two sides that you don't know what to do with them. They are that irrelevant from each other. We ordered two pizzas and a salad. When the pizzas came of course there was no space on the table because of the salad and plates, so she was pushing us to finish the salad. Seriously? Since you made us sit on tiny table we can't enjoy our food and finish whenever we want? Salad is terrible for $15 and pizza was just average. If torturing the clients is the concept of this restaurant everything makes sense and I'd say they are pretty good at it. However if you are a logical person, then I don't suggest this place.
author: Osman K.

description: One of the worse tasting pizzas. Ordered the pepperoni pie. The pepperoni was disgusting looking with big clumps of fat.  I have had pizza all over the u.s.a and this one was not good.
author: Roman R.

description: First time I've had a bad experience here. I am embarrassed for the server who was clearly not trained in the slightest way. I will spare the details but the kicker is that she brought us red wine from the cooler (cold red wine, yes) and then threw mad attitude about it when we asked why it was cold. We were literally shamed for asking for red wine that wasn't cold. She was very convincing that we didn't know what we were talking about but ultimately it made for a disappointing experience. She also set down the bottle without pouring and the strolled away...on a super slow night. Eh, not impressed like I used to be, Delphina.
author: Christine M.

description:
I was lucky this Sunday evening as the crowd hadn't yet arrived, so I was given the choice of a seat at the counter or at a small table near the entrance.   I took the table and regretted it.   Once people come into the place to wait for their own tables they are standing all but adjacent to this poorly placed table.  Children eye you as you try to eat; adults who should know better begin to roam deeper into the dining area, and you are no longer in a restaurant but rather on display.  Terrible.  

Beets with goat cheese and seeds was a nice enough.  Not spectacular but nice enough.  Chicken all diavola was also OK.  Basically it was just a roasted half bird that had some pepper on its non-crisped skin.  But the chicken was tender.

As a general rule the food at Delfina Pizzeria is good enough but as with real estate: location, location, location.
author: David D.

description: Was steered here by our Airbnb hosts after a long day of travel. Was a Friday night, so the place was jammed. You sign in on a chalkboard, then wait to be called--took 20-30 minutes. Well-staffed with friendly attentive folks. Menu wasn't huge (which is actually a good sign), but something for vegans and carnivores alike. Had the carbonara pizza--guanciale and cheese with two eggs cracked over the top. Sounds weird, tasted great. If you're in a hurry, don't bother, but if you have a couple of hours for good pizza in a comfy environment, this could be it.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Given that the last pizza I ate was the best pizza of my life in Tokyo recently (tuna pizza - don't knock it till you try it!), the bar for pizza was set pretty high in my mind. I'd give this pizza a 3.5, with an extra bump to 4 for the efficiently of their staff and good service.

Tonight we had the Salsiccia sausage pizza and the clam pie. I liked the flavor and copious amount of topping on the sausage pizza, while I thought the clam pie was a bit sparce. I wish it would have been more clam-forward. On the flip side, my boyfriend thought the clam pie was light and crispy while the sausage was overly loaded. My second slice of sausage pizza did get a little bit soggy in the middle from the loaded toppings. The crust was a little dry and bland for me, but that could just be because I am comparing it the memories of my last pizza. The pizzas both came out super fast - good if you're hungry, but slightly bad because it got cold faster.

I do appreciate that the staff was very efficient and we got good service from our waiter. I also like that they have pickup service so you can avoid the usual long waits at peak hours. At 5pm on a Sunday, we had just beaten the crowd and didn't have to wait for a table.
author: Shelley T.

description:
My friend and I were wandering around Fillmore and decided we were hungry. He had been to Pizzeria Delfina before and suggested it, knowing full well I am a self-professed pizza snob. Luckily, this place did not disappoint! 

We weren't super hungry, so one pizza was enough for us. We ordered the Margherita and I asked for prosciutto. The pizza arrived, and the prosciutto had been laid on top and cooked with the pizza. I wish I had requested it on the side, but that's my own fault. The prosciutto was tasty and the pizza was cooked perfectly. Our waiter, whose name I unfortunately can't remember, was extremely pleasant. This snob will definitely be back!
author: Sarah B.

description: This time it was okay. Pizzas were not great. Expensive and way too loud. Had to squeeze in everyone. Too small for the seating and we are not big people. We have participated twice. I think not a third. Sad
author: Robin F.

description: I get the hype. Everything we've tried here has been quality, and all about simplicity and freshness. Most (if not all) of the pizza's are Neapolitan-style. Two that we've tried recently and would order again (and again) are the Margherita DOP for a simple classic, and Salsiccia if you're in the mood for something with more action happening. A few other dishes that we love to complement with a pizza is the grilled asparagus, chilled trip "streetcart-style" and Neapolitan meatballs in Sugo. Buenisimo!
author: Alex B.

description:
Always bomb, no matter which location you decide to nosh at.  I've been there a couple of times and have never gone wrong with my food :)  A thin-crust pizza type of place that is filling, but not your deep dish hefty pizza (if that's what you're craving).  As my boyfriend says..."this is 'fancy' pizza", lol (he's a Round Table kind of guy).

Definitely get the meatballs.  The seasonal pizza I had most recently was a Carbonara pizza with white cheese, bacon pieces, greens, and an egg on top.  They also really spruce up the typical chile pepper flakes that all pizza stops have...they oven roast regular chile flakes, which brings out an even more intense spiciness.  1 flake had my mouth pleasantly heated.
author: Mon T.

description: Pretty good neopolitan pizza. It not like Chi or NYC. Good choices and crust just right.  A bit chewy and super ultra thin
author: Jeff C.

description: Whenever I'm visiting SF I must eat here. Best burrata cheese. I was told by a waiter they make it in house. And the Panne cotta is probably the best I've ever had.
author: Heather R.

description: Wowza. The carbonara special pizza was sooo good. Had a nice little spicy kick to it. Went great with a bottle of rose and Delfina's deliciousos meatballs.
author: Madie H.

description:
Because both Bi-Rite and Tartine Bakery had epic mind boggling eye bulgingly long lines, I settled for pizza, which wasn't really settling at all! 

Their burrata with arugula is clean and fresh and the pizzas are wood fire thin crust perfection. I could quite honestly pack away a whole pizza...and then some...if I were by myself, of course, for no one to witness such sumptuous gluttony. 

There is limited seating inside and a few tables outside. The only comment would be to have the heat lamps turned way way up in the late afternoon through evening. That blusterous Karl is truly a barometric foe.
author: Christina S.

description:
Wow. This place really went above and beyond for us.

We ordered the Prosciutto Pie twice via UberEats, and twice it came with the arugula missing, which is a highlight ingredient of that pie.

So this second time, I decided to call the restaurant to see if it actually comes with the other ingredients as it states on the menu. The girl who helped us, Kelsey, was amazing. She was so understanding and just wanted to make things right.

Apparently, there's supposed to be a separate box that comes with the pizza with the other ingredients, which was never given to us. Kelsey called UberEats to ask if they could come pick it up, but when she couldn't, she called us back to tell us to order another one through UberEats and she'll have the driver come by and she'll make sure everything is packed correctly, AND gave us a fresh pie AND comp'd us for both orders... AND gave us a gift card to come back for the inconvenience.

Wow. So grateful that good customer service still exists. We went from being pissed and not wanting to ever come here to planning a date night for us here. 

THANK YOU KELSEY!
author: Sue C.

description:
Pizzeria Delfina has been on my list of places to eat at in San Francisco for a decade now - but I haven't gone back to the city for almost nine years, so I hadn't made much progress. I wasn't planning to be in San Francisco that day, but this and that made us change plans and go there. Eating there still never crossed my mind until someone asked the sales assistant in the Rag and Bone boutique where Pizzeria Delfina was; suddenly my eyes darted in the direction she pointed to, and I saw that bright yellow sign. Ah, it was surely destiny.

When we entered at four in the afternoon on our way back from a tour of the Fillmore Street shops, we were led straight to an open table - no waiting. Score! The waitress was super friendly; service throughout our meal was stellar. The saffron arancini were like no other version of that dish I've ever had: They were tiny little... I want to call them "popcorn arancini." The rice had a vivid saffron color and that distinct taste (though not too harsh) with little bits of molten cheese inside. Ah, just delightful, especially with a pitcher of cold Peroni Nastro Azzurro. The Margherita DOP is a version of the venerable Neapolitan standard made with San Marzano tomatoes, mozzarella di bufala, and other ingredients sourced from Italy. The buffalo mozzarella didn't melt as nicely as I would have liked, but the flavor of the pizza was fantastic. The lasagna di Mezzogiorno was rich and lovely, heavy with cheese and sausage between the layers of spinach pasta, while the "Sunday supper sauce" had bits of slow-cooked pork in it. I was crestfallen to hear they had just sold the last butterscotch budino - I haven't had it since a really rude host at Pizzeria Mozza caused me to start boycotting that place nearly a decade ago, so I was really looking forward to it - but the silky, clean buttermilk panna cotta with blood orange and almonds was a wonderful consolation.

I loved the bustling little space that's not overdesigned or uncomfortable (although I concede that, had one not been as fortunate as were we to slide right into a table, one might not be quite as sanguine about the whole experience as were we). Pizzeria Delfina feels just like what a fun, hip city restaurant should be: good food, refined but not too conceptual, in a vibrant-but-relaxed environment. This is definitely a place to which I'll want to return.
author: Andrew W.

description:
First pizza in SF I've had that has real flavor!

Just ordered take out. And only a single pizza. I'll have to go back for a salad. Calamari in the photos looks promising too.

The tiny dried herbs they give you are spectacular as well. I'm not a pizza connoisseur, but each bit was full of flavor. The correct bread to sauce to cheese to topping ratio. Thank god. At last. If only it weren't pizza, maybe I'd give it a 5.

I'll see you guys soon to taste the rest of the menu.
author: JWest M.

description:
Delicious, quick service but pizzas do take a while but they bake me fresh ! :) 

I recommend the mushroom pizza they had - so delicious and the overall feel of the restaurant is great
author: Joanne H.

description: This is the first Italian place I've been in SF and I loved it. The place is really nice and inviting, the food is delicious!!! I recommend it 100%
author: Papus L.

description:
Haven't been to Delfina in years and first time to Pac Heights location.

Early lunch with a prosciutto pie & arancinis with a Peroni and a glass of white.

Arancini was sooo salty and the pizza was good but nothing to get all giddy about. Prices verses portion are worth the price.

The server wasn't very focused or together but it's alright.
author: L D.

description: If I could give a lower rating I would. Fast food restaurants have better customer service than this place. Our waiter was a complete jerk. I have no idea how this guy even has a job with that attitude. Super rude & was giving me sarcastic responses when I asked questions about things on the menu (mind you that I have NEVER been there). Their food is also over-priced & not all that great. Totally felt like this guy looked at us up & down, felt that we couldn't afford or were worthy enough of eating there, and treated my family like garbage from there on out. Biggest mistake I've ever made. AND he was upset about not getting a tip. Lmao here's a tip asshole:smile and work on your customer service.
author: Yessy V.

description: This place is great!! Excellent pizza with a thin crispy crust and amazing soups and salads. Although the food always brings us back, it's the service that locks it in. The staff is a symphony in motion. Hope is superb with her customer service and she doesn't miss a step. She always is welcoming with her beautiful smile. Great team and great food!! We sat at the counter and enjoyed watching the expertise of the culinary staff. We forgot to add cheese to our pizza and even though we would have been fine with a sprinkling of cheese and quickly melted, Hope said they don't put the same pizza in twice. She made us a brand new pizza and was very accommodating!!! We will always enjoy coming back to Delfina Pizzeria.
author: Veronica L.

description: Won't be going back, although I did give them four chances.  While the toppings and sauce where good, the crust was always soggy, I had to fold the slice to eat it.  For a rather pricey pizza, you think they could do better.  Also the longest wait for just the Pizza I can ever remember.  Still that would warrant two stars.  What brings them to one -- is the friendly "SF mandate" fee multiplied by the number of children you have.  Absurd.  Not family friendly -- and that mandate fee is B.S. -- only aspiring fufu places do it in S.F., and let's not pretend it can't be more honestly covered in their already high prices.  Spent over $100 there with three kids, for soggy pizza.  Why it gets such a high rating here only shows how many in S.F. think they are getting a quality experience if they spend a lot on what is largely fluff (i.e. -- just decent toppings and literature).
author: Gibo M.

description:
Pizza. Like real Italian pizza. If you know, I don't need to say any more.

My only wish is that "fries with eyes" frequented the menu more. Changed my world.
author: Johnathan K.

description: The pizza is good, but the tripe is to die for. I come for the tripe. Great texture, simply prepared, and the chili oil, lemon, and sea salt DIY seasonings complement the dish and each other very well. Yes I just did a review of the tripe at a pizza place but to me this is the star!
author: Bo M.

description:
I hadn't been to Delfina in a while and have been on an absolute pizza tear lately so it seemed like the natural thing to do. I've always been a fan of their pies, especially the margarita so needless to say it was nice to be back. 

We had to wait about 30 minutes for a table (which is usually the case) so while waiting we grabbed a bottle of wine from Molly Stone's across the street. Delfina has a great deal on corkage ($18), so make a mental note there. The waitstaff was super accommodating and brought us plenty of stemware for the group. Super attentive and nice.

We ordered a few pizzas and the Mary's roasted chicken as our mains. Skipped all the starters so we could crush as much pizza as possible. The chicken was really well prepared and roasted to
perfection. Try it! As far as the pizzas go, we got the marg, the prosciutto/arugula, and the Neapolitan. Of the three, the marg was probably my favorite because the cheese was excellent. Normally I go crazy for the Neapolitan because anchovies are my favorite thing on earth but, that night the marg was king. 

Delfina is a great little neighborhood joint so if you're in the hood, check it out.
author: Benjamin F.

description: Delphina pizza crust is great. Crisp on the first bite and delicious-ly chewy with the flavorful toppings. Fennel laced Sausage, mushroom/fungus, thick globs of cheese. A small place with a hip young vibe. Adviseable to make reservations during their busiest times (Lunch/Dinner).
author: Don W.

description: Pretty solid pizza joint! We ordered take out on a Friday night and it still took 45-50min. The food was fantastic though! We got the sausage pizza and the meatballs!
author: Michelle L.

description: We walked out of the restaurant. We were waiting for a table for 5 and it was like we were waiting to get into the coolest bar in town. They had tons of questions and the worst was the attitude. Since when did we become pretentious in SF?!? I used to love Delfina's but last time I was there it was the same crappy service! So this time I'm not going back.
author: Gimena P.

description:
So, the Salsiccia pizza is bomb. That alone is worth four stars. It packs heat and a lot of flavor - the Italian sausage and fennel combo is super satisfying.

However, the clam pizza was a huge letdown. My fiancé is a lover of all things clam, but even he was disappointed in how unappetizing this pizza was. It tasted very one-dimensional and the clams kept rolling off. I didn't like the tomato sauce base either.

I would come back to try other pizzas because the Salsiccia was that good. The salads also looked great.

The restaurant is relatively small and conducive to larger groups, so expect a wait. Luckily we didn't have to wait more than five minutes for a table. Happy to have an excellent pizza joint nearby. Just skip the clam!
author: Valerie L.

description:
So much fun.  Food and service were great.

Food: We had the Salsiccia pizza, Neopolitan Meatballs in Sugo and Mary's Chicken Alla Diavola.  All were superb with well blended, complimentary flavors.  Mary's Chicken was excellent.  It is a heavily spiced half chicken served simply with garnish.  The chicken is cooked well and juicy.  There is a bit of heat from the chili, but just enough to make it interesting, not spicy hot.  Serving sizes are appropriate.  We even brought some leftovers home.

Service: Excellent, fun service.  We were told there was a twenty minute wait when we called, but we were seated in less than five minutes when we arrived.  They don't take reservations.
  We had barely say down when waters were  brought to our table.  Our waitress suggested an excellent wine based on our preferences (not the most expensive) and my youngest daughter had "some of the best lemonade ever".  Our waitress had a good sense of our mood and we had a lot of fun sparring with her.  The timing of our entrees was a bit off, but our waitress quickly handled the issue.

Atmosphere: Hip and trendy.  Good for couples and families with older children.  Our daughters are twelve and fourteen and had a wonderful time.  Our youngest can be a picky eater, but she really enjoyed the chicken.
author: Greg S.

description:
With my parents in town visiting recently I wanted to check out a spot that I typically wouldn't go to on my own so Pizzeria Delfina was a great option.  Located in Lower Pac Heights, this location like the others is always bustling with a line out the door of hungry customers drooling over the wood fire pizza cooking in the back.  My fiance and I arrived a bit earlier than my parents to put our names down on the busy wait list - a pretty simple chalkboard system and the host/cashier at the counter keeps track fairly efficiently seating parties to the best of their ability.  Expect a wait of 30-45 minutes for a party over 2 as the seating in here is pretty limited but you can grab a beer or glass of wine from the counter to sip on while you wait.

When our name came up on the list, we were seated in a nice cozy table in the corner and the server greeted us immediately bringing waters and grabbing out bottle of wine to enjoy.  Delfina does cater to vegans with an option of getting a plain pie (no cheese) with a choice of three different toppings ($17).  Between the four of us we shared three pizzas, a vegan special (arugula, olives and mushrooms), a simple margherita ($15), and the broccoli raab ($17.75). Perfect to share between four people. The pizza came out within 30 minutes and was fresh, hot and not overly oily.  The crust was absolutely delicious, perfectly cooked and reminded me of the east coast style I am used to from back home. 

In all, a good experience at this location.  The best pizza ever? not sure about that, but a good atmosphere, great service and a fun neighborhood vibe in this Pac Heights establishment. A good place for date nights, meeting up with friends or bringing the parents while they're in town to visit.
author: Kelsey B.

description:
Not too bad, I'm sure the regulars think this is the greatest , as they should. I would give them 3 1/2 stars because the pizza is not bad
We went because of the reviews so it was on the list of "food places we gotta try"
Seemed like more of a "Yuppie" kind of a pizza place, The service is great, The Pizza is better than the average pizza and I might go back to try the meatballs, Two customers had ordered them while we were there they looked amazing.
I would go to Golden Boy or maybe wait at at Tony's, Speaking of Tony's, have any of you noticed the quality of sitting down to eat there as opposed to getting a slice to go? Night and day. Happy Eating
author: Joey C.

description: Great brocolli pizza.  We were seated immediatly... No wait.  Parking was good.  Entire experience was good.
author: Mike R.

description: Delfina's Pizza Salsiccia's my favorite pizza in the world.  Yum, yum, yum!
author: J C.

description: Came with a friend and sat at the counter. Split the meatballs and the sausage pizza. We were in heaven. Perfect portion for two. Great service and fun to watch the chefs prepare the food. Went around 9pm on a weeknight and was seated right away but I can see how the wait at a more popular time would be long.
author: Elise F.

description: The pizza was OK (not the "must have" thrillist and sfeater say it is) but the service was one of THE WORST EVER. Our server didn't check in on us once, and when we were ready to go, we had to wait 10m for our check, and another 10 just to get our card back. And on top of that, since we sat at the "bar", we had "the pleasure" of enjoying the plates being thrown around with complete disregard. Needless to say I will not be coming back and wont ever recommend it.
author: Fiorella L.

description: I have had better wood fired pizza. The base was excellent but the topping could have been better.
author: Sumit W.

description: By the slice is $3, it tastes decent, and is one of the best deals for food in the area, they might have better tastier dishes but that hit the spot without being over $10.
author: Robin H.

description:
I don't get this place. The pizza crust is invariably burnt.  I watched them make about  a dozen pizzas, and they always burn them. They simply don't know how to control the heat used in a Neopolitan pizza.

They are also too cool for pizza slicers so all of the pieces are different sizes. The toppings are forgettable and skimpy on the meat. The waitstaff is rude and acts like you're lucky to even be given a table. If you end up enjoying yourself and stay even a few minutes after you paid your bill, you'll get the death glare.
author: Sutee D.

description: I've had just about everything on the menu.  It's all good, but I SWOON for the meatballs.  I can't get enough of them.  I could eat them everyday.  I wish I was eating them right now.  Extra crostini please.
author: Jessica F.

description:
Hanging around Dolores the boyfriend and I decided to grab a bite to eat... so we thought Pizza. Originally, we were looking for a by-the-slice type of place but ended up here. 

We got the 4 Forenza/4 Cheese pizza (spellcheck) and Margarita (regular not DOP). The sauce we more on the salty side so eating a 4 cheese pizza didn't help lighten the saltiness of it. The margarita was pretty good but the mozzarella didn't seem to be very gooey and melted like I am used to. I would also describe their pizza to be more rustic.

Also, as you have seen the small plate with grated parmesan, tiny strains of oregano and red pepper is cute but I definitely wish there was a little bit more on the plate.  

Seating is tight but they do have both indoor and outdoor seating areas.
Staff is friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable about their menu.
Their lemonade was fresh and tart and the rose sweet tea was sweet but the rose flavor was very subtle.

I am not sure if I would come back anytime soon.
author: Ariel B.

description: FANTASTIC EXPERIENCE IN THE LATE NIGHT.  I stopped in close to closing time on an assuredly bizzy Friday night and was treated like a king.  Sat at the counter and dined very well as the PHENOMENAL workers of this pizzeria went about cleaning and prepping for the next day with absolute care and discretion.  I have always been impressed with the QUALITY OF SERVICE at Delfina PH but this night really blew me away.  GRAZIE 1000 RAGAZZI * the baccala' was 100% delicious.
author: Michael G.

description: The hosts were kinda rude, for no reason. Frustrating start. But the Romano beans and the authentic Margherita pizza, as well as our very nice server, who kept giving us more cheese, made for an awesome experience.
author: Andrew K.

description: Literally the WORST pizza I've ever had. The staff was rude and made us sit outside while we waited for our pizza and they burnt it after the fact. It's so flavorless and dry that a school cafeteria could outshine this place. We paid $15 for shitty customer service and a pizza that even Little Caesar's could do better. Do yourself a favor and avoid this hellhole. Save $10 and go literally anywhere else.
author: Nerise M.

description: Waited over an hour for this place, so I grabbed a pre-dinner ice cream at Salt & Straw around the corner. I was super hungry when we finally got seated. We ordered the crispy pig ears to start, which were really great! Perfect texture and a nice start. We also ordered three pizzas: the salsiccia and two of the specials they were having that day. The crust were perfectly how I like them. I can't remember the name of the specials, but one of them had a bunch of fresh cherry tomatoes on the taste which were amazingly sweet! Next time I come, I'll just order takeout to avoid the wait!
author: Cynthia M.

description:
I'd gone to Pizzeria Delfina in the Mission years ago. I've been meaning to go to their Pacific Heights' location ever since they opened, but never really had the opportunity. On Tuesday, October 6th, my pizza craving and the roommate's affinity for take out brought me here for dinner. I placed an order online at their website around 5:15pm. It was ready for pick up at 5:45pm when I got to the restaurant.

*Belfiore Burrata ($12): w/arugula, crostini & extra virgin olive oil
*Neapolitan Meatballs "In Sugo" ($16): Pork, beef & veal meatballs w/ tomato sauce & crostini
*Margherita ($14): Tomato, fior di latte mozzarella, basil
*Salsiccia ($18): Housemade fennel sausage, tomato, bell peppers, onions, mozzarella; add Arugula (+$3)

I adore thin crust pizza. Especially if it has a nice chew. Luckily, that's what you'll find here. I loved that they packed the arugula separately so it stayed nice and fresh. Went well with the Salsiccia. Their Margherita was good as well, but I wish it had more basil. Since we got take out, the crust in the middle of the pizzas suffered a bit and were soggy. The toppings kept sliding off. Still, they were some of the better pizzas I've had. The Burrata was amazing! Rich, buttery and creamy! I ate the whole portion myself! The Meatballs were a touch dry, but I loved the sauce. Yum!

One of my favorite thin crust pizza places close to home. Pizzas do suffer a little from take out, so I'd suggest eating the pies there! Next time, I know I will!
author: Elena N.

description:
It was an absolute gift to the pac heights neighborhood for Pizzeria Delfina to open this location.  

Have you seen the families waiting & dining here every single day?  

Where on earth were they eating pizza in this neighborhood before?!

Pizza Inferno?!  
I hope not.

They probably don't even remember.

They've blocked it out. 

Who wants to remember a time when there wasn't Delfina's fabulous pizza salsiccia, fantastic pizza margherita, or stellar meatballs?  

WHO?!

Perish the thought, right?

The prosciutto pie is great, too.  The tenderest prosciutto, the freshest arugula.  Flavor bliss.

This location is actually significantly more relaxed than the mission location; even when it's packed.

Not sure why, but I do appreciate.

You should always order an extra side of red sauce.  It's fantastic.

It's all about the sauce, right?
Well, the crust & the sauce.

Delfina nails them both.

5 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
Is it acceptable to like one relative more than the other? Guilty as charged! I'd done the Mission location for years - so conventional wisdom would suggest, "if it ain't broke, don't fix it."  
Well, I happen to be with others (yeah, I was following the crowd) they wanted to try the location on California Street. 
What a pleasant surprise.  There are MORE families at this location, but it isn't a bad thing - because there is also MORE space! 
And yes, the same great dishes found at my Mission location are found here, with a few extras! 
Parking is as much a challenge here as it is at the other location - but at California you're guaranteed to have more "elbow room!"
author: Nick S.

description: Still one of the great pizza place but hopefully service could be improved. Only reason will never order again! Ordered through online delivery and refused to do special pizza. No logical answer why couldn't they do it. I would imagine accommodating customer who has been ordering twice a month and spending $100/delivery since they open would be normal customer service. Extremely rude and sarcastic remarks why they cannot do any daily special pies. Extremely disappointed I'm sure will take my business to Delarosa from now on.
author: Steve S.

description: One of the worst pizzas I've experienced in SF during the last 20 years. I did order it through Caviar for a home delivery.  I ordered the cheese pizza with extra mushrooms and sausage. What was delivered was a charred crusted pizza with raw dough for 3/4 of the pizza..  I could not pick up a single piece.  I scrapped off the toppings from the raw dough, threw out the dough, and ate the toppings with a fork. One of the worst pizza experiences ever....
author: michael N.

description: They sucked! If I can give no stars omg that would be better. I went for the first time on my lunch break and got there at 12:10. At 12:40 I was fed up and just asked to pay for my wine, right at that moment my pizza came and they said everything was on the house. Good because I open the box and the pizza is half burnt. Get it together damn it!
author: Christine G.

description: Favorite pizza place in SF. The food is amazing and super fresh. We waited about 20 minutes for a table in a Friday night which is great. The staff was very friendly and helpful. Definitely can not wait to go back. Would love for the mission site to reopen as well.
author: Eva T.

description:
Pizzeria Delfina is heaven for the taste buds whether you are a pizza fanatic or not. I was worried about coming here particularly because I think pizza can be overhyped (see my Seniores Pizza review). This is not the case with Pizzeria Delfina.

WAIT TIME: The place was packed on a Monday afternoon at 1:00pm. However, the servers are hustling and the turn around time is fast. We opted for inside seating and if you want to get seated quickly, I'd pick the bar seating. Our wait was probably 5 minutes max. 

FOOD: OMGGGGZZZZZ Food is insanely good here. It may have been because they served dishes I like - Either way I thought their 'Cold Tripe' starter ($9) and their Funghi Pizza (~$19.50) was one of the best dishes I've had at an Italian restaurant. The Cold Tripe is not for the light hearted if you're not into weird foods. The taste is light with the right amount of salt, citrus, oil, and chili. They make it super interactive by allowing you to mix your desired portion of salt, oil, and lemon into the dish. I thought it was genius. the Funghi Pizza is one of their seasonal pizzas with hen of the woods mushrooms. I love mushroom pizza and really appreciated they did not just go with run of the mill crimini mushrooms. The flavors were on point and the crust was thin, light, and hot (temperature). I couldn't have asked for a better meal.

SERVICE: Excellent. The place was packed but our waters were refilled and the waiters/waitresses were excellent at checking in. We felt very welcomed there.

OVERALL: Go on off times (early evening, late lunch, weekdays). Order the cold tripe and funghi pizza. DO IT. I'm still dreaming about it.
author: Nicole J.

description: Pizza is amazing!! Such a good atmosphere and aesthetic. Great place for a night out with friends. The Panna pizza is my favorite and the burrata appetizer is a must!
author: Matilde M.

description:
Ate at the Pizzeria this afternoon and had a very attentive, gregarious and kind server. He also seemed like the kind of guy who could rap along to Eminem really easily. Also is probably really good at Office trivia. I think his name was Anthony? 

PIZZA WAS BOMB DIGGITY TOO. 
DRINK LAMBRUSCO 

Chop chop little onion
author: Tess O.

description: My favorite pizza in the city--del Popolo and A Mano are close behind. The little gem salad should become a permanent part of the menu because it's soooooo good!
author: Grace E.

description:
I've had this place delivered often at work through Caviar but this was the first time I've been to the restaurant. Tried almost every pizza on their menu and everything is really good. Very nice attentive service and only a short wait if you visit on an off hour. Otherwise it can be a long wait since they are so popular.

I like that they have bread sticks at the table for free. The waitress recommended the roasted corn with chili butter ($7) for an appetizer. The sauce was soo creamy and not too rich. We really liked it! The two of us shared a panna pizza - tomato sauce, cream, basil, cheese ($14) and it was enough food since we weren't too hungry. Its one of my favorites on their menu. Note that it's very saucy so if you're looking for more toppings try something else they have. I'd recommend getting your own personal pizza if you have an appetite.

Overall consistently good pizza but not the best I've had.
author: Linda X.

description:
San Francisco has not let me down once this week. We're here for our first wedding anniversary and I was looking for a good pizza place, you know, not Domino's or some crap like that. 

We had the Salsiccia pizza, house made fennel sausage, tomato, bell peppers, onions and mozzarella. Between the two of us we ate the whole pizza. I asked the waitress for a great wine pairing and she suggested a delicious red, Barbera d'Alba. I loved it.  

Atmosphere is quaint, location is great, and the service was perfect. They were attentive without hovering. 

Great night, great experience.
author: Allison G.

description:
We've been going to Pizzeria Delfina since it opened & its still the best pizza in town. 
Simple, crispy, tasty. Its all in the details.

...also, the meatballs are incredible.
author: Simon S.

description:
I'd give them 3.5 stars.

We were visiting a friend living in the Pacific Heights neighborhood and she recommended going to Pizzeria Delfina for dinner one night! No reservations are taken, and everyone in your party has to be present in order to be seated. The atmosphere is casual - very busy with a young vibe. 

We enjoyed the Margherita pizza, Prosciutto Pie and meatballs for 4 people. The pizzas were great- delicious with fresh and authentic ingredients, but by no means were they the best I have ever eaten (which some people claim on yelp). The crust was thin and crispy. 

We found that the service to be slow and below average. We had to flag down the serves multiple times for water refills, and they mixed up one of our pizza orders. In addition, when I checked my credit card balance the following week, I noticed that the restaurant charged me for the whole bill even though the dinner was split four ways. I quickly called the restaurant and they issued me a refund. This was the first time I encountered this sort of billing error, so I am glad that I check my credit card statement to catch their mistake.
author: Syyu C.

description:
Pluses of this restaurant are the food and location. Food is consistently tasty and dependable, though expensive for what it is.
However, the noise level is really awful. I had to talk so loud this evening just so the people at our small table could hear, that I had a sore throat when we left. We asked twice for the music to be lowered a bit, but our requests were ignored. The restaurant is small with an open kitchen-- that's noisy enough but tolerable. But coupled with loud, throbbing music, it makes for an overall unpleasant experience. There are other good places for Italian food in SF with a much better atmosphere, and a staff that seems to care more about making guests happy. Try Piccino or Pizzetta 211.
author: M. D.

description:
Sauntered in with a friend on a Thursday at 5:30pm and planted myself at a table within a few minutes. The pizza deities were watching over me.

Tricolore salad: A dish of arugula (green), radicchio (purple red), and endive (yellow). A lemony dressing was pre-mixed into the salad, which went well with the peppery arugula and slightly bitter radicchio and endive. The leaves were in their prime and gave a crunch with each bite. The salad was topped with rectangular slices of grana padano, an Italian cheese with a flavor similar to that of parmesan. I appreciated the simplicity of the tricolore, but felt that it could have done with even less of the dressing.

Salsiccia pizza: This pie had a thin base upon which the ingredients were built. The crust was charred and slightly puffed. The tomato sauce easily fell off of the pizza and onto our hands as it was topped with but a few melted bits of mozzarella cheese. Taken together, the thin base, charred crust, and tomato to cheese ratio kept this pizza refreshing bite after bite. Atop the cheese were thinly sliced red and yellow bell peppers that gave the pizza a both savory and sweet addition. The ground sausage was kept moist by the underlying tomato sauce and packed some mild heat.

It gets very busy in the restaurant, so you may need to flag your server down if you should need anything.
author: Cici T.

description:
I attended a demonstration of a supposedly italian recipe of grilled asparagus Chef Craig Stoll (who in this biography is devoted to authenticity among other things).   Why but why did he keep taking about italian cuisine and imply that the recipe is italian...why pepper your demonstration with italian this...italian that.  The recipe may be your recipe..call it californian, call it what you want, but please don't call it italian.  He literally drawned the grilled asparagus in butter and garlic.  The authentic recipe which is a northern recipe does not include butter.  In fact, italians do not drawn ANYTHING in butter or garlic.  Garlic is only used in southern cooking. The lemon is added at the end "al freddo" after you take the asparagus off the grill.  

Why is every chef in California compelled to brand anything and everything as italian?  First he talked about how the "gas" ovens try to imitate the wood oven in Italy..and then went on to say how they are better.  Why compare? Who are you trying to convince?

 I think that my biggest frustration is that he was trying to 
"educate".  Please do not educate people do don't know any better what is authentic or italian and what is not.  And Tuscany is not in northern Italy, it is in central Italy.  Northern italian cuisine does not include garlic and there is no such thing in authentic italian cuisine as a recipe that includes ground up garlic.  When garlic is used in Italy, they smash it, add it to the sauce, or oil and then they promptly remove it.  So your garlic information under the "italian education for cooking" was also wrong.
Why can't you guys call what you do Californian.  Own it as your own.  Do NOT sell it as Italian because it is NOT.  What he made this morning would not even pass as a french recipe.  you don't drown ANYTHING in butter.  

I find it frustrating because people do not know better. Not right!
author: Clara H.

description: This place is hands down the best what I call Mod Italian restaurant. Great service, super friendly staff. S/O to Sophie for giving us a great experience. We had the meatball- which was absolutely delicious(you can order 1,2 or 3) and the GREATEST BURRATA I HAVE EVER HAD. Olive oil was delicious and the crostini was perfect. We also had the radicchio salad which was stellar- tasteful but not too many flavors at once which is exactly what we wanted. And then- the speck pizza. Which was so incredibly delicious. The crust was very yummy and the pizza doesn't leave you feeling "bleh". Felt like we transported to Italy. We also had a great bottle of Italian rose. Will come back time and time again.
author: Kelly S.

description: One of my favorite pizza places in SF. It's harder than you might imagine to find a good pizza pie in this awesome city where you can fine the best cuisine in almost every genre. But when you're in the mood for thin, wood fired, tradition Italian style with fresh sauce and top notch ingredients like house made fennel sausage, this is the spot. Always great service. Their new Meatball pizza is a MUST try. 4 cheese meets meatballs like my Italian grandmother makes. 5 stars all the way.
author: Jason P.

description: Pizza was good, but nothing too special. But the service was awful. I ordered takeout, and it took 1 hour and 5 minutes for them to make two pizzas. I was chastised by the woman at the counter for arriving earlier than the time they quoted they'd have the pizzas ready (I was 5 minutes early). The pizzas were finally done 20 minutes after the quoted time. The staff ignored me the entire time I waited. Next time, I'll choose one of the many many  wood fired pizza restaurants in San Francisco that are just as good, if not better, than Delfina. Not worth the hassle.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Exceptionally good pizza. The DOM margherita pizza is absolutely worth the extra money. Clam pie is unusual but yummy and the lardo pie is also delicious. Sides and salads all outdid expectations and they don't take reservations (which I love) so you can always count on a short but tolerable wait.

The only downside and reason for 4 vs 5 stars is that the staff does not manage the hallway waiting area well. We were seated next to the hallway and spent most of our meal shouting over the people who were using the side of our seating area as a bar and also constantly worried that they were going to spill their drinks on us. I told management but they seemed a little confused.

Bottom line? Go! Eat! Have a great time but do NOT let them seat you at one of the two tables along the entry way.
author: Arlo G.

description: Pizzeria Delfina is a really fun place to dine. It's right off Fillmore, so a good stop for lunch or dinner after shopping. It's pretty pricey for a pizza, but the ambience, wine list, and other food options make it a great place to eat. Normally, the wait is fairly long for dinner. When people visit I will take them to Delfina and then Smitten for dessert next door and it is always a fun time!
author: Lauren A.

description:
Delfina was one of the top places to go to when I first arrived in SF. I put it off since it doesn't take reservations and I live at the bottom of the hill and didn't want to risk a tough hike up the hill and faced with a long wait. So luckily I was at the right elevation and had time to kill during the Fillmore Jazz Festival to put my name on the chalk board and wait.

The wait was about 30 minutes but it was a nice day so wasn't too bad. There wasn't enough room inside for our stroller but the staff happily offered to take it and put it out of the way. They have high chairs and free breadsticks (keeps the toddler and me happy till proper food arrives!).

We got the classic margherita pizza and the salsiccia pizza. The margherita is very simple but really nice. I found the salsiccia to be a tad boring although still nice. It would be nice to see a spicier pizza on the standard menu.

The soft drinks are unlimited refill but served in smallish glasses filled with ice. It got a bit frustrating flagging down a waiter for a refill every couple of sips and after a while I just gave up.

Overall good pizzas, you won't be disappointed but not sure if the hype I built up for it was worth it.
author: Tristan L.

description:
I have been to the mission location a few times and was happy when I relocated to Pac heights and had a local location. 

My recommendation is to eat in. I tried carry out and it just didn't hold up for whatever reason. 

However I did go with a group of friends - we shared a few pizzas, meatballs, burrata, it was all very good. You can't go wrong
author: David S.

description: BEST PIZZA Ive ever had. Good ol' fashioned brick oven pizza.  i recommend the Margarita pizza, my friend had the Panna and she loved hers also.  It gets hectic around lunch time, especially since it's a small place...but well worth the wait!!
author: Brea M.

description:
My go to pizza place in the city when with friends or by myself after a long work day and a few espresso beans (if you know you know).

Ordered form Uber Eats and got the Cherry Pie, Grilled Brentwood Corn (w/ Calabrian Chili butter)and Beet Salad (w/ farro, goat cheese and seeds) for me and a friend. 

Everything was amazing and really fresh. Sides were super filling and had tons of left over pizza. Will continue to order from them per usual.
author: Cecilia C.

description:
Saw that this place was pretty popular on Yelp, so decided to try it myself.

Setting: Very casual, hipster-like. Large bar area, with only a few tables. There's also seating outside, but no heating lamps and it doesn't seem like its affiliated with the restaurant. 

Service: Awesome! We told the waitress that we were newcomers, and she happily explained customer favorites, as well as her own. 

Food: I love the complimentary breadsticks (the crispy, cracker kind, not actual bread). Not a whole lot of menu choices, as it's primarily a pizza place. Honestly, it was pretty hard to read the menu. I don't know that the Italian dishes mean! After asking the waitress many questions, we ordered the warm citrus & herb marinated olives (hot and had seeds), panna pizza, and pecorino moliterno (basically, toasted bread with cheese). The panna pizza was very yummy (the waitress said it was one of her faves) and the crust was fantastic. 

The only reasons why this place doesn't get 5 stars from me:
- Takes forever to get a table! Waited about 30 minutes in the crowded waiting space.
- The breadsticks aren't unlimited! The waitress only refilled our cup twice, and then took it away. So sad.
- It costs extra for them to box the food. Of course we didn't learn this until after we got the boxes back and saw it on the check.

I'd probably give this place another try, since I know what to expect now.
author: Lauren V.

description: I love pizza, and having lived in New York I have eaten a lot of great pizza. For me, pizzeria Delfina is right at the top. Pros: much of their food is local, the food always tastes fresh, and although I am always satisfied, I never leave feeling overly stuffed. My favorites are the insole tricolore, the margherita pizza DOP, and the butterscotch desert, which to me is heaven in a glass jar. Also, the service is above and beyond. I look forward to every visit, and I try to get here as often as possible!
author: Nic Z.

description: I got a 4 formaggi Pizza with fennel sausage added and an order of meatballs with my girlfriend. The food was good but very expensive for a relatively small portion. We spent $40 and were still hungry afterward.
author: Ryan D.

description:
Busy Fillmore area where traffic and parking can be a challenge.  Nice bright, narrow, restaurant with counter, booth, table, and outside table seating.  Thus, your tushy has many choices.

Nice choice of pizzas, salads, and specials.  We had the Salcissia (sausage lover's delight) and the Prosciutto & Arugula pizzas, Fried Okra (addictive), and the Grilled Octopus Salad.  Variety of drinks too, ranging from house-made root beer and peach sodas.

Nice staff who are attentive and helpful.  For you match collectors...place has matches!
author: Scott L.

description:
We didn't encounter the rude waitstaff as many others have suggested. Curt, perhaps. Rude, no.

What we did encounter was a fresh, delicious pizza, typical of the style of New Haven / Naples. Not quite up to par with those in terms of the chewiness of the crust, but the thin crust before the edges is well done.

The particular pizza, the Broccoli Rabe ($17.50), was better than expected, if a tad salty. The two kinds of cheese go well with the rabe and olives.

Perhaps a little on the pricey side, it's still a fun date night treat.
author: Andrew R.

description: Pizzeria Delfina (and Delfina for that matter) is one of my all-time favorite, go-to spots. Be prepared to wait in a bit of the line, but it's so worth it. My go-to dishes include the belfiore burrata antipasti ($13), the neapolitan meatballs in sugo piatti ($16.50), the panna pizza ($14.50) and the prosciutto pie ($18.50). The pizzas are a great size and always delicious.
author: Hillary M.

description: I don't really think I need to say anything new in this review. The worst part about Delfina is the wait. Which is understandable once you see just how small the inside is, and taste how good the food is. Every pizza is amazing, and the meatballs are to die for. It's not a classic New York style slice, but instead smaller, thinner pies with the perfect amount of flavor in each bite.
author: Griffin S.

description:
I called and picked up the food this time.  Fast ordering, solid customer service and an amazing pizza. Try the Salsiccia with shrooms!

On another day, ordered a Margherita pizza to be delivered.  Minimal amount of basil used as a topping.  Turned more into a mozzarella pizza.
author: Andrew H.

description: Pizzeria Delfina is always busy and the quality of their food matches the highest standards. I'm their frequent quest. Their thin-crust pizzas are delicious, and the real star is, of course, Neapolitan pizza! However, if you decide to go there on Friday night or on weekend, you should be prepared to wait for the table.
author: Oleg K.
