Had dinner here last night and for the most part it was a good experience. The server was great, the pizza was excellent. Fiance had the squid dish which she liked. One star knocked off for the terrible wine. We were pleased that their bottles of wine are very moderately priced. Ranging between 30 and 40 bucks. The one we chose was blah. Both of us commented on how bad the wine was. My only knock on that is they put it on the menu. Maybe some people love it who knows.

However we did order the fried bread and mozzarella appetizer and oh man, warning don't order it. I love fried mozzarella sticks and the ones you order from a bar would be less greasy than this appetizer. It was also incredibly salty. 

The app was the only miss really in terms of food. We also got the simple salad which was really good and the pizza is awesome.
author: Hyung L.

description: One of the better Neapolitan style pizzas you will find in the SF area. I had the margherita and salsiccia pizzas. Both were excellent but the sauce and fresh mozzarella on the margherita were particularly enjoyable. I hope next time I have room for the fried pizza dough dessert cause the couple next to us had it and it looked amazing! Luckily we went rather early and were able to get in quickly. I'm not sure it would be worth the huge waits I have heard of. Don't get me wrong, it's a great pizza but pick your dining time carefully. Go hungry and try the fried apps as well.  The atmosphere was very pleasant as well as the service.  I will be back soon...
author: Mark N.

description:
Time after time I feel a long line is due more to a restaurant's hype, rather than it being an actual indicator of the magical meal I may or may not be waiting some crazy amount of time for.

Ok, so 45 minutes at 7:00 on a Friday night really isn't unreasonable...and Pizzeria Delfina lives up to it's hype- it's an amazing (and reasonably priced) meal! Please note: You MUST put your own name on the chalk board. Since we were "newbies" people had no problem jumping the line before us, not mentioning how the system works so that we could have our fair turn (but what do you expect in Pacific Heights?). 

The boyfriend, his two little sisters, and I decided to try Pizzeria Delfina before seeing "Horrible Bosses" at the Kabuki. (The movie lives up to its hype too- a trend for the night!) 

Our server (though I can't remember his name) was awesome! He was attentive, quick, and a ton of fun. Whoever you are- props to you!

We ordered:

Pasta E Fagioli (sp?) which, dear Yelpers, is NOT what I was expecting. This is no tomato based soup with small macaroni noodles, reminiscent of the Olive Garden version. This is a butterbean based soup with fresh cracked pepper and big noodles. And let me tell you- it was amazing!

Two Margherita Pizzas....which should really just be called deliciousness-minus-the-basil (they have like 3 leaves per pizza), cheesy-goodness-get-in-my-belly-now-ness. We only ordered two for the four of us...DUMB DUMB DUMB. We easily could have devoured another! 

For $41 bucks I fed four people. Not too shabby!

Minus one star for the ridiculously loud music...and the lack of basil on my pizza! (I'll be back despite my criticism!)
author: Annalise F.

description:
Ordered pulled mozzarella appetizer and the Napolitian pizza.  Supremely disappointed.

Incredibly busy, but the service was well done, kind and prompt.  Second star.

The mozzarella was both tasteless and tough - I honestly don't know where it comes from but store-bought cheese sticks have more flavor.  White mass on toast.  It could have been sticky bun dough and we wouldn't have experienced a difference.
  
When we got to opening the pizza, I literally laughed out loud.  Granted this pizza has no cheese, so it was an experiment ordering it.  There was so vanishingly small amounts of toppings I couldn't believe it.  Like barely any sauce at all (maybe two tablespoons?), the dough was barely wet, and so few anchovies or capers I figured they were metering them like pearls.  I counted 18 capers on the whole pizza.  Every third or fourth bite I got a hint of salty flavor from a tiny bit of anchovy.  From my point of view, this product does not count as a "pizza", it counts as barely wet dough with an afterthought of a few teaspoons of "toppings" accidentally spattered onto it.

We were laughing at the situation.  Along with one 4x overpriced bottled beer ($7) the meal cost us $31.  

Won't return.
author: Jonathan D.

description:
My husband and I were visiting San Francisco and the only reason we tried Delfina out was because it was the only open place at the time and I felt like pizza and beer. The atmosphere was casual and also a little hip, so I didn't feel too out of place with a hoodie and jacket. 

We tried their signature margherita pizza and meatballs on the side. The pizza was really clean and fresh and didn't have to worry about oil getting all over my fingers. 

Unlike the other reviews, we got there a little after 9pm on a Saturady night and we were seated right away.
author: Christa K.

description:
Pizza ok, over priced, salads too small. Extra charge of $1.50 per person which they don't tell you about until you get your check. 

They say charge is for healthcare for employees which is an unregulated voluntary tax. Unfortunately most people believe they pocket most of the money however no one seems to talk about it in the open. They should post what $ they took in and post where it went if it is truly for the employees which I am 100% for. Otherwise just raise the prices and put the $ in your pockets honestly. This goes for all the restaurants with this unregulated bonus they give themselves.  Hopefully the new affordable health care law will do away with this type of Popeye tax.
author: Mike W.

description:
Whenever I have friends visiting me from out of town, I always take them Little Star. Well, it was the end of a debaucherous weekend, we still hadn't been to Little Star, and they're not open for lunch. My friends had a flight to catch so a Little Star visit was out of the question. One of my roommates raves about Delfina so I decided to take my friends here instead. 

Now I don't think the pizza itself is as good as Little Star (the comparison might not be fair though since we're talking two completely different styles of pizza), but it's still delicious and five star worthy in my opinion. 

It was pretty busy when we came in, and the place isn't that big, but we only had to wait about 15 minutes for a table for four. The restaurant has a really cool, unpretentious, but still a little classy feel to it. 

We started with two appetizers. The fresh, stretched mozzarella, which was fantastic, as well as the spicy cauliflower. The mozzarella comes with a couple of pieces of crusty bread as well as a bed of some sort of greens that were yummy! It's lightly drizzled with olive oil as well. The appetizer was a little small to split amongst four people, but it's a good size to share with one other person. The cauliflower was delicious. There was nothing about it that necessarily blew my my mind, but it was spicy, which I liked. 

The two pizzas we went with were the four cheese as well as the panna, which had a little cream on it (sounds kind of weird, but it's REALLY good). Both pizzas were excellent. The cheese and sauce on both tasted very fresh, and neither pizza was very heavy. The pies aren't huge, but a good amount to split amongst two people. 

Even though the restaurant was busy our waitress was very attentive, and knew the menu well when we had questions. The prices here are reasonable, with most pizzas costing between $10-15 and most appetizers under $10. I'll definitely be back!
author: George A.

description:
I honestly think I could eat at Delfina every day for the rest of my life and be perfectly happy with every encounter... even though I've cut meat and dairy from my diet! Sound crazy? Well, of course it does....

There's not much I can say about their fine array of delectable, artisan Italian pizzas that you haven't read previously, but for the vegan types out there who still like to join their pals for a gluttonous night on the town, don't let a stop through this particular pizza parlor leave you with the desolate, sexless option of eating nothing but garden salads and crushed red pepper. 

Upon asking my lovely server if they could whip up something that'd be appropriate for precocious youngster who doesn't animal byproducts, it was no sweat off of her perty little brow to recommend a vegan pizza consisting of spicy marinara, broccoli, mushrooms, and fresh basil. Once piping hot and sitting in front of me, the flavors worked so well together, I honestly think the presence cheese would have been a bit of a deterrent. It was easily one of the best vegan pies I've ever consumed, and it totally beat previous vegan versions I've consumed with that strange synthetic soy cheese alternative that most other pizza joints use in lieu of actual Mozzarella for difficult eaters like myself. Of course, that's not to say I'm complaining about spots that substitute Daiya cheese or some other cheese-but-not-really-cheese product, it's just that with ingredients this good, all you need are the plant based goods for a remarkable creation. 

What makes it even better is that the pizzas are small enough to where if there's any contention over which pie will arrive on the table, it's quite possible for each person to order their own individual pizzas and avoid a crisis. If you've worked up a pretty mean hunger, it's easy to pounce on a whole pizza just by yourself, but if you're more sated half way through, you'll walk out with a couple of slices to heat up in the company communal toaster oven the following afternoon. Problem solved!
author: Ruggy J.

description: $3 extra for 3 fillets of anchiovies.  Rip-OFF.
author: Veritas V.

description: This is our go-to place for pizza. Not only do they have great pizza, their side dishes are all great. The staff is friendly and efficient. We love this place. It would be nice if they could turn the music down a bit.
author: Lee D.

description: When my husband wants a special night out, we head straight to Delfina's. We love the burrata salad and broccoli raab pizza. Can't go wrong with wine on tap either. Although it's a bit on the pricey side, it's well worth the cost for a bustling ambiance and delish offerings. Arrive early! The wait can be long.
author: April S.

description:
It's hard not to like pie from Pizzeria Delfina. I can't believe it's taken me this long to sample their offerings. 

Start with the napoletana with mozzarella added on for that dash of cheese, then move on to the carbonara with farm egg, which tastes like pasta on a pizza. Finish off the trio with the broccoli rabe. It will make you feel like you're getting a dose of veggies, thus eliminating the guilt that will inevitably ensue for having just noshed on three pizzas.
author: Lee H.

description:
The best pizza I've ever had, anywhere.  Sorry.  That's just the way it is.  

You'll obviously have to have strong feelings about super thin crust and minimal cheese to agree with me.  

I've tried many, many others.  I always come back here.
author: Goolie G.

description:
Pizzeria Delfina makes the most authentic Italian pizza in San Francisco.

That is a big statement to make, certainly. I eat a lot of pizza. No, we're not talking Round Table, Pizza Hut, Costco or other chain pizzerias; we're talking real Italian pizza. I work in Italy every summer for roughly two months (I'm an archaeologist) and I eat Neapolitan pizza two to three days a week while I'm there. Thin crispy crust topped with buffalo mozzarella cheese, prosciutto, mushrooms, corn ... you name it, I've had it. When I come home to California, I don't want to eat pizza or pasta ever EVER again. I also can't stand to be in the freezer section in the supermarket, but that's another problem.

I am ready to eat pizza again after my tomato, basil and garlic detox is complete sometime around November . When I want an authentic pizza, I head to Pizzeria Delfina. I only go for lunch because I don't have the patience to wait for a table during their dinner rush. If there are more than three parties on that chalkboard, I'm moving down the street to another establishment. I unfortunately don't live in San Francisco anymore, and Pizzeria Delfina is on the list of places I eat when am back in town.

The fried pig ears are amazing, and my favorite pizza on the menu is the salsiccia. A few times I've had one of their rotating pies and I haven't be disappointed. The place also has Peroni on tap, the best accompaniment for a fine slice of pizza.

If you like Chicago, New York, or other heavier pies this place probably won't rock your socks off, but I hope you try it and appreciate the differences between the two traditions.
author: Victoria K.

description:
I'm torn between a three and four star rating...and yes I would go back.  My reason for going back was that the service and food was good.  I was a cool atmosphere and I had a window seat....However, I'd like to have one more type of pizza before I go crazy and fall in love with the place....COME ON, YOU KNOW WHAT I MEAN!!!  JUST NEED ONE MORE PIECE!....ok, i'm going back because the piece that I got was good....COME ON, YOU KNOW WHAT I MEAN....

Bottom-line - Good pizza, good service, hip place, around a good neighborhood.
author: Ron B.

description: Best pizza I've had in San Francisco, with a thin delicious crust that you finish every bite of, great cheese and restrained but delicious toppings. My favorite is the quattro formaggio, then the salsiccia, but they're all good, and if you ever see the spicy, fatty amatriciana special, order it. I've been really pleased with the appetizers and vegetables too, especially the arancini and anything fritti. Service is very aloof, but I don't care.
author: Cecilia L.

description: Fantastic Neapolitan style Pizza. One of the few that tastes authentic and right out of a brick oven, vs a convection oven. Don't just walk there, RUN FORREST RUN!
author: E ..

description:
Eating at the counter, one of the chefs was cooking a sauce and kept double dipping his spoon into the sauce.  He kept  dipping without cleaning.  
Give it another try..,.Popular place, but the waitress at the counter (12/16/2010) was not good, and the Pizza..No it is not the best.  Frozen taste just as good.
author: John B.

description:
Wait - 1 hr for a party of 4. Smaller parties got seated a lot faster.

Vibe - Hipster crew with a splash of family friendliness. The music was awesome but cranked a little too high to have decent conversation with your party.

Food - Margherita pizza is the best! Fresh globs of mozzarella, amazing sauce, and a crust that was so delightfully thin and chewy and crispy at the same time that I ate all my crusts. ALL! Salsiccia is your typical sausage/bell pepper/onion/mozzarella pizza, but the fennel sausage really makes the pizza outstanding. Tried the Capricciosa which is not on their regular menu. It had prosciutto and artichoke on a bed of cream sauce, but it was a little lacking in flavor and pizzazz. The meatballs are rich and flavorful, but on the salty side. The buttery bread that came with it was absolutely divine!

Staff - Awesome! They have the greatest personalities that are a perfect match for such a high volume and limited space restaurant like this. They even brought me gelato for my birthday (tahitian vanilla bean with pistachio praline, chunks of cherries, and the TCHO chocolate sauce. SO GOOD. I tried to contain myself from licking the bowl, but ended up spooning the chocolate sauce directly into my mouth anyway).

Will come back again for my Margherita fix!
author: Moraia W.

description:
I like large heavy pizzas with tons of toppings, but there is something about the pizza from Pizzeria Delfina that is simple but refreshing,

Food: Tried a few different pizzas, they were all good. I usually don't eat my crust, but I ate the crust from here.

Ambiance: We called ahead and picked up our order, but the restaurant was crowded for 10 pm and had a very energetic but cozy feel to it.

Service: Pizzas were ready when we arrived and they kept the prosciutto and arugula separate so they wouldn't get soggy, I thought that was nice.

Price: Not cheap for the quantity but good for the price.

Overall: If you like thin crust pizza, you'll like Pizzeria Delfina.
author: Binh D.

description:
came here last night after a day of studying and this pizza ALWAYS hits the happy spot in my belly.  This place would be a 5 star minus the never ending long wait!

Every item that we tried was easily 4-5 stars!  SO DELICIOUS

1. Fresh-stretched Mozzarella  8.25 - 4 stars - the unfortunate part of this was that they ran out when we ordered but they brought out a fresh batch for us as long as we didn't mind it coming in the middle of our dinner.  it was GOOD but it wasn't as stretchy or as tasty as i imagined.  maybe i like baked mozzarella more?  i expected more flavor to come out from the pieces of mozzarella.

2. Margherita - Tomato, fior di latte mozzarella, basil $13.00 - 5 stars - SO AMAZING!  every bite is a mouthful of juicy cheesyness and tomato flavors.  typing right now makes my mouth drool.  this is my favorite pizza here, hands down!


3.  Salsiccia - Housemade fennel sausage, tomato, bell peppers, onions, mozzarella - $15.75 - 5 stars - if you love MEAT, this is the item to order.  Every bite guarantees yummy housemade sauce.  It's a little on the salty side but really, if you're ordering sausage that's exactly what you expect. 


4.  Neapolitan Meatballs in Sugo - 13.75 - 5 stars - my absolutely FAVORITE.  sometimes i wish they provided more bread so you could scoop up every little bit of sauce that comes with the meatballs.  very smooth creamy taste and the meatballs perfectly complement the taste of the sauce.  definitely a splittable dish.  

5.  Prosciutto Pie - Prosciutto di Parma, caciocavallo, mozzarella, panna, arugula = $17 - 5 stars - like the concept of a pie but i still prefer the pizza over the pies here.  the prosciutto is very fresh and the presentation is absolutely stunning.  taste is GOOD but not my favorite.

Add a pitcher of beer and the total came to $120 with tip.

negatives:  SUCH A LONG WAIT!  A long wait to get seated (over an hour on a Monday night), a long wait to take our order (probably because of all the people), a long wait to receive our food.... SIGH.  This place would definitely be bumped up to 5 stars if we could solve this waiting problem!
author: Sandy L.

description:
While visiting SF, we went to Pizzeria Delfina in Pacific Heights on a Friday evening (around 9pm) the line was long (about 10 to 15 ppl in the line) but we asked to be seated at the bar and was seated right away.

Ordered the broccoli pizza, marinated olives, and a bottle of chianti.

Service was excellent.  Atmosphere was casual, fun and lively... sitting at the bar meant we got to watch all the wonderful food being made.  

Pizza was amazing - good amount of toppings, top quality cheese and the crust that reminded me of Italy.  

We didn't finish our bottle of wine and the waitress packed it up in a brown paper bag for us (apparently this is legal in SF..yay!)

It's hard to find pizza like this where we're from (Vancouver BC) and it's one of the most memorable meals we had in SF.
author: J B.

description: I like to come here on sunny days and wait for an outdoor table - totally worth the wait as you can enjoy your meal basking in the sun and people/dog watching. I always order the Salsiccia+ arugula which in my opinion is the best combo- and this place cooks this pizza perfectly.
author: Jennifer F.

description:
So worth the wait, but wished the portions were a little bigger. I've been coming to Delfina for years and have been to both SF locations. I do frequent the Pac Heights location over Mission because of the size of the restaurant. The wait, however, is no different.

The Margherita, Clam Pie and Salsiccia are always done so well. I cannot complain about the quality of the ingredients. The slices also do not fold or get lump anywhere, a true sign of excellence. I can never get enough of their Insalta Tricolore or thei iced teas. MMMM
author: 3beeskitchen ..

description:
Best. Pizza. E V E R. Yes. 

My husband is so picky with food but really enjoyed their tricolore salad (still talks about it in fact..)

There is usually a wait, but it is sooo worth it.
author: Dana S.

description:
Really Great Pizza,,, The best....  5 stars... but minus one because...

There is 1 waitress that started about 6 months ago that makes me want to vomit all over my plate when I am there... 

So I now get take out because her voice, ( which carries through the place and penetrates my soul ) is so loud, condescending, and childish that i cant stand to be there... She has ruined it for me... Never again will I wait 45 minutes for their Delicious, fantastic, amazing pizza, when I all I have to look forward to is an unsettling dining experience.

You know who I am talking about, really tall, skinny, brunette, voice like nails on a chalkboard... seriously I cant be the only who thinks this... Am i right ?
author: Scott G.

description:
After scoring on parking (fist pump!!) we walked up to Little Star Pizza and realized that the Divisadero Location doesn't open on Mondays!  DOH!!! (insert sad & ugly-moded face...) 

After putz-ing around the neighborhood for a few minutes trying to decide on an alternative plan I suggested this snazzy joint named: Pizzeria Delfina!! 

!! Pig-Out ALERT !! 
We ordered 2 pizzas for 2 people b/c the pizza's only come in one size, they aren't very large, and we were HONGRY (like the hippos!) 

Pizza #1: Prosciutto Pie
         (Prosciutto di Parma, cacioccavallo, mozzarella, panna, arugula)
Pizza #2: Margherita
         (Tomato, fior di latte mozzarella, basil 
****** & because we're ruthless carnivores we decided to add fennel sausage (not sure what the extra charge was).

Service was pleasant and everyone was kind. The wait was about 20 minutes so we walked around the block to kill time. 
When we were seated it was loud and difficult to hear each other talk. 
Ingredients were SUPER fresh and the flavors were delicious.
Pizza #2 was unfortunately served about 10-15 min later than our first pizza. We weren't upset about it but our server came over and apologized before we had a chance to inquire or register a complaint. 
We figured the kitchen forgot about our fennel sausage request and they just needed the extra time to prepare it. It wasn't a big deal but I could see how this could be frustrating if we had to be somewhere after dinner.

** To make up for the late pizza, we were comped 2 servings of their freshly made gelato. We had their Malt and Cantoloupe flavors which was a great combination. (The very sweet malt complemented the flat/milder cantaloupe. :) 

One weird thing I noticed was that they charge $1.50/person for the long thin bread sticks they have on each table.

In the end we were pretty satisfied with our meal. We originally hoped to have a deep dish pizza but the thin crusted ones we got instead were still very tasty. (We killed the 2 pizzas! (only 2 slices leftover!) It was pricier than what we anticipated on spending but we're just glad to have gotten our pizza fix. 

SOLID 3.5 stars. 
Guaranteed, I will return for more.  =D
author: Karen G.

description: Great pizza but very long wait for Saturday lunch. Got the sausage pizza which was fresh and great tasting. The staff was super friendly. Just wish the wait was shorter than 35 mins for two people on a Saturday at lunch.
author: Sean G.

description:
Who would of thought cracking an egg on top of a pizza can be so good. And for a girl who loves topping more than crust, Delfina has the pizza I love. I came here with a group and we each ordered our own pizza, that way we can share because sharing.... is caring..... The wait for a table can be dreadful but you're always welcome to order a drink and sip on it while you wait. 

What we ordered:

Mussels and Clams - Love the broth and goes well with the bread. Fresh mussels and clams.

Calamari- Small portion and once again, (I see the theme of this restaurant) Excellent SAUCE.

Salsiccia- (housemade fennel sausage, tomato, bell peppers, onions, mozzarella)- Careful when you take your first bite, it will burn the top of your mouth. I think what I love about delfina's pizza is everything is really saucy! 

Clam Pie (cherrystones, tomato, oregano, hot peppers) - Seafood Linguine on a slice of pizza. I could taste the sweetness of the clams.

Special -Purgatorio (spicy tomato sauce, 2 farm eggs, add sausage) - Creatively done with two running eggs on top of the pizza. I'm inspired.

Special - Fungi (wild mushroom, add sausage, panna) - The only white sauce pizza we ordered that night. One of my favorites. 

Excellent service from our waitress. Food came out in a timely manner, considering all the pizzas they have to make: to go orders and the other seated customers. I'm delfinaly craving for a slice now.
author: Christina W.

description:
We arrived late Friday night at Delfina, 9:45pm or so, and were seated after a short wait at the bar. Our waitress was bright and bubbly, picking up our order in just a few minutes. We ordered arancini for an appetizer, a personal favorite of mine that you can find EVERYWHERE on the East coast, but not so much out here. The arancini were amazing, a bit over-salted for my taste, but still delicious. I didn't think to ask, but I always find that they're delicious dipped in marinara sauce, but I bet they would have obliged had I asked -- try it out for yourself and let me know how it is!

For dinner, my friend and I split the Salsiccia pizza, which was absolutely delicious. Our food experience was fantastic, and I will definitely be coming back.

The notes below are in the hopes that the couple next to us someday flip through the yelp reviews:

Unfortunately, our evening was interrupted by the couple sitting next to us, or rather the woman sitting next to us who chose to berate her fiance in the shrillest of voices for over 30 minutes, for an issue she created in her head about the level of attention that he was paying to her. Neil, if you read this, friend, you can do so much better. My friend and I spent the entire time trying to play it cool and not get up to tell her that it was unnecessary to continue to emasculate you after you had already apologized to her three times for which you should have NEVER APOLOGIZED. You weren't in the wrong, she is bat-sh*t crazy and please reconsider a lifetime with a woman like that. Awful. You were doing everything you could and there was no way to appease her. Good luck with whatever you choose to do.
author: E. P.

description: The best in SF - both food and service.  Worth the wait and then some.  Superb pizzas and other dishes for those who don't want a pizza.  AAAAAAAA+++++++
author: Christin A.

description:
I think Pizzeria Delfina was one of the first in this new wave of fancy pizza joints, but after going back today -- after a way-too-long three years since my first and only visit here -- I think it may be the best.  We got there around 11:30am today, and were shocked that we got a seat immediately, since we always see lines every other time we drive by.  We started with the grilled asparagus special, which came topped with lardo butter, bacon, and bread crumbs.  Amazing!  I'm sure all the other stuff cancelled out the healthiness of the asparagus, but I'm still glad we started with veggies.  However, the crostini, fried asparagus, and arancini also were very tempting.  

We followed that with the Salsiccia pizza and the meatball calzone.  The calzone was just perfectly cooked, warm, gooey, and cheesy on the inside, with a nice light, crispy shell.  The meatballs were delicious and not too dense.  We had the Margherita and Salsiccia pizzas last time, and both were good, but the sausage was definitely the most memorable.  Today, the sausage was again super good, and the pizza had the just the right amount of toppings on a perfectly crisp and chewy crust.  It was just right.  The prosciutto pie and the special Gricia pizza also looked really good, and I think we'll be back soon to try some different pizzas, but we'll probably also get the sausage pizza again too!  

I also have to give a special shout out to the staff, who were all very friendly and helpful and always there when you needed them.  Just an absolutely perfect lunch today.
author: Pilan C.

description: Tried the quattro fromagio pizza, chard with pine nuts and the fresh mozzerella with arugula. All fresh and delicious. The olive oil they use is high quality. The fresh lime drink was very good and made with their house made selzer water. Everything is fresh
author: Piper W.

description:
2010 brought me back to my 13th year, when it seemed like every other week there was a large envelope waiting for me in my mailbox. It was Bar or Bat Mitzvah season and I loved it. ( parties involving chair hoisting are always good in my book )

6 engagements blossomed last year and I couldn't be more happy for my friends. One in particular, with a dear friend from college finally had the 'bended knee' moment that even Boys II Men would be proud of.

To celebrate the coming nuptials I took them out to Delfina and we had a feast.

Arriving around 6:30 on a Friday evening, we chalked up our name on the board, and enjoyed the atmosphere along Fillmore. 

Beverages are offered during the wait and if you're with friends, there's really nothing to worry about.

Delfina is a casual spot, with a sense of culinary precision. You're sitting in a kitchen, surrounded by great friends, and the host just wants to deliver pizza after pizza to you.

The Napoletana and Salsiccia were hits. Comfort food with exquisite toppings made slices fly. The crust is a light foundation that allows a speck of salt to shine or a protein to take the lead.

A side salad of fresh greens and lemon vinaigrette balanced the meal while crunchy breadsticks played a resounding percussion session along the way.

Delfina is a SF favorite, as is this couple headed towards the chupah. Mazal Tov!
author: Mike K.

description:
I came here on a Sunday night around 7 pm and there was a big wait. The hostess said the wait was around 20 minutes so we decided to stick around but the wait was probably closer to 40 minutes. You have to write your name up on the blackboard yourself so don't wait outside assuming that you're in queue.
We finally got in and were seated at a table near the door and it was really cold. The place was also really loud and I felt like I had to talk over it and strain to hear what my friend was saying to me.

The waiter was friendly and took our order and answered our questions related to the menu. The food took a while to come out and we didn't eat until past 8 pm. But each table got long skinny breadsticks so I nibbled on those while waiting. I got the broccoli raab pizza (a little spicy!) while my friend got the salsiccia pizza. Both of the pizzas were good but nothing to write home about in my opinion. I ate 2/3rds of my pizza and left feeling really sick of bread.
Overall, the food was just OK and not really worth the wait or the price and I probably won't come back again.
author: Bommy C.

description:
I can't believe I waited so long to try this place.  I love Delfina and pastas so much, so when deciding where to eat I also revert to Delfina. But the Pizzeria is just as amazing!

We arrived early (6 pm) on a Thursday for dinner.  We were lucky enough to be seated outside, under a heat lamp.  At about 6: 30 pm, a line started to form.  The service was nothing special, but our waitress did recommend the perfect glass of red wine.

The food is superb!  I LOVE their thin crust.

+ Grilled corn and arugula salad - so tasty and refreshing!
+ Clam pie
+ Salsiccia pizza

Eat here!
author: K V.

description:
What pizza should taste like. Not a style or brand, but pizza. Italian pizza with pretense. Missing are the paint by numbers topping list or the silly named specialty pies.What we have here is pizza, wine, music, and gelato in a complimentary combination for this neighborhood eatery. Go here and enjoy. 

What we ate:
Fried Smelt
Fresh Pulled Mozzarella
Prosciutto Pizza
Choccoc
author: Patrick A.

description:
PROS:
- Their pizza is very popular. They have neopolitan pizza with unique toppings. 
- The pizza tastes good. You can tell that the ingredients they use are fresh. 

CONS:
- The portions here are so small for the price. A medium sized pizza costs approximately $14, does not include any meat toppings, the size of a small pan pizza, and is so thin that it is only enough to feed 1 person. My bf and I shared one and we were still hungry. 
- There is a 30 minute to 1 hr wait. 
- The place is so small that there is no room to wait inside. You have to write your name on the chalkboard then wait outside on the sidewalk.
- There is only street parking.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
Pizzeria Delfina kind of rocks my socks off.  

The pizza is really unique, I'm not sure how I feel about the crust, but the toppings are always tasty, flavorful, and fresh.  The broccoli pizza is so unusual, a real stand out.  Also, I'm a huge whore for a great margherita pizza, and theirs is pretty good.  I've had some nice sides/salads/antipastas, too... especially love their olives (served warm!). 

Pizza aside, I like the ambiance.  Hipster hottie waitresses are super friendly and great with wine recommendations.  The music is always bumping.  Lots of fun.

P.S.  the chalkboard sign-in in lieu of a hostess?  LOVE IT.
author: Julie H.

description: Lets be frank, anyone who says their is "amazing" pizza in sf is a straight up liar, or they've never had a real east coast slice, it's all in the watar. But, the truth is I'm a fan of this place and its the best pizza I've had since I've been here
author: christopher h.

description: Came to Pizzeria Delfina the other night for the first time. My overall experience was pretty good. I was a little frustrated by the wait time and check in system. You put your name on the board and wait for them to come sit you at a table. I saw several tables open while I was waiting. The service at the table turned the experience around. Aileen was super friendly and had great recommendations. Everything I had was delicious, especially the house made gelato.
author: Sara H.

description:
We got there early on a Saturday evening - around 6:30 p.m. - and I was surprised that there was already a line forming. Luckily, a lot of people put their names on the chalkboard and went down the street for a drink...and their names ended up getting called pretty quickly. The estimated 1 hr wait ended up being 20-30 minutes. There isn't much of a bar area for people who are waiting for their tables, but it's probably worth staying close to the hostess in case your name is called.

I started with beet salad and the large meat platter which was probably a bit aggressive. The large meat platter was great - a wide selection of salamis, pepperoni, proscuitto...the works. The beet salad was hearty and heavy on the beets (which isn't always the case with beet salads!).

I ordered the broccoli raab and olive pizza, though I probably should've gone with my first instinct in ordering the margherita as the olives were just too briney for me. My friend got one of the special pizzas of the day that had sausage and a bitter green - that was quite tasty.

I'm not a dessert person but as we were sitting at the bar, I saw them making this amazing looking dessert that looked like a version of a funnel cake (but instead of strawberries, cream!) - the zeppolino (or something like that). That dessert probably single-handedly moved my rating from 3 stars to 4 stars. Delicious.
author: Wendy L.

description:
Best place in San Francisco for pizza, hands down. I'm torn between 4 and 5 stars but am going with 4 because it's always crowded and you'll have to wait for a table.

The first time I went here we ordered the Margherita and the Salsiccia, assuming the latter would be more interesting and we'd like it better -- not so! The Margherita is so simple but so delicious. 

I've gotten take out once from here before as well. That significantly reduced the wait, which was awesome, though the pizza definitely wasn't quite as good since we didn't eat it right out of the oven.
author: Sydney L.

description:
Fabulous place for Sunday brunch...even outside when it's cold and wet (ceiling heater and slight overhang for some protection from rain).  I came here on two consecutive Sundays.  Both visits were fantastic.  And what I love even more is that I'm able to dine here with my dog just hanging out beside me.

The meal on my last trip included the following:
Cali-ceci (salad with calamari, garbanzo beans, olive oil), Salsiccia (super thin crust pizza w/ housemade fennel sausage, grilled red peppers), and a glass of Moscato.  After tasting the Salsiccia pizza...I'm a fan!  This is one of the best tasting super thin crust pizzas all around.

Service is great.  I never feel rushed out...I can take my sweet @ss time eating, people watching and some chit chat w/ passersby who want to stop by and pet my Kyoko =)

 Total bill for one was approximately $42 including tip.
author: Michelle N.

description:
Mmm...yummy

I came here for a lunch date w/my homegirl and we had some pretty amazing food. We ordered the insalata tricolore (very tasty and refreshing salad!), broccoli raab pizza (surprisingly yummy. a bit salty from the olives tho), & limoncello (sooo good). i'll be back for more delfina...
author: Natassia S.

description:
I've had the prosciutto pie and the broccoli raab pizza.  I didn't think either one was particularly fantastic.  The price was quite high, almost $20 for a pizza I could easily eat in one sitting.

Tonight for a change, I got the fried asparagus with lemon brown butter and parmigiano and a calzone with cheese (caciocavallo and another) and nettles (which really could have been any type of bitter green).  The calzone was okay, but nothing to write home about.  The asparagus, on the other hand, was amazing!  Far and away the best thing I've ever had from Delfina.  Next time I go, maybe I'll just get like three orders of that for dinner.

I will keep exploring the menu, and maybe when I find the right entree to go with my asparagus, I'll come back and add another star or two.  But for now, I'm really not that impressed with the pizza.
author: Marty F.

description: delicious pizza and meatballs.  The service is usually cheery and the atmosphere very pleasant. The specialty lemonades are great, too.   Occasionally the wait can be long to be seated, but it is so worth it.   The pizza is light in crust, the ingredients very fresh and just really, really good!
author: Gabby M.

description:
Great Pizza's with enriching flavors.
 
Personally I am not a fan of the white base ones so if you're going in for the first time stick to the regular menu choices, you will not be disappointed...  at all!

It's the best pizzeria in my neighborhood so many more visits are in order and this review is bound to be updated!
author: Sumit G.

description:
pizza sch-mizza. try. their. meatballs. immediately. 

i like pizzeria delfina's pizza a lot. they just do it right; with their super-thin, wood-fired crusts and simple yet sumptuous toppings like the fresh-stretched mozzarella and house-made fennel sausage, it's what i imagine pizza in italy tastes like. but the pizza is NOT the best thing on the menu here, not by far. 

i had been happily dining on PD's pizza for several months when i wandered in on a blustery, rainy san francisco winter day, and pizza just didn't seem like it would cut it. in fact, i was skeptical about how five meatballs with no pasta could possibly warm me, but thankfully, blissfully, and deliciously, i was so wrong. 

the meatballs are juicy and fork-tender, almost melting in your mouth, if that wasn't a kind of gross thing to say about balls made of ground meat. they arrive in a stoneware pot, in a pool of bubbling marinara sauce, with a piece of roasted pork to flavor it all. they are absolutely, hands down, without a doubt, no ifs ands or buts, the best meatballs i have ever had in my life. 

at $13.25, i will admit that they're a little pricey (that's $2.65 a ball!). but honestly, after trying them, i would probably pay $3 or $4 a meatball. because they're totally worth it.
author: Kris G.

description:
Recently moved to SF, and this was my first Pizza experience after being told to go by many friends - and I must say it was NOT a disappointment.

However, I must warn you - there will be a wait.  It is very popular and if you are up for the wait (I waited 1 hour), it is well worth it!!  No reservations are taken!!

When you come in, write your name down on the chalk board to your left, THAT is your waiting list.

You are greeted by bread sticks waiting for you on the tables when you get in, which should help after waiting for a while.

Warm Olives and Fresh Pulled Mozzarella were very very good as a apps!

Salsiccia pizza - AMAZING!!  4 Formaggi pizza - Very good!!  And the Panna Pizza - INCREDIBLE!!!

Pizza's are made extremely well, a bit on the small side, but not personal pizzas by any means.  Music that played when we were there had a late 80s/early 90s theme - but it was fun to listen to.

It is a very active and small restaurant with an open kitchen.  You can eat at the counter if you like.  Big parties are very hard to accommodate.  Probably better for 2 or 4 tops!

If you can ask for Cindy - She is awesome and funny and an attentive waitress!!

ENJOY!!!
author: Jorge C.

description: fun spot for weekdays after work. Pizza was delicious! no seating so got take out. would go again any time
author: Xing L.

description:
Been to both locations and they are practically identical.

Cons:
This place plays their music quite loud.  It's very hard to carry a normal conversation unless you are seated outdoor.  But who da hell wants to sit outside in SF weather??
The wait is horrendous......It's like going to Ikes during lunch hour.  I never understand how a popular restaurant can remain in such a tiny place.  I waited almost an hour for both locations and it definitely sway my opinion of this place.

Pros:
Awesome thin crust pizzas for a reasonable price.  

Napolentana: This one has anchovies and olives with a tomato base sauce.  You gotta be careful because the olives and anchovies flavors are very strong.  People who hates anchovies will definitely hate this.  I liked it.
Salsiccia: It's like a combo and is definitely the star of the night.  I love their tomato sauce and fennel sausages.  Topped with green bell peppers and mozzarella.  Must get.
Margherita: The basic pizza and also very delicious.  It's gotta be that tomato sauce.
Calzone: A non tomato sauce with Nettles, Ricotta, Pinenut, Cacciocavallo.  This would be my favorite if not for the smaller size.  Who said size doesn't matter?  I want more of it.

Finals:
Due to the wait and horrible parking situation, I can only encourage people to order takeouts.  Pizza is not worth standing in some cold windy weather for an hour.  Also, make sure you order a side of tomato sauce because each pizza has alot of crust.  You don't wanna waste food now, do you?
author: Ricky N.

description:
Am I being picky? I've tried this place twice, once with my boyfriend a few months back and another just this past Friday with my coworkers for lunch. 

The first time going, I ordered a Margherita and Salsiccia pizza and started with a ciccioli. The ciccioli was described to us as mozzarella sticks battered with pig fat and that was exactly what we got. The first two bites were scrumptious and definitely FATTY. As it started cooling down, I just felt nauseous. *shiver. Never again.
Our pizzas came and the portion was just right. The crusts are thin and pizzas simple and bare. The pizza margherita definitely needed more than the few slices of fresh mozzarella on it. I guess that's how they make it and it's not what I was expecting. The Salsiccia was good with a perfect and crispy crust... But other than that, i feel like I've enjoyed better. Our first impression of the restaurant didn't leave a lasting mark. 

The second time going with my coworkers, it was a light lunch. Started off with a delicious and lightly battered Sand Dab. That was good with lightly sprinkled lemon juice, olive oil, and dipped in aioli.  Then shared the broccoli raab between three of us. First thoughts? The broccoli tastes exactly like the leafy and bitter Chinese broccoli I eat at Chinese restaurants down to the bit. Just covered with cheese and with some sprinkles of salty olives. Meh...

I'll come for convenience but probably nothing else...
author: Rosanne L.

description: Nice hip ambience with good thin crust pizza and appetizers like the cauliflower. We came here for lunch and was fairly busy. Pizza I would say was good but not awesome hence the 4 star. Want to try the PA location next...
author: Mihir M.

description: The downside of this place is the incredibly long wait (most of the time). If you happen to go at an off hour, the pizza is good and they serve some micro-brew beers on tap. Don't order the pizza for takeaway unless you live very close to this restaurant because this pizza really needs to be eaten hot (it's that thin crust style).  A favorite there is the mushroom pizza (seasonal with no sauce, local mushrooms and cheese).
author: Amy L.

description:
This remains as my favorite restaurant in SF. Great food, drinks, service, atmosphere, and specials. 

Heat lamps outside make this a doggie friendly place to eat even on a cold day.

Excellent Arnold Palmer as well.

The meatball special is AMAZING. Please add it as a regular dish!
author: Captain B.

description:
On my first visit, super hungry, me and 2 other guys ordered 3 pies, a bottle of wine, an appetizer.

A place like this, doesn't disappoint for a number of reason. Just to let you know, most of these reviews you're reading are like 'my first impressions', 'first visits,' and if you liked what you ate. Yay. If you didn't like it, you trash the place like as if they dunno how to run a business or make the damn pizza.

This place in some ways, reminded me of some of the pizza joints I ate way back as a child growing up in the east coast. Pizza's back there - they got character. Some will hate that it's not made in this way or that way. Too much salt. Too much this. Too much that.

Delfina got a character of its own. It's very new yorkish in some ways (to me, not you okay? shut up for a second), and the taste kinda has that certain inspiration behind it.

You won't be dissappointed. Don't compare with other individual pizza joints because, some of these reviews are kinda so stupid to read.

Come here on a day when you really feel like you want pizza. If you come in because the line was too busy at a Thai restaurant you originally planned to go to, you're gonna feel mediocre about this place or any other pizza joints.

5 stars, because I wanted italian food. Narrowed down to pizza. Delfina delivered.
author: Paul P.

description:
I went here Saturday night with my sister. She's a real Italian food fan. 

We made several attempts before to go here, but the line was just too long. So, if you want to go, then come early. 

The food was one of best Italian food experiences I've had in recent memory. They had some special appetizers not normally on the menu. Tripe and pig ears. Seriously! they were really good. 

We had the sausage pizza. The sausage was clearly homemade and was so juicy and tender. We also had a side of meatballs which were wonderful. They tasted like the meatballs my friend's Italian mother makes. 

Dinner was topped of with some gelatto. We had scoops of hazelnut and chocolate gelatto. So good! So decadent. 

Service was superb. I'll be back!
author: Jack R.

description:
I ordered and enjoyed the Panna Pie which consists of: tomato sauce, heavy cream, basil, Parmigiano-Reggiano, and olive oil. A different pizza, the broccoli raab, was not even close to being as good. 

Alan Richman ranked the panna pie at Pizzeria Delfina as #3 on his list of the best pizzas in America. It's very good, especially for $10. But this is probably not the third best pizza in the United States.
author: Rob M.

description:
O-M-G ! 

The pizza, the fried mozzarella, the breadsticks, the ambience!!!!

Worth every minute you wait to get a table, and you will wait for long...
author: Gianluca V.

description: Love love love Pizzeria Delfina. Delicious pizza, friendly vibe, nice and comfy space to dine in. Glad I had a chance to try their pizza. Fans of Pizzeria Delfina, if you're ever in Los Angeles, you would love Wolfgang Puck's Pizzeria Mozza: http://www.yelp.com/biz/pizzeria-mozza-los-angeles
author: Steven L.

description: The salsicca pizza, the meatballs, and any of the salads are about as good as it gets. Good wine selection and a staff that knows how to recommend a good pairing.
author: Kyle C.

description:
So we waited for 50 minutes to get in and we order 2 pizzas and an Iced tea. The guy with pierced nose is serving us and happily replaced the tea with lemonade...never mind. He realizes and asks to give us iced tea, but we were OK without it. We are eagerly waiting for the pizza and when we get them they are not the ones we ordered. We tell the guy that he has messed up and he did not even offer any apologies or offer to take anything off the bill.

Well...food is good but its not cool to mess up 2 things out of 3 and not try to make up for it.   I spent a lot if time waiting so as a paying customer I demand a level of service expected of a place with the price and rating it has on yelp
author: Nadia C.

description: I came here with a recommendation from my cousin and this place was amazing. Great service, delicious food especially the pizza and mussels, and a good location. I would come here again when I travel to the City again.
author: Kevork T.

description:
Some of the best pizza in town - go to know the 'hidden menu'. Awesome

Order the 'magic pie'
author: Jon C.

description:
Whenever I pass by this place I always see a huge crowd of people waiting, so I never really had a desire to try it. Was always curious though. Lines suck, but there are magic hours to come, and luckily I hit one of those with the lady.

Onto the review! The fact that this place changes their menu every day is very interesting! These guys definitely know how to make a fantastic pizza!

We ordered the special of the day which had spicy sausage and olives. It did not disappoint! The flavors were so well matched together with the cheeses that it was simply fantastic with every bite. They know how to make a mean cappuccino too Foamy and very strong. Worth every penny!
author: Michael N.

description: Best pizza I have had in a very long time. Service was also excellent. Try the Napoletana.
author: Tara R.

description:
There sure isn't a whole helluva lot to this pizza.  

EXCEPT FLAVOR, bitches!  Less is more in every way.  Although, I'm a fiend for truffle oil and had to add a little to my Quattro Fromaggio with housemade fennel sausage.  I hope Delfina doesn't hold it against me.  But truffle season's over and I was Jonesin'/

I grabbed my pie to-go and all of the three ladies who welcomed me and said hello were just icing on the cake.  Be sure to get the sides of peppers, parm, and oregano.

Oh, and, it's easy to eat it all by yourself.  Trust.  (To coin a Jessica-ism)
author: Tamar D.

description:
Service is mediocre, they are not very nice in general. 
Kind of noisy if you are looking for a quiet place, although I don't mind the noise. 

Food Is good. We were a big group on the table (8 or 9) , few of us asked for different kind of vegetarian pizzas, although at the end they all looked and tasted suspiciously similar. They were fairly good dough.
author: Isa J.

description: Was visiting San Francisco, and I was told that this place is a neighborhood hot spot. Usually always has long lines...But the afternoon I walked by there was no line and no wait, so I decided to check this out. They had this really huge and yummy fried mozzarella stick that was the highlight of my meal. Unfortunately, the pizza didn't live up to it's restaurant name, it was merely average...It gets half a brownie point for having an egg on the pizza though. I love egg.
author: Cathy L.

description:
When I heard that Delfina was opening in my neighborhood, I was SO happy - I never liked Zao, which had previously occupied the space.  Since its opening a couple of weeks ago, I've been eager to try it out.  Tonight my boyfriend and I decided to go there for dinner.  It was....OK.

We got there at about 6:15, and only had to wait about 20 minutes for a table.  It seemed that the people who arrived after us had to wait a lot longer.  I was surprised that the place was crawling with kids (literally).  They don't seem to have high chairs, but that didn't stop the hordes of Pac Heights moms and dads, who dined with babies on their laps.

I thought that the food was quite good.  I enjoyed the margherita pizza - the best part was the dough, which was fresh and chewy.  They also had a good selection of red and white wines by the glass.  Prices seemed reasonable, too.

Service was good, too.  This place is BUSY, but even though she was rushing around, our waitress checked in with us just the right amount.

What I didn't like: again, this place is packed and busy, and something about the acoustics of the floors and the walls combined with the big crowd of people made it very, very loud.  The music didn't help, either.  While our meal at Delfina was a good one, I can't say it was relaxing.  I'm really glad that Delfina is in my neighborhood, but I think I'll try to avoid it during peak times.
author: DD B.

description:
Everyone who knows me knows I love pizza. So when this place opened up in my often-visited neighborhood, we had to try it. On Tuesday night, coming home from work, I get off the bus and it's right there in front. It smelled good from the outside.

There was a wait when we arrived. We were slightly confused about how to get our name in since there was a line already formed. Note: put your name on the chalkboard yourself. The chalk is inconveniently placed on the right side of the little aisle (board is on the left). The wait wasn't too long, though the people behind us seemed to be there forever.

We split the Insalata Tricolore: Arugula, radicchio and endive with lemon, extra virgin olive oil and grana padano. It was good. I liked how the lemon and oil countered the natural bitterness of the greens.

We each got out own pie. She stuck with the Margherita. I stepped out of my comfort zone and ordered the Broccoli Raab because it came with spicy peppers. The food didn't take to arrive and it was delicious.

So why only 3 stars? The atmosphere! You couldn't hear yourself think let along carry on a conversation with your dining companion. the hard floor, the hard walls, hard ceiling -- all contributed to the sound bouncing every which way. At times, I felt like we were shouting just to be heard.

The pizza is thin and crispy. It reminds me of some great pies I had in Italy. The quality of ingredients is fantastic. Just wish it were pleasant to be there because I'm not sure how the pizza would hold up after the 5 minute walk home.

Service was also a little slow at the end. I think we waited 20 minutes for the check.
author: Dave B.

description:
A friend and I went for dinner after catching a movie at the Clay. She wanted to go to Dino's, luckily I talked her out of that horrible place, and instead we went to pizza heaven. We had the margherita pizza. The super thin crispy crust was delicious and perfect for a late night bite (not too heavy, yet still filling). The tomato sauce was a delicate balance of tart and sweet.

The pizza deserves 5 stars, but I'm subtracting half a star for service. It took quite awhile to get our check.
author: Dani D.

description:
This location is simply not as consistent or as good as the Mission pizzaria. The waitstaff here can also be incredibly rude. There have been several incidents, which run the gamut from serious attitude over the phone when requesting vegetarian topping accommodations to waitstaff being terse and rude when you "only" order a pizza. I'm just one skinny girl. How much do you expect me to eat? 

I've also paid, only to be given no change, which means that the bitchy waitress effectively tipped herself 35 percent on top of tax and the bullshit SF health ordinance fee. When I politely inquired about the status of my change she looked at me like I was insane. I guess the Pac Heights noveau riche don't mind getting screwed, but I do. Craig, I'm a huge fan, but do get your house in order!
author: Jacqueline A.

description:
The food is okay, but definitely not worth the price. Also, these guys charged me the full amount of the bill on my card in spite of my friend paying half by cash. I was in a rush and traveled out of the country shortly after, so couldn't go back to have them rectify the error. 
Fail. I'm not recommending this place to anyone.
author: D B.

description:
I went here on a beautiful Friday afternoon with my friend and we were pretty hungry. We were seated right away which was nice. 

Some of the pizza topping sounded a little foreign so we just asked our waitress what she recommended.  We ended up ordering the Salsiccia and it was delicious- the fennel sausage was on point.  We also asked for her beer suggestion and I forgot the name of the beer but it was a pale ale which went well with the pizza.  Our low-key classy pizza and beer meal on a warm sunny summer day definitely hit the spot for us.

Funny side note, the bread sticks on the table look like decoration, but yes it is edible so don't be afraid to nibble on it as you wait for your food. My friend and I sat there for a while contemplating if it was food or decor and we were so hungry already so we broke a piece off and ate it and realized it was indeed food. They refill those too if you eat them all up!
author: Jenna T.

description:
Yummy, this place has a fun atmosphere and I love the type of Pizzas they offer. Great original combos. I'm a thin crust person and this place hit the spot. The crust on mine was a little over done but I loved the spinach meat combo and the very homemade feel. 

I'd go back here all the time if there wasn't a line. They probably don't take reservations because they don't need to because they are always busy. I waited about 20 minutes but at least there was a heat lamp and, well, I'd probably wait again.
author: Lauren B.

description:
Delfina is just an excellent pizza place. I had the prosciutto pie, which is topped with arugula. It was light and refreshing (for a pizza) and I didn't feel all fat and bloated afterwards, which can happen with pizza. My boyfriend got the pie with the house made (i think) sausage. That was delicious, but I think the toppings might have been a bit too heavy for the crust to support.

All around great meal, if I lived in the area I'd go back!
author: Jordan L.

description:
2 thumbs down.  Service was bad, waiters were annoying & lazy, and the pizza was burnt!  

1. We (my sis, bro, and myself) got seated by the window and the waiter brought us our glasses of water.  We were settled and ready to order after a few minutes.  A waiter approached us and instead of taking our order, he asked us to move to a different table.  WTF.  They wanted to accommodate another party that just walked in.  Seriously RUDE.  Being too damn nice for our own good, we said fine.  

2. After moving, the waiter finally took our order.  We decide on a special they had for the day, which included mushrooms.  The other pie was the "Salsiccia" with sausage, tomato, bell peppers, onions, and mozzarella.  The pizza finally arrives and we're irritated & hungry at this point.  The first thing we notice is that the crust is BURNT.  We take a few bites and realize most of the bottom of the whole damn pie is BURNT.  I've had enough thin crust pizza like this all over NYC and SF to know that these pies are messed up.  Crispy thin crust pie should not be burnt, especially for an establishment with such rave reviews.  But again, we're too nice and hungry and just keep eating. Also, the "special" pie had about 4 slivers of mushrooms and it was about $17.  Such a rip off.

3. The entire time we're eating, the waiter doesn't come by ONCE to check on us or refill our water.  It's a little past the lunch hour so it's not super busy in there.  Also, we're seated right by the register, where all the waiters are standing around CHATTING and being lazy.  

I haven't felt so irritated in a restaurant as I did here.  Just because you have lots of reviews on Yelp, doesn't mean you can serve burnt pizza and slack off on service.
author: Cynthia H.

description:
Excellent experience across the board.

A friend and I came in for a pre-work birthday nosh.  As a devout pizza lover and East Bay resident, I was not sure how high the quality would be across the bridge!

We started with the mozzarella in carozza which had great texture but was a bit bland.  I decided to save mine to eat with the sugo that accompanied the AMAZEBALLS, ahem, meatballs.  These meatballs were exactly what a meatball should be: moist, flavorful and absolutely delicious.  They alone cinched a repeat visit.  And I was right, the sauce on the mozzarella improved it dramatically.  

Lest I forget, we had a tasty roasted cauliflower with dried capers and peppers.  I'm not a fan of the vegetables generally but this was good and assuaged my guilt about the other items.  

Finally, the pizza.  We ordered the prosciutto pie and it was very good!  The arugula on top could use a bit more flavor in its dressing if it's going to be such a prominent ingredient but otherwise it was great.  Excellent crust, cracker crisp on the bottom.

Our service was absolutely lovely and very attentive.  Maybe it's because my friend tattled that it was my birthday but either way, I intend to return and find out.
author: Shauna F.

description:
Almost 3 years later and this place is still always packed.  After the first few months of it being open, we actually stopped bothering because of the crowds of people shrouding the doors. Unless you're eating at off-peak times, prepare to wait - even for an outdoor table on a foggy night. That being said, they have overhead heatlamps that make the outdoor area quite cozy.

One semi-foggy Saturday afternoon around 4pm, we walked by and saw that all of the outdoor tables were open, so we figured why not.  Having already stuffed our faces a few hours prior, we opted to only get pizza and wine - no starters. We got the pizza special - cherry pie - marinated cherry tomatoes, ricotta salata, basil, and olive oil. This was THE perfect pizza pie. The combination of the toppings with the juiciness of the cherry tomatoes was deeeelicious. I even ate the crust.

Now, we were only going to eat the pizza, but as our server listed the gelato flavors, we were very intrigued by the blueberry swirl.  Oh yes, we caved in and got dessert. There wasn't as much blueberry as I'd expected, but mmm mmm mmmm, dessert was good.  This was quite possibly the most perfect meal we've had in a while. The best part is that it was so unexpected.

We will back, Pizzeria Delfina....and hopefully a lot sooner than another 3 years from now.
author: Lisa C.

description:
My companion and I wanted to enjoy the nice sunny day today and so we ventured into the hood to satiate our gourmet pizza craving. We rarely hit up this side of town and thought we'd do some window shopping to soak up some of the sun ray while the weather's dry. We usually go to the Mission Delfina and thought we'd pay this Delfina location a visit and let me just say, we're glad we did!

This location is much roomier than the Mission Delfina and so we barely had to wait before we were seated. No surprise, it was busy when we arrived but the wait was no more than 10minutes. The staff here is super attentive and super friendly. Our bread sticks was refilled before we even had to ask and our orders were taken without us needing to waive our server down. Throughout our entire meal, various servers came over to check up on us without being annoying or pushy.

The pizza needless to say was divine and no better than the Mission location but the obvious difference between the two locations was the service! Thank you staff & servers for making our first experience here so enjoyable and fun! Although it's not a high end place, the service definitely was top notch! We'll definitely be making return visits! 

P.S. Thanks for proving such an awesome array of 80's music!
author: Soozie H.

description: For the quantity and quality, there are much better places in the city. Overpriced and overhyped.
author: Austin B.

description: Pizzeria Delfina makes very delicious pies. We were greeted promptly by a friendly server who put our name on the blackboard and offered to take our beverage order. The friendly service continued once we were seated and throughout the meal. The varieties were innovative without being pretentious. I didn't need to use the Google Italian-English translator the way I do at certain competing pizza establishments in the  city. The thin-ness and crispiness of the crust, the tanginess of the tomato sauce and the fresh creaminess of the cheese all jived with my hardened New Yorker standards. The only regret of the experience was the Zeppole di San Giuseppe we ordered for dessert. Zeppole are by definition balls of fried dough - a spherical cousin to the beignet. At Pizzeria Delfina they are thin flat rounds of pizza dough that have been deep fried and adorned with a mascarpone-based icing. The taste was decent, but they were not hot enough (possibly attributing to the time taken for decoration) and they definitely were not zeppole. Next time we will skip them.
author: Keith R.

description:
Walking down Fillmore street reminded me so much of the fancy streets of San Diego, PB and OB, except with way more white people.  Everyone's a yuppie and out to see and be seen and spend some money.  Pizzeria Delfina is a great place for it since you can sit inside or out and thanks to a cut-out window still feel the breeze at your back.

The pizza combinations are wonderful and it was my first time trying a pizza with egg on top.  Yum!  We also had a prosciutto pie with withered spinach.  I walked to the bathroom in the back and all the male chefs/servers waved to me.  Oh I feel pretty!  My BF said he went to the bathroom and no one waved at him. Sorry!  The service was great and everyone was happy and friends with each other.  2 pitchers of Anchor Steam and I was loving this place until the bill came.  Yow!  $16 and $18 pizza (6 small thin crust piece each) plus 2 x $18 pitcher equals quite a bill for 4 people, but hey that's the price you pay to be fancy on Fillmore.  Now that I've been I'm over the hype and you can find me at home with a Pizza Guys delivery since I'm not one to frequent such yupster places.
author: Holly B.

description:
Fresh pies if you can handle the lines.

I'm not sure i'd wait for anything for over an hour (you can't call in a reservation #fact), but if you like moist dough that melts in your mouth and you can cut the line Steven Spielberg Hollywood style- Delfina is more fun and tasty than Space Jam.

Bisous.
author: Noah W.

description:
Second time here and it still doesn't fail to deliver! This time though I came with two friends and dined in ordering:

Insalata Tricolore   8.5
Arugala, Endive, Spinachish Salad w/ lemon vinaigrette and grana padano (cheese) ~ the salad, light fresh using top quality ingredients and if you ever buy arugala or endives yourself its quite expensive to get them of this quality. so don't be off put the price its shareable! and pairs great with pizza

Margherita  12.5
Tomato, fior di latte mozzarella, basil ~ perfect, thin crust pizza. What more can I say just try it yourself! It's light on the sauce and cheese with that chewy thin crust coupled with a side of  smoky chipotle chilis, herbs, and parmesan, amazing. (was cut into 6 large slices)

Total came out to about 23 for the three of us as an afternoon snack BUT a $1.5 service fee was charged automatically as part of a donation to a relief fund so it totaled to 27!! Not that I minded the fee but having it charged automatically puts a bitter spin on it but hey its for a good cause.

Cheers,
Alex
author: Alex L.

description:
Came here for the Margarita Pizza since it is on the list of 100 things to eat before you die. I thought this defiantly deserved to be on  the list. 

I sat at the bar and there were heirloom tomatoes in front of me and tub of fresh mozzarella cheese. I was very impressed. The pizza was great. My only complaint is the $1.25 that they charge for San Francisco's Health care program.
author: Alison M.

description:
Wait on a Wednesday night - 10 minutes @ 7:30pm. Small place so I assume that it could be a nightmare on the weekend. 

Broccoli Rabe pizza was great as was my Spicy Cauliflower. I could leave the glazed carrots behind. 

Music - way to LOUD. Like a bad disco show. I was waiting for the ball to drop from the ceiling. Was disturbing.
author: Doreen D.

description:
Pros:
Excellent Italian food in the neighborhood.  Great little crushed red pepper and herbs with the pre-meal, although don't get caught in the trap of gobbling up all the breadsticks.  Save room for the pizza!  (I like to add pepperoni and arugula)

Cons:
There really are not a whole lot of healthy options or much besides pizza, meatballs, and anything.  Tricolore salad is healthy though.

Fun:
As best I understand it, this restaurant started as a spillover from the regular Deflina being too crowded!
author: Mike G.

description: Love this place! Great food, great atmosphere. Its fun to eat in or take out, the only downside can be the wait. Everyone who works here is very accommodating and friendly. Best Pizza in SF!
author: Colleen R.

description:
food is good 1 star

service is good 1 star

prices ok 1 star

BUT you'll be screaming at each other because the music is too 
freaking  LOUD!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Martin C.

description: What a little gem of a shop! Well i guess its got 2 locations really isn't small. The proscuitto pie is amazing and it alone makes me what to give it a full 5 star. Have yet tried any other ones but the thin crust and brick oven flavor lead me to think that other pizza would be equally as good.
author: Ivy R.

description:
I'm just gonna say it... not as good as Delarosa. Had I come here first, I probably would have rated it higher because it was still a great meal, but... it just wasn't as good. Sorry! 

Fried risotto balls: delicious. Burrata: how can you go wrong? Margherita pizza: simple and yummy. Fresh lemonade: I can live without. 

Super cute, low maintenance, close to work... I'll be back.
author: Molly S.

description: Love! Panna all the way, love the creamy sauce. And grapefruit soda. Ended the niner loss here and ate my sorrows, best therapy ever. My friend ordered the four cheese-which was really tasty as well.
author: Stephanie G.

description:
I just moved home to SF after a year of living abroad in Asia, and went out for dinner with my family. My brother said that Delfina is his favorite pizza place so we decided to try Delfina in Pac Heights. The place is a bit small so although my name was at the top of the list, we had to wait a while for a table for 5 to open up. The server apologized saying that people have paid but are just chatting. Finally, 2 tables for 2 that were next to each other opened up so they pushed the tables together and sat us there. It was very tight and apparently the old Caucasian couple seated to the left of us kept making snide remarks about how close we were sitting to them. My mom moved in closer as much as she could (we didn't ask to be seated in a tight space) but the lady kept making comments like, "she's practically sitting on my lap" (we could've actually fit another person between them!), and about us being Chinese. So they paid and got up to leave, and the lady rudely told my mom to move over. Sigh, I thought San Francisco is a diverse and progressive city. 

I know this isn't Delfina's fault; their pizza was delicious and the staff was great. But the incident really put a damper on our celebration ... what a way to be welcomed home. I'd rather head over to another pizza place where my family and I wouldn't be subjected to discrimination.
author: Diana B.

description: Amazing food! Ate here two days in a row it was that good! Excellent staff! Each time I went I ordered the salsiccia pizza and added pepperoni to it..... Was amazing. I am a big fan of New York style pizza, and although this pizza is NOT New York style, it is a very good pizza. Will definitely done here again on a visit to San Fran!
author: Kristina G.

description:
Finally, after longing for this place for so long, I finally made it here!  

appetizers: 
*belfiore mozzarella - damn good.  think about high quality mozzarella with olive oil and pepper with arugula on top of toasted bread.  NOM

*broccoli fritti - nothing too special, but damn tasty.  this was pretty much tempura'd broccoli with parmesan.  not that i'm complaining or anything........

pizza:
*panna with fennel sausage - if i were to ever describe a pizza as creamy, it's this.  don't get me wrong...it's not a white pizza, but it's one of the most savory pizzas i've ever tasted.  

dessert:
*tahitian vanilla and amaretti gelato - vanilla wasn't much to speak of, but hte amaretti was definitely legit

overall, delfina had a pretty relaxed atmosphere and there was no wait for seats at the bar.  if you're in a group of more than 2 or 3 though i'd recommend coming as early as possible since you'll have to wait.
author: Jeff N.

description: The lines are super long.  And if you get more bread, they will charge you!  The ice cream is really good.  The pizza is good.  The mozarella ball is good
author: Byron L.

description:
What a lovely lunch with a bunch of co-workers! Unfortunately since we did come here during lunch hour on a weekday, our party of 7 had to be split. But they were kind enough to seat us within close proximity. 

At my table we ordered the Salsiccia (housemade fennel sausage, tomato, bell peppers, onions, mozzarella) and the Amatriciana
(caramelized onion, guanciale, chili, tomato, pecorino) which is their special for the time being. I really liked the Salsiccia especially the sausage. The Amatriciana was alright and wasn't spicy at all-- I had the impression it was going to be spicy. 

Love the interior as it's very modern looking though it is a bit small for large parties. The people working were super friendly.
author: Eugenia G.

description:
Yum. I could eat this pizza forever--so light and delicate. I love how imperfectly oval the pizzas are and how unevenly bubbly the crusts are. 

We ordered the specials of the day. Favorite was the PURGATORIO: two farm fresh eggs, spicy tomato sauce, and generously shaved rectangles of pecorino. How can this not be a winner? 

The other pizza we got was the funghi which was loaded with wild white mushroom. This one was definitely cheesier and sans tomato sauce but just as satisfying. 

Warm olive appetizers can get really salty. I liked its warm concept but probably a tad salty for my tastes. The meatballs were really juicy and tender, slightly pink on the inside (we'll know soon enough if i've acquired some parasitic form of food poisoning). Tasted like a Chinese "lion's head" but with sugo. Good but not worth over $2/pop. 

Just a warning, they tack on $1.25/pp to support the SF Health Care Security Ordinance. I was all for it. Others, however, may not be too pleased with such forced measures.
author: Annie W.

description:
Delfina's Prosciutto Pie is so savory! I love prosciutto and I love arugula. Toss it all over a pizza crust, cacioccavallo, mozzarella, panna and we have a utopia. 

It tastes magnificent when its hot and fresh and it's still pretty good when it's cold. 

A lovely friend of mine was offered a position at her dream job and to celebrate, she bought  a Prosciutto pie- Lucky for me, I got to enjoy a large portion of the celebration meal.
author: Jenny K.

description:
Love this place. 1st time at the Pac Heights one (no wait), 2nd time overall.
Started with a bottle of the gragano frizzante, of course!
Roomie had the special - carbonara pizza - so yummy and I had the proscuitto/arugula pizza, felt like a little light on the proscuitto portion.
Still had almost 3/4 leftover to take home.
Tossing and turning between dessert. We shared the sorbet, the size of a ping pong ball ($5) and zeppole (which i have to say was very disappointing to end our great meal) i was hoping for something similiar to a beignet with powdered sugar not a dis-assembled funnel cake with sauce on top.  Close to $100 incl. tip and tax for bottle of wine, 2 pizzas, and 2 desserts.
author: DayDay D.

description:
Insanely good restaurant!! 

The atmosphere is really cool and it feels fresh. Bread sticks on the table, grated parmesan, fresh oregano and peppers on a small plate to go with it. Nicely done. 

The food is really tasty. Thin pizza, soft crust, but crispy and well done border. But if you're like me and like cheese, save yourself the disappointment and do not order the Napoletana. It is a "cheeseless" pie, with anchovies, capers, olives and tomato sauce. I have to say it's good, but not really a pizza. 

But I was drooling over everyone else's food that the waitresses were proudly and cheerfully bringing over to their guests. I should have just got on their way and intercepted one of those cheesy pies. 

The Burratta also looked very good and the presentation was classy.

The wines by the glass are also nice, and they can make some wise recommendations. 

Will definitely come back, but this time will order a different pizza. Should've read some of my fellow yelpers review before ordering!
author: Michel A.

description:
Pizzeria Delfina always hits the spot!

Came to this location for the first time last night and was pleasantly surprised.  I think the servers here are actually nicer, more social and attentive than those at the 18th Street location!

The food is a no-brainer - EVERYTHING is good and tasty!  I often crave their thin crust pizzas and love the accompanying dish of red pepper flakes, grated parmesan, and dried oregano stems.  Tried the oxtails "special" and it was so tender and delicious.  Also, yay for serving Peroni's and Montepulciano's!

Note:
Perhaps they could precut the prosciutto pizza better because it gets mutilated when we do it!
author: Vicente G.

description:
I don't know...I'm not such a big fan of pizza with burnt crusts and burnt spots on its underside.

However, the rest of the pizza was good, and it was a pretty good value.

(they do add 1.25 per person for a "healthy san francisco" tax)
author: Alison L.

description:
Perfect for lunch, early evening or late night.  Simple choices and presentation, but executed to perfection.  Prefer it over the restaurant parent.
