At our meal, the service was friendly and attentive, again better than the more formal Delfina.  Crisp dried oregano, red pepper, and grated fresh Parmesan on a small plate at your table a nice touch.

If you're expecting overloaded pizzas, eat elsewhere.  The simplicity of the food and focus on the very best ingredients is their strength.
author: Pierre W.

description: I saw the reviews and figured this was a winner.  Not in the slightest.  After waiting an hour on a Wednesday night, just to be able sit next to my dining-mate at the bar, we were served two mediocre pizzas, at best.  There is no taking a bite; there is only gnawing your way through the tougher-than-cardboard crust.  The toppings are not baked in.  They're just tossed on top of the crust and cheese (because we sat at the bar, I could watch how they made the pizzas).  As such, fall right off the slice as you try to eat it.  The only pleasant things about this place were the reasonable prices and the fresh oregano and peppers that you can put on top of your pizza, and you'll want them.  For the life of me, I can't figure out why there were so many people waiting to eat here.  I'd say that there are roughly 500 pizza restaurants in San Francisco better.  You should skip this one.
author: Stan T.

description: Went on a recent trip to San Francisco, and decided to take a taxi to try Pizzeria Delfina.  Lets just say it was worth the ride.  The 4 cheese pizza, and pizza with Proscuitto were spectacular.  The burrata cheese with arugla was excellent on there bread.  The coziness of the restaurant, and the feel of chefs that really are inspired to cook great food and present was very apparent.
author: Leon N.

description: I want all pizzerias to serve their broccoli rabe pizza. It is so rare to find a sophisticated pizza with that kind of flavor jumping out. It's not for everyone but it is definitely for me. The boyfriend preferred the four cheese pizza. All delicious, great crust for the discerning pizza lover. The only thing I did not prefer was such high prices for a soda. I probably should have given in and drunk a beer at those prices.  So skip the soda, eat the pizza, and the saffron arancini.
author: Alexa H.

description: No it is not a five star restaurant. It is the best pizza in town by far. Fun service. Not cheap but worth the price. A bargain for what you get. No reservations but if you eat a 2 PM lunch there is a short or maybe no wait.
author: Peter S.

description: A little pricey, but the funghi pizza ($17) was terrific. Go!
author: Mickey M.

description:
So it's half block from where I live... always busy and I've been very curious... finally, I had a chance to eat there the other day ^^ 

On such a warm autumn day, it was so lovely to sit outside to eat. The pizza is a thin crust pizza and easy to eat. I am not so big of a pizza person, but the size and the taste are easy for me. Can't believe I haven't eaten there till few days ago. 

My most favorite was the desert. The ice cream, the combination of banana and caramel was fantastic !!
author: Sayaha A.

description:
Most definitely will be heading back here. The pizza was flavorful, not drowning in sauce, and the service was outstanding. Too bad I cant remember the servers name... But she was fantastic.

 Thursday night 6 pm, small line starting to form, right? No worries, she greeted them all before seating us, and then spent time making sure we had no questions about the menu or pizzas. She gave us an amazing recommendation for the Amatriciana (sp?) pizza special, which, if i ever run into i will be ordering again. Oh and we started with the pulled mozzarella appetizer with arugula and bread - delicious! The breadsticks are very good as well, and just sit there begging to be eaten as you sit down.

The cheese, peppers and fresh oregano are a nice touch on the table next to the vase of breadsticks. definitely makes for a nice atmosphere. It might be very dififcult if you're more than two people to find somewhere to sit BTW to heads up. 

Most definitely try it if you're in the area. If you're not in the area, it's very BART-able from the 16th street BART station. Parking can be pretty difficult after 6pm, but worth the trip.
author: Vittorio L.

description: pizza is amazing. I love the thin crust. Gotta try it! :)
author: Ally V.

description: They just have the best pizza here! It's not your average pizza joint and it's more a sophisticated savory pie for adults who love pizza.  Very crowded establishment which is a good thing. Leave your children at home or with a sitter, very little room for highchairs and kid parties. Parking is difficult so you'll have to make trips around the block a few times.
author: Patrick W.

description:
First time here and yes, I love pizza. And it was AMAZING! I absolutely loved the crust. I basically said, over and over with every bite, "THE CRUST IS SO GOOD!"

We had to wait about 15 minutes, but the guy managing the list was really friendly and efficient (I mean, not his fault the restaurant has limited space, right?).

Our server recommended that we get a pizza each, but I honestly think that's far too much food for two people. In fact, we ended up taking an entire pizza home because we were so full. 

I loved both pizzas we got:

Napoletana: Tomato, anchovies, capers, hot peppers, olives and oregano $11
"Purgatorio": spicy tomato sauce, 2 farm eggs, pecorino romano $15

Yum! Highly recommended!
author: Chung N.

description:
Good, fresh, tasty pizza. They use the same small set of ingredients in many different dishes--for example, you can get broccoli rabe on a pizza or as an appetizer. That can be either a good thing or a bad thing: small selection of food overall, but the few ingredients they have are good, fresh, and cooked very well.

Minor complaint: there's lots of stuff of the menu that you won't be able to decipher unless you speak Italian. I found this a little pretentious. But the servers were happy to translate.
author: J. K.

description: The Prosciutto Pie is HANDS DOWN the BEST pizza I have ever had!!!  If I could go here every day and eat that pizza I would.  Went this past weekend and tried the meatballs for the first time.  They were delicious!!  Moist, flavorful, with the right amount of saucy goodness.
author: Brooke K.

description:
A friend bought me gift certificate for Delfina before I moved out here. I checked it out the first week I got to town, and that was the beginning of a long and great relationship. Seriously, this place is awesome. I get take-out pizza a few times a month and almost always go with the Margarita pizza. It's the thin crust style and a whole pizza is a good size for one person. You've gotta make sure to ask for extra spices and cheese because they're perfect on the pie. If you're eating in, I recommend the meatballs and gelato. 

Delfina in Pac Heights is always crowded. You'll have to write your name down on the chalk board. Don't be turned off by the wait. You can order a glass of wine and people watch while waiting outside. You may have problems with parties of more than 4 as the tables are fairly small.

5 stars for the pizza, atmosphere, and service.
author: Jonathan G.

description: Pizza no better than your average take out place, and off-putting healthy SF tax. Forgettable.
author: Nick C.

description: Good pizza but not a five star because the bottom of my pizza was all black.
author: Logan N.

description:
Thank God Pizzeria Delfina is only a few blocks from my apartment. I have yet to dine-in because I can't deal with the lines because when I want pizza I need quick satisfaction. 

Their pizza is really good. I love the simplicity of a thin crust pizza with really fine ingredients. I think it is much better than A16 but doesn't quite measure up to Una or Tony's.  But unlike Una at least I can have other options, the meatballs and tricolor salad are worth a try.
author: Chanthi L.

description: Are people out of their minds? Four stars for Delfina? This pizzeria looks cool, that is true - but music is just too loud. Also, the main reason to go to a pizzeria is the pizza: and theirs is nothing special.
author: Bruno N.

description:
The best time to grab a table at Delfina appears to be a Monday night when the Giants are playing in game 5 of the World Series. Unlike the many other times I've passed this place, we were able to grab a table with no wait.

The food here is really good. The warm marinated olives are excellent. Delfina's is well known for its pizza (and my pizza was good) but their meatballs are just outstanding. They are some of the best I've ever had.

The atmosphere was nice; it was noisy but not too noisy that I couldn't have a conversation with my father. Services was good and the manager came around with glasses of sparkling wine after Brian Wilson threw the 3rd out in the 9th and the Giants were the 2010 World Series Champions. Very classy!

I've enjoyed Delfina's other location (on 18th street?) and was happy to see that the Pac Heights place help up the standard.
author: Bruce H.

description:
I avoided this place for a long time as it seemed such a hipster place to be which from past experience normally means substandard food and dreadful of service.
I was wrong. 
The food is fantastic (pork fat that tastes like bacon on toasted bread?! Hellsyeah!), the service is easy going and relaxed.
The waits are long, admittedly, but you can get a pint and wait outside while having a chat or just go around the Filmore neighborhood.
For shorter waits, go at around 3pm on the weekend. If it is sunny, you'll still have to wait as the outside spots are few and hot commodity, but you will definitely find a spot inside.
-1 star for the long wait thus delaying the time that yummy pizza got into my belly and the loud music that can be dialed down a touch.
author: Mirto H.

description:
I was on the hunt for the best authentic pizza in SF and I found a winner! Delfina wins hands down! Although you might have to wait an hour for a table, it is worth every minute.

Or...you can always order take out.
author: Lauren T.

description: Good standby around town.  Probably my favorite for pizza in the area, very satisfying.  Always PACKED though, regardless what time you come it seems.
author: Phil J.

description:
Small, crowded, & noisy, but some of the best pizza you can find on the West coast, methinks! Not knowing that if it doesn't say it has cheese, the pizza doesn't have cheese, gf & I split a Napoletana (tomato, anchovies, capers, hot peppers, olives and oregano). Excellent! Others in our party enjoyed a pepperoni/sausage pie & a seasonal "cherry" [tomato] pie. We had a couple of sides--fried squash blossoms (very good), & zucchini in a tomato-based sauce (good, but nothing to write home about).

Listed by Food & Wine as one of the *country's* top 25 pizza places: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/food-wine/food-and-wine-best-pizza-in-us_b_827096.html#s244444&title=San_Francisco_CA
author: J R.

description: I wish this place was here when I was in school.  I miss Pac Heights.  :(
author: Fatty A.

description:
everytime i eat here i declare its the best pizza i've ever had.  from the toppings to the perfect crust - In my opinion it is the gold standard.  My favorite is the Panna
( i like the simpler pizzas which actually most of theirs are).  Service and ambiance are great too.
author: hary n.

description:
Fresh, sophisticated flavors, yet casual. A solid four stars. I appreciate their ambiance and see what they're trying to do, but they have just a few kinks to work out.

Definitely a popular Fillmore restaurant. There always seems to be a wait, which is worth it for up to 45 minutes. They should, however, have a better waiting area than the small bench at the doorway. Too many people there makes it an uncomfortable wait.

Went to this place twice in the same week unintentionally. Loved their root beer and Tricolore salad. Not too in to the fennel veggie dish just because it was too salty and made an unsuccessful attempt to be zesty. Ordered it because they ran out of their special salad.

Normally not a fan of thin crust pizza, but I would come back for Delfina's pizza. For dinner #1 the pizza was a 4 Formaggi. Tasty. 
The choice for dinner #2 was the Salsiccia pizza. Warning: spicy sausage! I prefer to be warned on the menu, folks. Also, just an FYI, they do occasionally fall victim to the charred edge of the thin crust.

Would I go back there? Sure. I like their interior color scheme and the food is fresh. Single-stalled bathrooms are decent too. Service was good. And since I'm a germaphobe, my last tip is for them to present the bread sticks in a dish so they do not get contaminated by the bare table.
author: Kelly T.

description: We ordered the saffaron arancini for appetizer and I loved it, served warm, very tasty, a must try. We also shared the Panna and Salsiccia as main course. I really liked the Salsiccia, the Panna was not very special. Overall, it was a good experience, it gets really crowded late afternoons and in the evening, so schedule your visit.
author: Sasan A.

description: After a busy day of walking around Fisherman's Wharf and The Presidio, I was hungry! Pizzeria Delfina was definitely able to satisfy my hunger.  I read the reviews before going and many people said that there was a wait so before going I called to see if there was a wait and if so if I could make reservations.  Unfortunately, I was told it's first come, first serve.  We decided to go for it anyway and when the three of us arrived, we were told the wait was for about an hour.  We decided to wait it out and they have a chalk board where you write your name and the number of people in your party.  We ended up waiting for at most about 45 minutes because three seats opened up at the bar/counter.  If we didn't take those seats, the wait for a table was about another 10 minutes.  Service was good.  All the staff were attentive and nice. The food came pretty quick, which is what I would expect because this place is not too big and there were a lot of chefs in the kitchen.  I got the margarita pizza and it was very good.  The size was good.  I was pretty hungry and ate the whole thing myself. I highly recommend asking for olive oil so you can dip the slice of pizza in the olive oil because it adds more taste.  Speaking of taste, I could really taste the quality and freshness of the ingredients. The one negative I had with this place was the music.  They unnecessarily blast rock music through the speakers so we all kind of have to yell to each other.  Overall, I can see why this place has such good reviews and I highly recommend it.
author: Michael G.

description:
Despite the very hipster feel of this area most of the places here are pretty good and Delfina (Pizzeria) is definitely one of them.

It's usually pretty packed but doesn't seem like the wait is very long for 2-4 people. They bring out these large and thin breadsticks when you sit down which are good but a little quirky as I'll be chewing on a dry piece of crumbly bread and not sure if I like it or if I eat it cause it's there.

The menu is small and simple but everything sounds good. Prices are pretty good and their pies are delicious. The bread is bubbly and a bit toasty with just enough olive oil and tomato sauce to keep you wanting more. I would definitely try the basic pie before going into all the different ones just because the others aren't always as impressive.
author: Sam H.

description: After having amazing pasta at Delfina, I looked forward to trying the pizza at Pizzeria Delfina. Unfortunately I was sorely disappointed. The crust was underwhelming; the toppings were not unique. Una Pizza Napoletana blows them out of the water by far.
author: SiliconValleyShoeGirl L.

description:
The fennel sausage pizza was excellent. The crust was crispy and light, the ingredients were of high quality, and my favorite part was the tomato sauce.. 

We sat at the counter which is fun because you can watch them make the food and see all the interesting stuff that happens behind the counter.

Service was good and the food came out without too much wait. The restaurant was clean and felt spacious despite the fact that it's actually a small space. 

I found it to get a bit too noisy during lunchtime, but that's the price I'll pay for the pizza. I will definitely be returning!
author: Al B.

description:
The thinner crowd and ability to walk down the sidewalk at dinner time tipped my impression of PD - Fillmore into squarely positive territory. But this was only a take-out order, so the review is only about the food.

The verdict was that it's damn good pizza! Just as good as PD - Mission, but I really don't like being in the claustrophobic version: hence my one-less star for that one.

Prosciutto Pie (with prosciutto, three kinds of cheese, and a whimsical-sounding "dandelion greens") was my favorite. Great combo of green, cheese, and  meat, all of which I like on fancy-pants pizza. Ditto for Salsiccia, which had housemade fennel sausage, tomato, bell peppers, onions and mozzarella.

The damage was about $35, and it was worth it, yes. Would love to come back and dine in with some vino.
author: Tara R.

description:
I always leave happy when I go to pizzeria delfina-

the service is on par, the prices are reasonable, the food never fails to disappoint, and the ambiance is very welcoming.

I suggest going at not peak hours- 3pm-5pm to get a table right away.
author: Clarissa P.

description:
A few favorites:

Margherita
Salsiccia
Prosciutto Pie
Broccoli Raab

.... and make sure to get the burrata, if it's on the menu.
author: P K.

description: I love being wrong. My previous review was proven wrong tonight. The lines here aren't *that* bad. And you can drink on the street. I ordered take out and they deep fry anything off the Fritti menu to go when you arrive... and, they deep fried the world's best mozzarella stick for me. They call it Mozzarella de Corrozza. Not just the best mozzarella stick (who knew there was a list?), but it was the best fried food I've had in my life. Two come in the $7 order, and one is enough for one person... two is perfect.
author: Jon A.

description: Perfect "get out of town" date night spot! Found this place on Yelp and immediately fell in love with all the food pics. Went for dinner one evening and the food was magnificent, talk about mouth-gasm YUM! Only drawback was that we had to wait a long time for a table but hey it's SF, it's small and I get that. The while you wait wine helped ease the mouthwatering hunger pains.
author: Holly M.

description:
this is the closest to pizza in Italy that I've had. It is thin crust, chewy and delicious. I'd stay with the classics- the Margarita, sausage and cheese ones are so good. We tried the salted cod too and it was too fishy. 

The wait can be rough...take out might be the answer for busy nights. the leftovers still tasted great the next day.
author: Inna L.

description:
Love Love Delfina's! The servers are so incredibly nice and their pizza is to die for!! It tastes so fresh and the fact that they use seasonal ingredients makes it tastes just THAT much better! The Cherry Pie is amazing...(perfectly ripened cherry tomatoes used!) get it when you can 'cause they don't offer it all year long! 

The blood orange mimosa is the best mimosa I have had yet!! Can be a bit of a wait because they are So popular.. but it is totally worth it!!!

LOVE the food... LOVE the atmosphere!!
author: Connie K.

description:
We ordered 2 pizzas to go over the phone on Superbowl Sunday, and the guy who took our order was very nice. He said that the pizzas should be ready in 15 mins, but we didn't want to pick it up until 45 mins later, since we were running some errands. When we got there, the pizza was a bit cold, so it was probably sitting on the counter for a while. Boo

Anyways, we ended up getting the Prosciutto Pie and Salsiccia. The Prosciutto Pie was pretty good, a bit greasy. The sausage on the Salsiccia was tasty (my bf thinks it's the same type of meat they use in their meatballs). 

Not bad overall, so I would probably come back to try other things on their menu.
author: Cheryl C.

description:
There used to be a time when I used to look down at all you girls who would date more than one guy at the same time.  You know who you are.  It's particularly bad when you say you REALLY like one of the guys.  Cause then how can you date others?  I mean, one is enough, right?

Well, now, girls, I understand you.  It all becomes clear.  You see, there is this guy I really really like.  His name is Little Star, and every time I eat there I get a little foodgasm.  I think he's the greatest guy in SF.  I love him.  But I have another boy I want to date now too.  His name is Pizza Delfina, and he tastes almost as good.  Sure, he's a different sort of guy.  Instead of being deep and full of flavor, he's more like a hipster in his skinny jeans.  Very thin.  Very refined.  Lots of style, not so much substance.  But then, we all like skinny pretty things right?  

4 PBR-Style Stars
author: Leon K.

description: Pretty good Neapolitan style pizza! The crust is crispy and chewy. The sauce (which is very important) has good flavor. I like the Margherita pizza the best. It's simple but has a lot of flavor. Price is as expected $10 - $18 per pizza. the place is cozy, good ambiance and modern look to it. The best is to get there early to bypass the lines. Of course there always is take out. This is definitely a good won't let you down go to pizza joint that has a modern but casual environment.
author: Tim S.

description:
I would probably give Pizzeria Delfina 3.5. It's better than A-OK but not enough to be yay! i'm a fan. We got here at 6pm for a table for 2. There was already a wait. We ended up waiting for about 20 minutes which isn't too bad considering you could walk around the block and check out the boutiques to kill time. 

We ordered the Ciccioli to start which is pretty much a pig fat spread. It was soooo yummy but I felt like I was clogging my arteries with every bite. For our pizza we got the proscriutto pie. Also tastey!

The service was a bit slow. It took 2 hours for us to finish. For some this may be a problem, but I was enjoying the conversations I was having with my dinner buddy so I didnt mind the slower service. Also it's a bit noisy in the restaurant so you end up screaming to have a conversation.
author: Mei C.

description: Pizzas are great.  However, there are many more places with better service.  Last few times service has been horrendous.  Then the kicker - we replaced meat on a pizza with vegetables.  They charged us extra for the veggies!  Wha?   If you can't cater to vegetarians, then why be in SF?
author: Meghan C.

description:
Went back for my 2nd trip and the food was once again very good.

My friend and I split the Panna pizza. It was tasty and reasonable ($10). We were also able to sneak in around 9:20pm before they closed at 10 and the service was friendly and prompt.

Two thumbs up
author: Rachel R.

description:
Delfina - Mozza - Luzzo ??? Luzzo's so far has the best Margherita, and pizza overall, that  I've ever had the pleasure of consuming. Pizza goers tend to compare these three, but since we can't be in SF - LA - NY all at once, we'll just have to say that each is arguably the best of their city.   

On to Delfina:
YUMS
: Mozzarella in Carozza - cubes of fresh mozza and bread, skewered, battered, and fried to holy moly perfection. Out of this freakin world. TIP - don't let them take the dish away when you're done, save the oily, zesty sauce for dippin with your pizza! 

: Carbonara Pizza - eggs on pizza! Awesome - but wish there was more of it.  

UMS
: Margherita Pizza - classic tomato, basil, and mozzarella. It was very good, but not great. Wish that there was more basil on it, rather than trying to tear the few pieces provided on to each slice. If you get this, ask for add'l. 

I'm not a huge fan of their crust - as fun as it looks, it's just too starchy and lacks serious flavor.

But for the Carozza, I will definitely be back.
author: Jessica W.

description:
Its fine... in the way of crispy crust, bitter greens, fresh cream and salt. Its fresh and rich and theoretically, easy. Unfortunately this place is stressful, and the 15 minute estimate is always 45. With everyone rushing around and squeezing by and waiting, its way more hectic than dinner should be. 

If you go at lunch or an off night, you could luck into fresh, interesting comfort pizza and decent service. Judging by the rude service and incorrect change I got tonight, its rare.
author: ruth k.

description:
I have to say - my best friend is really great at suggesting / recommending new eateries for me to try.  We went here Dec 2010 before we took the Shortie to see the Nutcracker.  I can't remember what we ordered but what I do remember was that the food was pretty delicious.  

You definitely need to go early to get a table since the place gets pretty packed quickly.  We were there about 5:30ish and there was quite a line waiting for a table.  Love the fact that you put your name on a black chalkboard with OG chalk.  

I haven't been back since we went that one time but I will definitely eat there when I'm in the area.
author: Shirley a.

description: At Delfina for a friends bday!  So far soooo good.
author: Rose A.

description: Hands down one of my favorite restaurants in the city! You can not go wrong with anything you order here. I would highly recommend the burrata appetizer, the meatballs, and the margherita pizza with arugula added on top. It's my guilty pleasure that I indulge in all too often.
author: Janelle S.

description: I've had Pizzeria Delfina (MIssion location) bookmarked for a while and didn't realize there was another location in Pacific Heights. After a fun day at Baker Beach, we wanted to grab lunch. I had the Salsiccia (house made fennel sausage, red bell peppers and onions with no cheese) and it was good, but not the best I've had. It's thin crust, but not as thin as others (such as Pizza Antica in Santa Clara or Vesta in RWC). So if you like more dough in your pizza, this place is it! Expect quick and friendly service with great vibe here with lots of outdoor seating -- very dog friendly.
author: Cindy T.

description:
Love the welcoming staff, wonderful homemade breadsticks, our gourmet magherita and prosciutto pie pizza, but not a fan of the insalata tricolore, a lil too much vinaigrette for me! 

Highlight of the night, the host remembers my name even when I left! I tapped him and said "Thanks for everything, the food was amazing!" Our host said "Thanks, bye LISA!!" Wow, the feeling of a Pac Height local is awesome blossom, I feel so special!! =) I love our waitress too, she's always smiling, observant, accommodating, always notice when our water bottle or breadstick cup needed refill, such a darling!!

I was super lucky to find parking in front of the restaurant, VIP, baby! Yayurererer!! 

Advice on the parking:
Here's what you should do, write your name on the chalk board and then look for parking! We arrived at 6:50pm and didn't get seated until 7:15pm, if you're still looking, maybe you should consider parking at the Japantown parking lot, it's a nice little walk back!
author: Leeseuh K.

description:
Went here on busy Friday night and wait was a bit long so we ordered to go. Got 2 pies, the margherita and the salsiccia, and side of meatballs. Decided to just eat them in car cos we were starving and didn't want crust to get all soggy.  Actually didn't help cos they were aready limpy in the middle.  Surprisingly the pizzas lacked flavor.  The margherita was missing fresh basil and the mozzarella they used was real gummy. The salsiccia didn't have any fennel flavor at all.

If this is to be one of the better places to go in SF for Rustic Italian pizza then thats really sad.  I've had better, unfortunately out of state.  But u would think a big city like SF with Little Italy and all, would have something comparable. That's too bad...

On the bright side, while waiting for our pizzas, we went across the street  
to the Italian grocer/deli and bought soup and salad for starters. That turned out a lot better than Delfina's
author: Fei C.

description:
Good place in the fillmore area. My wife and I enjoyed a great lunch there. The food is solid and the prices are reasonable. We had the Pig's ear, the pizza napolitana and the lamb cheeks. The pizza was great but they are not as good as Tony's Pizza in North Beach. The lamb cheeks were great and it comes with potatoes that are cooked to perfection.

We had wine and beer on tap. Good selection and good price. The place is well done and they created a great atmosphere. This is a real San Francisco restaurant. 

Our server did a good job, but his knowledge about the food was not great when we asked question. 

We will go back
author: G R.

description:
Delicious pizzas!

Too bad there is always a wait - the food is awesome here!
Lots of Italian wines to choose from and there are 3 seats out front under a heater - usually open bc its so cold.

The menu is short but they have perfected what they got - try it out! 
Be patient.....
author: Jessica L.

description:
Probably the best pizza I've had in SF.

Go at 1:30 PM on a weekday and there's no wait.

We had:
- The tripe "tripperia" style: poached tripe seasoned lightly with lemon juice and fresh basil, served with chili oil and sea salt. Simple and delicious.
- "Fries with eyes": fresh fried smelt with aioli. Fish & chips, elevated.
- Napoletana pizza: No cheese on this pizza. This allows the bright, fresh tomato sauce to really shine.
author: Steven Y.

description: Bummed into a friend in the Fillmore and we decided to grab lunch.  Luckily, we were able to walk in to Pizzeria Delfina and get a table pretty quickly.  Had a salad and split a pizza and that was plenty, if not too much.  Service was friendly, informative and not intrusive.  Very inviting atmosphere.  And the food, well, it's always excellent.  BTW - they will sell you a pizza dough if you want to make your own pizza at home.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Took about 30 minutes to park. And waited for about an hour on a Monday. But when the beau and I took our first bite, we turned to each other, grinned like fools, and said, "The wait was worth it."

Delfina has been on my wish list for awhile, but I finally pushed myself to go after reading about the restaurant in a Sunset magazine where it (and 6 others) were featured under an article called, "The Best Bay Area Pizza." 

The women who work there are SO incredibly nice. And efficient. I watched as they served pie after pie, swooped in to greet and bid farewell guest after guest. When we were finally seated at the tiny bar, the waitress took one look at me and smiled. "You're so excited to be here," she said. She was right. 

We ordered both of the specials: the Purgatorio and the Gricia. The Purgatorio reminded me of the pizza I ate in Paris. It was made with a very mild, spicy tomato sauce, two farm-fresh eggs, and I added pepperoni. If you've never had eggs on pizza, you have GOT to try it. Egg yolk does something magical to pizza crust, I'm telling you. The Gricia was also incredible. It had spring onions, guanciale (read: pig jowl), panna, and black pepper. It was creamy, salty, delicious. All that paired with a bubbly red wine (Gragnano Frizzante) and ... what can I say. This is what I like to do.
author: Christine N.

description: My favorite pizza place in the city - nothing comes close to beating it. This is a great place for lunch and dinner. The only issue is that the wait to be seated can be long, but it is worth it.
author: Wolf L.

description:
I visited on a Sunday night around 8:30PM and it was really crowded.  Line-out-the-door crowded.  I've heard so much about Pizzeria Delfina, but never had the chance to try it until my most recent trip to San Francisco.  40 minute wait be damned, I was gonna try it!  

Wow~!!!  The Purgatorio pizza was fantastic!  Spicy, meaty, with EGG!  Who would have ever thought that pizza and egg would be such a fantastic combination?  The egg yolk was purposefully runny, mixing perfectly with the thin crust, spicy tomato sauce, and spicy Italian meats.  Probably the best pizza I've ever had!  I would have loved to try the other pizzas, but there was only 2 of us and we had only a limited amount of stomach space. 

My friend and I are fairly adventurous eaters so we also ordered the Grilled Fennel with shaved bottarga & lemon oil dish.  What is bottarga, you ask?  Why it's dried, cured, fish roe!  It adds a nice sea brine to the fennel.  Combined with the lemon oil, it was a fresh, tasty, and light dish.  Yum!

Lastly, we tried the grilled sardines, which was also very good, but not my favorite of the evening.  I wish it had more flavor.  

Really wish I had dessert there too!
author: Annie L.

description:
To the naked old Bay 2 Breakers dude @ Fillmore & Hayes: Thanks for luring the SF crowds with your boner - *to* Alamo Square and *away* from this restaurant I've always wanted to try and could never get a table at. I owe my Sunday happiness to you! Beautiful interior, friendly staff, great food, reasonable prices.

Recommendation: Amaraciata: A Campari-inspired, alcohol-free bitter mixed with lemonade. Refreshing, not sweet, novel, delish.
author: Janett R.

description:
Wonderful pie coming out of this joint.  Delfina puts out a neapolitan pizza in style with the addition of more inventive toppings than tradition.  My fav!  The crust is thin and perfectly 'burnt' on the edges and bottom.  The toppings are ideally portioned to not overwhelm, but definitely get taste with every bite.  

This night, we went with the broccoli raab and hen of the woods mushroom pies with a side of the braised kale, currants, pine nuts.  We had the side come out first (salad kinda) and it was marvelous.  They went a little overboard on the olive oil, but amazing none the less.  Both pies were delicious and a favorite couldn't be decided on.  

The service was really awesome as well.  While waiting, the girls at the front counter made recommendations on wine and let us taste a couple pours before making our final decision.  Our friendly waitress checked in regularly and kept the food coming.  

Super cool vibe, friendly staff, and amazing pizza make Delfina a must.
author: Tripp W.

description: Still a good place for good pizza. Salad and other plates seem to be getting smaller for the same price though.
author: Conny F.

description:
Its sad that i live far awyay from pac heights. The best pizzas ever! The dough is something special. 

Brunch is great too. The lines can be long, but its completely worth it!!
author: amit s.

description: This place is always so busy...but glad i waited it out. Actually on sunday night, the wait for a 2 top wasn't bad at all.  Shared a few apps and a pizza.  It was all delicious. Wasn't a huge fan of the wine selection, but i'll definitely go back
author: Dilly M.

description: Meh. It's just Ok. I mean, the pizza isn't bad tasting but we ordered a margarita pizza and I kid you not there was 4 tiny pieces of basil on the entire pie (6 slices) and one slice didn't even have any cheese on it. There is nothing "artisan" about a pizza whose ingredients aren't included on every slice. Kind of a joke. Had like 4 different people waiting on our table and they act like they could care less. Won't be back, it's not worth the money.
author: Melanie L.

description: I love this place, but I'm leaving off  a star because they were playing "We Built This City" on the stereo.
author: Brian C.

description:
Lets try this one more time.

A perfect season and a world championship on the line so why did the Pats go man coverage on that play. Why on earth would you have single coverage on Plaxico. Eli must have had a mini orgasm when he saw that. Plaxico's sluggo route was the perfect call. 

By the way, why call the slant and go a sluggo? Shouldn't it be a slango?

Where was the safety? Why not slide him over for a little help? Infact I would have made it clear that I am going into double coverage. Do this and two things could happen. 1. Eli would have probably have gone to his second or third read 2. Or he sticks with the sluggo and attempt to force the pass or would throw  the ball out of the back of the end zone.

Where was my safety help on my last trip to Delfina? I not only was able to finish every last crumb of my 4 Formaggi pizza but I then helped devour my dining companions Margherita.

What should have happened is we needed a third person that night. If we had done this two things would have happened. 1. We probably still would have only ordered two pizzas. 2. I would have eaten a lot less and not suffered that late night tummy ache.

I will never say this is the best pizza in San Francisco. But I will tell you that without question and hesitation that it is my favorite. I am a fan of all pizza and love them all like Anne Hathaway (gosh I hope she reads this). The crust is perfect and has a hint of saltiness. The wine list is 100 percent Italian which I know nothing of, but the waitstaff's knowledge is amazing and can help guide to you that perfect selection.

They do have a few desserts, but after stuffing your face I would recommend leaving and taking a walk up the block to the Elite Cafe and burn a few of those calories.

Bring a safety.
author: V B.

description: I made the mistake of going to the pizza place around the corner first (pizzeria delfina) Dino's was WAY better. Great flavor, and real pizza. Not foo foo pizza that's more like an appetizer. A great place for a real dinner!
author: Denise N.

description: This place just gets better and better! Love the food... the wait staff... the ambiance... down to the water bottles. I am just in love with this place in general! Funny... the guy that owns the joint down the street was trying to convince us to try is place out instead. Not even close, BUD! :)
author: Shannan J.

description:
The PIZZA is AMAZING. I am NOT a food snob except when it comes to pizza. Pizza from America hasn't been the same since I visited Italy when I was 10 and usually only eat it when I go back. However; I will for sure be getting TAKE OUT from this place in the future!!!

Nothing was special about this place as far as decor. The service is fast but its just so popular that you will be waiting for a table for a while. Our waitress was super friendly...almost like overly so, but its better than the opposite!

This would be a 5-star review if I had gotten take out but since I had to wait an hour and sit outside (unless I wanted to wait another 20) I give it a 4.
author: Ramey D.

description:
My girlfriend bought a few Delfina pizza pies from here and brought it back to her spot in NoBe. I am a huge fan! Can't wait to go next week and dine in person! 

Ahh Panna, you're worth my first visit!
author: Mika D.

description:
quite a solid dining experience. Came here late night post a movie and a drink, so we were defo ready to nosh on some pizza and make a limited number of decisions regarding wine pairings. run down:

special cherry tomato pizza - LEGIT, it wasnt smothered in cheese so you could really taste the fresh cherry tomatoes, quite pleasant and delicious. great olive oil and crust as well.
pig ear app - ok this was our bad, our server recommended everything on the menu but didnt mention this one, but for some reason we ordered anyways. it pretty much tasted like deep fried anything, which should be expected, but it didnt seem to fit with the overall delicious, fresh, dining experience of delfina. 

overall, a solid pit stop if you are in the fillmore area and want to split a pie, if there is a wait for tables, try and sneak onto bar seats, we got in right away through this method.
author: LeeAnne T.

description:
2 girls, a guy, and a pizza place.

We ordered a salsiccia pizza, a margherita pizza, an insalata tricolore, and the marinated olives and I believe everyone was pretty happy.  I finally understand why people love the pizzas here.  Take-out was perfect, 30 mins and it was ready, though it didn't look like the wait for a table was too long (7pm on a Wednesday).

The portions were about right and I really enjoyed the salad and olives as well.  Pizzeria Delfina is back to my neighborhood rotation (thank goodness because the list is pathetically small)!
author: Krystle S.

description:
I love Pizzeria Delfina. I've been here three times in as many weeks. Twice to grab a Margerita pizza to-go and once with my sister for a sit down dinner. 

I've been to Italy a couple of times and their pizza comes about as close as America gets to a true Italian pie. Crispy but not crunchy crust and the perfect sauce to topping ratio. It's the kind of pizza that makes you want to eat an entire pie by yourself. No shame: been there, done that.
 
If you're in a hurry or don't feel like waiting forever for a table, I would recommend getting your order to-go. It's much easier and the pizza is still sizzling by the time you get back to your apartment. But if you intend to sit, plan your arrival for a lull in the dinner cycle: late enough to bypass the early birds but early enough to avoid the dinner crush. I think my sister and I got there around 7 PM. 

Our server was really sweet and gave us good suggestions about what to try. We had the insalata tricolore, spicy cauliflower, and prosciutto pie. The salad was great with just the right amount of shaved parmesan on top to offset the bitterness of the radiccio. The spicy caulifower was good, but only if you ate it quickly and had the pieces that had been fried the most. It was just on the cusp of being too crispy to have been cooked all the way. The prosciutto pizza was excellent, but a word of caution: it is difficult to eat and you will look like a fool trying to do so. But don't let that dissuade you from ordering it.
author: Meredith D.

description:
First, I'll admit that I've been spoiled.  The best pizza of my life last year still prances around in my dreams...a place called Keste in NYC--they specialize in neapolitan style pizzas.  But this isn't about them.  It's just a preface.  As a result of that one fateful pie it's been a difficult journey back to the west coast where pizza is, at best, average.

Thank God someone brought us to Pizzeria Delfina.  The food was quite delicious, and it's certainly among some of the best pizza I've eaten in California. The tri-color salad was exceptional from its crispness, composition, and just the right amount of dressing.  The pizzas, well, let me just say.  I wasn't that hungry when we stopped in here, and neither was the rest of my party, but somehow we wound up ordering our own individual pizzas.  That was definitely the right move!  The pizzas all had really excellent flavors, although there was a lot of mess involved in their consumption.

I hate waiting to eat at restaurants, and seldom have to back in Santa Cruz.  Had there been much of a wait, I might have reconsidered.  We were lucky to get seated almost immediately...and I'm spoiled.  Service was fine, if unremarkable. 

Prices?  They were ok too.  Not a steal, but not outrageous, either.

My only complaint, and hence the reduction of a star was how incredibly burnt the crusts were on our pizzas.  Now, if you're the kind of person who never eats pizza crust anyway (I don't really get that, but ok), then this doesn't really apply to you and we can all pretend I gave this joint 5 stars.  For the rest of you who like to eat their entire pizzas, I understand the need to fire these babies to perfection, but last time I checked charcoal wasn't on the ingredient list of any of these pizzas.  Right?

Okay, so anyway, bottom line: eat here.  It's so good.
author: Daddy O.

description:
3.5 stars. 

We arrived at 8pm on Friday prepared to wait for a table (group of 5). We waited... and waited... and waited... 80 min later, we were finally seated. I realize this is a popular joint, but 80 min? That's a bit ridiculous. At least we had time to discuss what we wanted to order...?

We settled on the fresh stretched mozzarella appetizer, and 3 pizzas: the margherita, prosciutto pie, and one of the daily specials. I think it was called gianci? Something with spring onions and fatty pork. 

AMBIANCE: loud hip hop music was played throughout the restaurant. It could've been turned down a notch as our group had a little difficulty hearing each other during some of the songs. The space is smallish, but has a cozy feel. The tables are a comfortable distance away from each other so that each group is distinct.

SERVICE: Our waitress was friendly, but didn't check in on us very often. Despite receiving 2 bottles of water, they often went dry for long periods of time.

FOOD: While the pizzas were good, they're weren't SPECTACULAR as so many people have said.
- mozzarella: very fresh, paired perfectly with the crostini, olive oil and greens. Just wish there was more crostini!
-Margherita: Yes, like everyone else has noted, the sauce was REALLY good. It was so fresh and bright, and the simplicity of the pizza really let the flavors shine. This was by far my favorite pizza of the night.
- Prosciutto Pie: Good, but so difficult to eat. I felt like this was slightly bland because of the panna base (instead of tomato). The prosciutto was layered on top of the dough in large strips... it was extremely difficult to separate onto slices, and also to take individual bites of. 
- Daily special: Not special. I thought the flavors were super super bland. Nothing popped. This pizza had green onion on it, but I couldn't really taste the fresh, spring onion-y-ness. I wish we had ordered the Salsiccia instead.

OVERALL: Pizzeria Delfina was good, but nothing I would go out of my way for. I can see how it could become a staple if I lived in the neighborhood and could just stroll on over whenever. If I do find myself here again, you can be sure it will only be with one other person instead of 4. Oh and fairly inexpensive-- $15/person (group of 5 including tax+tip) for nicely full bellies.
author: Susanna W.

description: We went here on a random Saturday night and it was bustling. The prosciutto pie was amazing and so were the meatballs. The servers were great and made sure we were well attended to as well. The line can sometimes be long, but its totally worth it!
author: Brian N.

description:
Trying to eat more in the neighborhood brought me over to the second location of Pizzeria Deflina. 

The kitchen was having a really good night, and our Purgatorio pizza with sausage was probably one of the best pizzas I've had in a while. Brian was the pizza maker and the crust was perfect, charred, thin, crispy, and perfectly seasoned. The egg yolk on top was right in my comfort zone, loved it.

The appetizers we had were also standouts including the spicy cauliflower (nicely browned), fries with eyes, and pig's ears (awesome with the lime and chili oil). Service was excellent.

I'm starting to like my 'hood.
author: Derrick V.

description:
I really don't understand how anyone could give this place less than 5 stars. I mean, the pizza is out of this world. Sure, there is always a wait and it is a little pricey, but it is worth it. When I went, I ordered the burrata appetizer (delicious but not a big enough portion for the price), the purgatorio (a daily special with 2 eggs cracked on top and spicy red sauce), and the crema (a cheese pizza with cream poured on top). My mouth is watering just thinking of the meal. 

This place is a little pricey, but I'm sure there are ways to get around this. For example, the crema pizza was around $10 and pretty large. I think that and an appetizer would easily feed two people.
author: rebecca p.

description: I had to wait about an hour on a Friday night which was understandable but I don't really think it's worth the wait. Everyone here is super friendly, but the food was okay. I'm a sucker for margherita pizza, and I needed to find a place in the city quick. It's my absolute favorite! So when I found this place on yelp and saw the great reviews, I had to come check it out. Me and my boyfriend ordered the margherita and another pizza which I forget. But both the pizzas had an extremely crunchy crust, and it was almost burnt. Now I understand thin crusts are suppose to be crisp, but this was a little too crisp! The cheese wasn't all that mouth watering either, and they put literally two pieces of basil on the whole pizza! Now they can't be that cheap. But I gotta say there tomato sauce was really good and also sweet. I'll just stick to pizza antica in sj until I find a legit spot in sf.
author: Marilyn W.

description: Pizza is good but expensive.  The wait is crazy and the self-sign in to the wait list works worse than I thought (people trying to "accidentally" get ahead of others; children playing with and erasing names)...I think there is better pizza in the area.
author: Anon M.

description: I recently went here Sunday night with out of town visitors,we had a table of six. Earlier that morning we had put our name on the board with the front staff's suggestion as it was going to be busy later on that evening. Good idea! Arrived 7:15 p.m. we had to wait approximately 20 - 30 minutes. It was our first time here and I thought the salads were great however small and expensive and the pizzas, well I have had better. Ingredients are fresh. Three pizzas fed the six of us along with the burrata appetizer. They had run out of a number of antipati and piatti which the wait staff had infomed us prior to ordering. Their home made gelato:  meyer lemon and hazelnut were delicious. One thing I did note however,  is that the wait staff are very savvy in observing empty glasses of wine and asking the customers if they would like another glass.
author: K H.

description:
Incredible pizza. Come here, wait a little bit, get a table, and order the simplest pizza: the Margherita.

Thin, bubbly crust, perfect tomato sauce, with mozzarella and fresh basil. Pretty much perfect.

They serve other stuff -- wine, appetizers, more complicated pizza, but get the simplest, best, most delicious pizza they have and you won't regret it.
author: Leo B.

description: Had the Salsiccia and the Proscuitto Pie. The pizza was just average. The meatball appetizer was amazing though.
author: Mary M.

description:
Love this place. We were seeing a show at the Fillmore so just happened in here looking for something fairly close to the theater to eat. The line was really long, especially for a Sunday night! You put your name on a chalkboard, and we got lucky, because a lot of the names ahead of ours hadn't bothered to stick around. So we got into eat fairly quickly (about 10minutes). It is a pretty small restaurant, and I felt a little cramped in the seating area. It also was pretty loud. The music was a bit too loud, and that caused the general din in the dining room to be kinda loud, but we were there to eat anyway! 

We started with ciccoci (I'm butchering that spelling). It basically is cured pork jowel, that you spread on bruscetta. So porky, and delicious. A good app to split due to the richness of the dish. 

They have several different pizzas to choose from and we ordered a pizza with guanciale, Romano cheese and 2 eggs on top. It was a bit spicy, but the warm runny egg yolk was absolutely delicious! The crust was thin, crispy, slightly charred around the edges, just the way I like it! They also had Peroni, my favorite Italian beer, on tap, which is really hard to find! Their menu changes slightly from day to day, and they have several "daily special" pizzas on the menu. 

Their dessert menu isn't too special, but we did have a couple of scoops of gelati, which hits the spot after a spicy pizza pie. 

Since we were going to a show afterwards we didn't want to order 2 pizzas, so we just split one. We split an app, a pizza and a couple of scoops of gelati, and that was the perfect amount of food for me and my husband (he has a pretty healthy appetite!). If we had ordered a 2nd pizza, we would have had to box up leftovers for sure. Overall glad we stopped in here.
author: Lori F.

description:
I made an impromptu trip to Pizzeria Defina tonight (though it's fair to say this is a place I've been curious about for a while...)

We went in at about 6:30 & we were discouraged by the gaggle of people seated at the front entrance -- not a good sign! But, surprisingly, we got seated straight away (in a four-person booth setup for two people - I was very pleased & somewhat amazed that we could snag the spot!) 

The place has a ver-y hip air - uber-cool staff, and a loud background "soundtrack" in a noisy space. But the restaurant is attractive in a modern, spare way, and the bustling kitchen was open and visible to us from our seats. 

We ordered the Broccoli Rabe and the Prosciutto Pie - two excellent choices, as it turned out, from our friendly but brisk waitress. (There was the sense that she was trying to move us on with our ordering as quickly as possible, but she was very friendly and professional about it...) The broccoli was wonderfully fresh, garlicky & a bit spicy, and the pizza was delightful -- lots of prosciutto and *lots* of very good arugula sprinkled on top. (With so many top-quality veggies, the meal actually felt healthy, despite the doughy pizza and the 2 glasses of chianti!)

Obviously, I was getting into the vibe of the place -- I ordered a dessert! (The affogato -- a scoop of vanilla ice cream & a shot of espresso to "drown" it in.) Good - but, to my dismay, the server performed the espresso "drowning" -- I kinda wanted to pour in the shot myself, that's most of the fun... 

Nevertheless, an enjoyable evening & an excellent pizza. (Not cheap, by pizza place standards, of course - but then again, it is not a typical pizza place!)
author: donal c.

description: Great wood fired pizza. Great meatballs. Always a long wait so I mainly order to go.
author: Brian M.

description: I love how there open all day and don't close @ 2:30 like many places till dinner starts @ 5, great service and perfect sardine starter and great pie, PIZZA MONSTER APPROVED.
author: Chris D.

description: Had the prosciutto pie. Simple, fresh and delicious. If u like arugula there's enough on top for a salad.
author: David L.

description: Mouth watering burrata, extreme flavor some lasagna and perfect pizza. Would have given five stars if they axed the loud heavy metal, head banging music which is kinda odd for an Italian restaurant.
author: Maria S.

description: So it's Sunday, we sat at the bar. I had 1 beer  and I was having a good time. We made quick friends with the other ladies at the bar. So yes my voice was loud in order  to speak to my friends sitting 4 seats sway, and the other ladies sitting at the other end. The the waitress told us to be quiet and it totally put a damper to my mood and my experience. I was not maliciously trying to be loud, I was being friendly with the other patrons. I'm at a bar seat having a good  time until I was told to be quiet. From then on I felt uneasy unwanted and hated all the food. This is not a place to go if you want to be friendly with your neighbors. This is a place to eat, stay still and not be friendly because the hipsters feel like you're intruding on their environment because you're having a good time while their working. The meatballs are verrrry good. The pizza with anchovies can use more anchovies and less capers. The service sucks because they obviously want you to shut up and eat and get out. The manager told me we were annoying other customers, but I doubt that. The music was so loud of course I had to be louder than the music to speak to my friends. I love Delfina but zero likes for the the pizzeria next door due to the front of staff that also tripped over  my chair. Further making me feel in the way. I'm 120 pounds and very petite. I was up really close to the bar. Granted at the end of the meal the manager wanted to talk to us but why? It's the end of our meal we just paid. I hate this place. So I'm never going back. I love NOPA.   NOPA is  busy. People are crammed and always waiting, but I've never felt like I wasn't wanted or judged. Pizzeria Delfina is not a friendly place.
author: Suzy M.

description:
I'm a fan of PD - not a must-go place and it falls short of the second coming hype that's surrounded it since its opening, but it's a cool spot with very good pizzas and apps.  The service is FANTASTIC, including the most gracious and helpful host who was so devoid of any attitude that I thought i was in the suburbs.  The server instantly comped us a new pitcher of beer after realizing she had brought us the wrong brew.  I mean, seriously perfect service.  It goes so far.

The food is really good.  We had three pizzas, the sausage, mushroom and prosciutto, and all were tasty.  We also had the brussel sprouts and the meatballs as apps which were also tasty.  None of it was extraordinary or especially unique or amazing or especially cheap, but the wait for a table of 5 on a Saturday was only about 40 minutes and we felt so welcome that I have nothing but fuzzy feelings about this place and I'm eager to return.
author: Matt S.

description: Wow! We were blown away by their pizza!  Even my 1 yr old daughter-took a bite and said yum!  We had the salsiccia and margherita.  The sausages were very good with a hint of spice.  The margherita was amazing.  Waaay better than the one from Lombardi's!  You can taste the light drizzle of really good olive oil on top of every slice.  Almost reminded me of Italy!
author: Christy A.

description:
I would give this 3.5 stars.  We were fortunate to get there before it got crowded (it was a late lunch/early dinner).  When we left, it was PACKED!

I can't exactly remember what we had as a starter.  I believe it was a crostini with artichoke hearts that was good.

My fiance and I split a prosciutto pizza, which was pretty good.

The service was very friendly.  We found an interesting soda there which is apparently hard to find -- I can't remember the name, but it was some cherry coke-like drink from the South, which we found charming.  Would definitely come here again; the daily specials look the most intriguing.
author: Jacqueline C.

description: Best flat bread pizza I've had since my culinary adventure to Italy in 2004. Went of yelpers reviews for the margherita pizza and loved it! The place has great ambiance and friendly servers-5 stars!
author: Georgia R.

description: so overrated. not bad, but it's nothing exceptional either. I think the hip factor clouds judgment. I would go next door to Dinos for pizza which is damn good...
author: oliver g.

description:
This place was outstanding!! 
Just happened to be in the area (Pac Heights), parked, walked around a bit, found Delphina... and fell in love!
Everything about the experience was fantastic. Service was polite and attentive. Pizza was soooo amazing, Draft beer was fresh and cold. I will definitely go back, now it is a destination.
author: Jaeger M.

description: Best pizza in my life. We went very early and were seated immediately. We got the poached tuna (so good) and the pizza with arugula and prosciutto. Such amazing crust and flavors!
author: Heather K.

description:
A-OK is the descriptor for 3 stars.  I'm giving it 3 stars but in this instance, that's not "A-OK".  Not even close.  Cannot go 2 stars because it's not "bad", but it is also not $30 for 2 pizzas.

EDIT NOTE: I changed my mind, I'm going 2 stars.  Still good pizza, but they are selling "the experience and novelty of good pizza in SF" which should not be charged for IMO.

I'm not going to turn this into "East Coast/West Coast" ala Biggie/Tupac.  But come on San Francisco.  Yes, we have great eats here (although recently I am definitely on a dead streak with the exception of Dosa) and yes our city is expensive for a lot (and some wrong) of the right reasons.  But pizza SHOULD ABSOLUTELY NOT be one of them.  There is not good pizza in this town.  There is only OK pizza across the board.

So Delfina steps in and does something good: They created decent "fancy" pizza in San Francisco.  But let's put things in perspective: You can eat on the water, at a nice restaurant (READ: nicer spot than what Delfina is trying to be), in Venice, Italy for cheaper than what you pay for an individual pizza at Delfina.  In Venice.  Italy.  I get that may come off as something other than "cool", but damn if it isn't 100% true.

If you want great pizza, go to Grimaldi's in Brooklyn Heights next time you are in NYC.  I guess to summarize this, I'm not going to get too many helpful recommendations with this review.  And I probably shouldn't unless you are comfortable with understanding my message and what I am trying to say here: That this is decent pizza that is expensive and IMO is more expensive than it should be.
author: Matt B.

description:
My sister took us here when we visited her in SF back in November.  The thin crust pizza was delicious and when she said it was the best pizza in SF, I definitely agree with her.  

The burrata appetizer is fresh and delicious.  Apparently, they make their own burrata cheese.  YUM!  

We also ordered the meatballs which were AMAZING.  The best meatballs that I've had in the US.  You can taste the ricotta cheese inside and they just melt in your mouth.  My mouth is salivating just thinking about them.  

I would definitely go back there again.  It gets crowded for lunch and parking is hard to find but it's definitely worth a trip to try it.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
I am a big fan of Italian style,  thin crust, wood fire pizzas. You can eat a whole one without feeling bogged down, a low-carb alternative to the traditional pizzas. Delfina is famous for these super thin crust pizza, so thin the pizza collapses if held by the crust. They have a great char to their crust and I have to say it is hard to find someone else that does it better. Toppings are very gourmet like prosciutto and basil that work very well with the rustic crust. 

Here's the dilemna:

You have to eat in and straight out of the oven or the pizza loses its structural composition once it cools. If you get take out, it also gets cold quick which makes it soggy and comparable tasting to the box it is in. This means you have to eat in and with the limited seating and massive crowd waiting for a table, you better be patient or you might want to head to Dino's next door. Factor in prices where you can get a couple large pizzas elsewhere for a personal size Delfina pizza (low carb also means less content) and it makes you think how much has to go your way to truly enjoy this place.
author: Ed L.

description: It's good but it's not great.  Definitely not worth the wait.  If you are going to wait that long, might as well go to Beretta.
author: M. B.

description:
not impressed- we got pizza to go which i recognize totally alters the texture and flavor of pizza, but i really was not impressed with what we got.  we got two pizzas (prosciutto and mushroom) and an order of burrata.  the burrata was fantastic, though did not come with nearly enough bread.  the pizzas were ok- i think the takeout counter here just cannot handle the volume they get.  the pizzas were already cold by the time we got them (even though we stood by the counter and waited the whole time for our pizzas to be ready).  i think the girl at the counter just lost track on one of our pizzas which is really unfortunate. 

i would give delfina another chance (for an eating in the restaurant experience) if others wanted to go there, but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here again.
author: Lisa C.

description: Close to the Italian Embassy where we had some business, we stumbled upon this place.  The food was good and pizza was delish.  The ingredients were fresh and the food not overly greasy and for that I will pay a bit more.  Except here you pay a lot more which is why I would giving it 3 stars instead of 4.  I guess people also pay for the Hip vibe in the place which...well was only fun for me for the first 5 minutes.  We did get good service for which they get an additional star.
author: Shalu S.

description: Solid pizza. I really enjoyed it! Totally worth it if your craving pizza and best I've had in pax heights area. Went on a Sunday at 5:30 pm and there was a wait.
author: Valerie F.

description: Our Pizza came out underdone and when I asked them to put it back in the oven they looked at my like I was nuts. Then we asked for some bread and they charged us 1.50 for 3 little pieces of bread kina ridiculous if you ask me. Overall I woudn't go back to this restaurant any place that nickel and dimes you on isn't going to make great food.
author: Jeremy R.

description:
I have been craving this pizza ever since I tried it several weeks ago. The main thing I like about Pizzeria Delfina is that I really don't feel guilty eating there. Everything is very fresh and prepared in a healthy manner.

 I had an amazing citrus and fennel salad. The dressing was so simple...just olive oil which mixed with the natural juices from the citrus fruits in the salad...it was incredible!

We also had the broccoli rabe pizza...fabulous. The crust was perfect...not soggy at all inspite of the veggies. We also got a bowl of sauce to sop the crust. It was sooo good...and a HUGE bowl. Enough for leftovers for pasta at home. I had it with a sparking Lambrusco, which is now one of my favorite reasonably priced fun wines to drink casually. You can buy it at Traders Joes for $5 per bottle or another version at Whole Foods for $14 per bottle.

I'm probably giving them 5 stars because I live in the burbs now and there just isn't anything remotely as good as Pizzeria Delfina anywhere near where I live.
author: susan c.

description:
Here's the truth: don't believe the hype or the four/five-star ratings this place gets. The salad and pizza we ordered were not NEARLY enough to justify the endurance of an hour-long wait in the cold. 

Food was salty, music was turned way, way too loud, and the food itself was pretty unoriginal and incredibly overpriced. I have had my share of pizzas in this lifetime, and this was one of the more disappointing ones.

There are so many better restaurants in the City. This is just a place yuppies go to drink on Friday evenings. Unless you like long waits and food that doesn't live up to expectations, don't eat here.

I hope this review shows up...  YELP NEEDS TO STOP TAKING PAYMENTS FROM BUSINESSES TO HIDE NEGATIVE REVIEWS.
author: Ryan T.

description:
Call me old fashioned but I like my pizzas ridiculously simple - so for me the plain old Margherita is the best, and at $13, extremely good price for the quality.  I have eaten here about 8 times already, and when I am around upper Fillmore I do like to have lunch here.

Service is always upbeat and really friendly and I see some of the same faces here when I go for lunch which is always a good sign - next time I really must try the delicious looking meatballs in sugo.  They look and smell amazing!  

I like the atmosphere here, unpretentious and 'fun' and I would say Pizzeria Delfina is a great place for a lazy lunch with friends, you can't beat good basic Italian food and great company!

All the gelato range taste amazing - and my recommendation for antipasti would be the fresh-stretched mozzarella - yum!  If you are not in the mood for a glass of wine, try the fresh limeade which tastes really refreshing
author: Gray D.

description: I guess we lucked out getting a table for two at 12pm on a Saturday.  Cannot say enough about this pizza.  Goes down like water.  I am a very happy customer!
author: Cassie P.

description:
We thought we were being smart in going at 5:30pm on Sunday night for dinner. But even at that early dinner hour the place had a 45 minute wait. 

But to help ease your pain of waiting in the cold there is the option of buying a pitcher of beer or some wine to drink while you wait for a table. So that is a definite brilliant idea. 

When we finally got our table, everything just got better. Service was excellent and being outside with the heat lamps was just perfect. And of course the food was fantastic. We had the meatballs (5 perfectly cooked meatballs simmering in a tomato sauce that is perfectly seasoned!), and the fried pig ears to start off with. We ordered the pig ears assuming that since they were fried they would have to be good. I had envisioned ears coming out on a platter, fried up. But no, they sliced it up so thinly and then fried it so delicately, that you couldn't even tell what you were eating. If you hadn't heard us ordered them you would just think we had gotten some sort of fried heaven, maybe shoestring onion rings or something. And they tasted so yummy. 

This is not to overshadow of course the pizzas itself. Any pizza you order here, you're going to love. The thinnest crust possible, freshest ingredients and each one tastes so great you cannot possibly choose a favorite. :) 

The menu changes I think seasonally and even though there are tons of restaurants in San Francisco to choose from, make this one your regular spot!!! 

Also the guy that was helping seat us was incredible, he kept on checking in and letting us know status, and squeezed us in the moment he had a chance to. He was part of what put us in such a great mood despite the long wait!
author: Denise B.

description: love the vibe! love the food! got te fresh mozzarella which was ok, got the meatballs which are greattt & the salsiccia pizza with pepperonis which is sooo full of flavor!! very yummy stuff, deff a place to try!
author: suz s.

description:
Tried this place for lunch because of the great reviews. I was happy with the pizza produced (had the salsiccia and prosciutto) so that is the reason for the 2 stars.

Otherwise, the service was not good. Small seating area not good for groups. Had to wait awhile because we wanted a table and the table took way too long to simply get set. Our waitress seemed offended by some of the basic questions asked by our table and even went as far as saying "this isn't that kind of place" as a response. I don't care what kind of question is asked, a simple "I apologize we don't have that here" will suffice. We then asked about the coperto (extra service fee); I lived in Italy for awhile so I obviously know what a coperto is but had not seen it in SF restaurants and was interested. Again, seemed offended and gave an inflated response.

I suggest getting take out of the pizza and sitting at the public tables across the sidewalk in the sun without the hassle of the service.
author: Adam Z.

description:
Wine on tap! -beware! Delicious pizza and a picture of a friend on the bulletin board, I love this place. The vibe is laid back and family friendly. Go early to avoid the wait and just get a bottle of wine. We accidentally spent over 50 bucks on 6 glasses of wine from tap. 
Tip: When you walk in, if there is a wait, you just add your name to the bottom of the chalkboard list.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Boring  pizza. Loud atmosphere. Brusque service. And prices are way way too high for what you get. Though strangely, the salads are excellent.
author: Jeneen J.

description:
The pizza was great.  Not a five star pizza, maybe 4...yet very very good, simple with an amazing sauce.  It was the service and the other dishes made this place worth 5 stars.  

We had a delicious homemade pulled mozzarella which came with arugula.  Add a lot of spice with just a pinch of the chili flakes on the table.  Topped the night off with the cherry sundae that blew us away.

I believe our server was Kelli?  She was outstanding...friendly, helpful, knowledgeable.
author: Rob R.

description: had sausage pizza and meatballs pizza was good meatballs needed a little help
author: Laurence K.

description: Only tried their pizza, and it is one of the better pies I have had in my life. Perfect crust. Toppings were high quality and delicious. Will definitely be going back. Nice when something lives up to the hype.
author: David H.

description: I'm not sure this was my cup of tea.. The crust was great! But I'm more of a simple pepperoni pizza kind of girl. We ordered the only pizza that had meat (don't get me wrong- the sausage was very good), a glass of wine, beer, and the fresh stretched mozzarella.. Our bill was about $50 and I was just a little disappointed.. I think I had gotten my hopes up from reading the reviews and had a different idea in my head about the food than what it actually was! Maybe I didn't order the right thing? It's worth another try I suppose..
author: Maegan B.

description:
After many months of hearing my boyfriend rave about Delfina and Pizzeria Defina, we finally got there! Woohoo!

Parking: we lucked out, but we could have just as easily circle the block for an hour. It's all street parking, and sparse.

Ambiance: cool! Hipster, Italian, airy.

Menu: some broadly-appealing things, like the fabulous warm fresh mozzerella appetizer. But I also saw some oddball things, like pig's ears, on the menu. Hmm...Not for me. The pizza all sounded great. We had the Salsicca. It has sausage. I don't even like sausage very much and this was tasty. Not spicy.

Seating: WAY too crowded. I could hear the conversation next to me to clearly, I had to actually concentrate to keep our conversation separate. There were literally 8" between the back of my chair and the guy behind me, and 8" from our table to the next table. It took twisting and scooting to get in and out of the table. We're pretty thin, by the way.

Service: meh

Wine: We had the second-cheapest red on the list, (the Sevudo? Sevuto?) and we both thought it was quite good.

Summary: go, but don't be surprised if you can't get parked, and be prepared to have someone pop out of the car to order some take-out. =)
author: Karen Z.

description:
Pretty good!

We somehow quickly scored a table for the six of us on Friday night. It might have helped that we were a group of six girls... the wait here is usually tough. I've tried to eat here on several occasions and could never stomach the wait.

We shared the meatballs, salad and brussel sprouts for appetizers, and shared three pizzas (arugula/prosciutto, Marguerita, sausage/pepper).  We passed on the desserts and I had a very gingery ginger ale (try it!).

Overall, the meal was great, pizza was good. Crust was thin and had a great bite to it. Mmm... and food was fresh and tasty. The restaurant is casual; service was okay and a little hurried. They really want their patrons in and out of there. 

Like all gourmet wood fired pizzerias, it's not priced like Costco. A meal for two will be $50+... for pizza. 

But... I'll be back!
author: Cindy Y.

description: Delicious meatballs.  I love all their pizza, except the clam one.  Their salad is fresh but really small.  Good wine.
author: S C.

description:
This was one of our must go to stops on our trip to SF, and it met all of our expectations and more.

Had me salivating while I waited for 1/2 hr and watching pizza's go by with huge, beautiful blisters, perfect char on the crust,and picking up the aroma of all the wonderful ingredients wafting through the air.

Went ape and ordered 4 pizza's each and everyone was perfect, mushroom, margherita, fennel sausage, 4 cheese..... deelish.....

Had to have the special that day, Berkshire Pork Braciole, all the amazing goodness of tender, most flavorful moist pork  rolled with pinenuts and spices minus the usually nasty cheese and breadcrumbs that comes with the usual braciola.

Definitely the very best pizza in the West.
author: Dave C.

description: I am not a pizza lover but this place got me eating slices 2 nights in a row so that must say something about the quality of their pies. It's quite pricey at close to $20 for an average sized pizza. I love the Salsiccia, which is comparable to a combination pizza you would get at other places. The fennel sausage is yummy. I love the dried oregano they give you with your order. It gives your pizza that extra pizzazz. This place is tiny and it gets super packed so my suggestion is take it to go.
author: Chi N.

description: Yelp did not disappoint in recommending the margarita pizza - it was savory and thin and all I would want in a margarita pizza. We sat up at the bar and watched the guys cooking at the counter which was fun. For dessert we got the cherry and chocolate sundae which was a perfect finish to the meal. Yeah, the wait isn't so fun, but at least you can drink while you wait, which makes it better!
author: Anna T.

description:
Incredible fancy pizza.

Great place to bring a date *even if you've been with them for almost 2 years! :)
author: Anthony B.

description:
Oh my goodness, this place IS as good as they say!  My friend and I had a delicious meal here on a Monday night.  It was quite busy for a 9:30pm Monday and I can only imagine how much more crazy it gets for people trying to have dinner on a Friday or Saturday!  Good luck to those who try.

I love love love thin crust pizza and if you do too this is the place for you! We dined at the bar and it was fun to see the buzz of the kitchen, nibble on the decorative stick-bread and just people watch.  First to arrive was our meatballs.  I love meatballs!  Is that a weird thing to say?  Because I'll say it again...I LOVE MEATBALLS!  This dish is excellent!  I initially thought I'd skip the bread that comes with it but ended up using it to scoop up all the marinara goodness.  Next to arrive was an off-the-menu pizza with over easy egg and sausages.  You'll have to ask your waiter/waitress for this one.  It's in some of the Yelp pictures.  The taste of that pie was drastically different from that of the popular Proscuitto Pie and it was fun to switch between the two.  I love how the Proscuitto Pie is topped with arugula. Hooray arugula!  I can't wait to return!
author: Sarah Z.

description:
Still reviewing the top 100 things to try before you die list http://www.7x7.com/2010-big-eat-sf-100-things-try-you-die

Pizzeria Delfina is hands down one of my absolute FAVORITE spots in the city. I love both locations, however normally come here as it is closest to my house. 

On the list was the Margherita pizza, which USED to be my go to order at Delfina. I still have a love for it, and completely agree that it deserves a spot on the list....however I'm now a Panna convert....I felt guilty at first neglecting my first love, but its so worth it!

So the question, try before die?...ABSOLUTELY, in fact I may request that I'm buried with both a panna and a margherita pizza from Delfina.
author: Wendy W.

description:
Went again for lunch after trying awhile ago.  Tried the fennel for the first time.  It was so good, made with fried bottarga, which is fried fish roe.  Wow...that was tasty!  The margherita pizza was a good standby...with whole slices of mozzarella.  Tried the zeppolis--delicious and light...dusted with powdered sugar and with marsapone sauce--which was delicious...but, they were not zeppolis.  They were more of a light crisp funnel cake.
Great friendly service.  Get there early for lunch.  We were there at 11:15 am on Sunday and there was already a line--they open at 11:30!
author: Kailee Q.

description:
Went on a Wednesday night, slight wait but nothing to cry about.
