Ended our meal with the server-recommended cherry sundae - it did not disappoint! The chocolate sauce was so good, I was ready to drink it out of the little pitcher it came in.
author: Kelly R.

description: I would give it five stars but their service tends to be inconsistent. Unfortunately, I have never gotten excellent service here. The pizza alone is what keeps me coming back.
author: Lina M.

description:
Mmmmmmmm.  Fabulous, tasty, gourmet pizza.  It *is* as good as they say, people.

First off, they don't take reservations, so either come early or be prepared to wait.  But the wait is worth it!

We started off with a special they had, of lightly fried cheese in anchovy butter.  Amazing.  Melt in your mouth amazing.  We also had the cannolini, which was heavenly.  Definitely a dish I have to order the next time I'm there.  We also had the broccoli pizza, which was mmmmmm.  For dessert we had the cherry chocolate gelato sundae, and espresso.  The sundae was excellent- not too sweet, and I love anything with cherries.  

All in all a very delicious and pleasant dining experience.
author: Sarah F.

description: This pizzeria is definitely different than most Italian restaurants. They use high quality ingredients and their combinations are definitely unique. We ordered the sausage pizza, sardines, gelato and the fried pizza dough with sugar. The pizza was a thin crust and the tomato sauce tasted really fresh. The pizza was good for what it is but I don't really like thin crust:( The toppings were practically falling off the pizza, which I did not like. The sardines were good but after the third bite it was getting too sour.. The fried pizza dough was alright..definitely not worth the $8. Its a little too expensive and I don't think I would come back.
author: Rosanna T.

description:
Vivacious. Satisfying. Upbeat.

When you think "pizzeria" and "good time" you should come to PD.  The restaurant is vibrant both in ambiance (bright aqua blue accent wall) and atmosphere (hip music that the line cooks jive to while  making your scrumptious meal).  

My girlfriends and I ordered the salciccia and panna pizza and shared a lighter bottle from their lengthy italian wine selection.  YUM!  The pizza is uber thin - so thin that the first few bites require holding the plate up to your mouth, or, if you're a manners maven, using fork and knife.  

The pizzas aren't dripping with toppings or sauces, and methodically so.  Every bite promises a new burst of flavor from either sausage zing or fresh parmesan nuttiness.

Know Before you GO!
1. sit at the counter!  watch the zaney line cooks groove to the beautiful beat of pizza making.

2. put your name on the chalk board immediately - there's always a line.  And then go across the street to mollie stones to sample some cheese to kill some time.

3. eat the breadsticks in the salt shakers!  they're delish!
author: Jane L.

description:
Pizza was good not great but I would definitely eat it again.

I didn't particularly like the space, tables are a bit too close together and it gets really loud in there.  If it's a sunny day, I would recommend sitting outside for lunch.  I will give them a thumbs up for carrying Mexican Coke, you know the one in the 355ML glass bottles.  Not sure why Mexican Coke tastes so much better than American Coke but it's a proven fact at this point!
author: eric f.

description:
Scrumptious! This is my new favorite spot for some good pizza. Not too greasy, not too much crust and just the right amount of cheese and other toppings. Oh to mention a perfect combination of a tasty and light tomato sauce! Heaven. 

We started with the affettati, which was a great combination of different meats and yummy bread sticks to accompany the presentation. For pizzas we split the Margherita and Salsiccia. Both were extremely tasty. I definitely want to come back for the Prosciutto as I have head great things. You can also bring your own bottle of wine and just pay the $15 corkage fee. 

One thing that may present a problem to first timers is that you have to write your name on a chalkboard as opposed to giving it to the traditional hostess. Interesting way of doing things. I didn't have a problem, but I could imagine the older crowd may find this irritating. Regardless, the food is fantastic!
author: Jen B.

description:
Started with the tuna conserva salad, then had the crispy pigs ears, and finished with the special pizza: guanciale with spring onions black pepper and a white sauce.

The food was 5 stars, the service and ambiance, 3 stars, so there you have it. 

A solid 4-star experience. Food was good and priced nicely. Service a little lacking - I showed the server the three things we were trying to decide between and he said they were all "good."  thanks pal. 

I'll be back for the tasty pizza and absolutely for the tuna salad.
author: Dama J.

description: We've eaten here a few times.  Usually reliable pizza with a fun vibe.  On Saturday though it wasn't just the pizza that was mediocre but the service too.  We had the Greccia (sp?) with spring onions, panna and pork jowl. I was thinking pieces of unctuous meat.  When it came out 40 minute later which in itself was ridiculous,  it was slivered limp white pork fat.  Yuck! The spring onions stuck in our teeth and the crust lacked flavor.  The servers were unapologetic about the wait and didn't bother about the hardly eaten pizza on the table.
author: Alison B V.

description:
I must say, a glass of wine and a panna pizza with house cured pepperoni sure does a good job of curing a case of the Mondays. I came into Pizzeria Delfina feeling a little blue and left feeling delightfully full and a wee bit buzzed. Ahhh, bliss. 

This was my first time at the Pac Heights location so I was really surprised to see how big it was inside - at least twice the size of the Mission location. My server seemed to be M.I.A. for most of the time that I was there but the entire staff was super friendly and attentive. I had at least 3 different people check up on me, take my drink order, bring me the check, ect. so I can't complain and say that I was ignored or treated poorly. It was just weird that I never really saw the person that I ended up tipping. 

As for the food, the panna pizza here was pretty much the same as the ones I've had at the Mission location but the crust was a little thicker and there was way more pepperoni (YES!!!). As much as I love Pizzeria Delfina in the Mission, this one is closer to my apartment and is just as yummy so I might be coming here from now on for my panna pizza fix!
author: Amanda R.

description:
I've been here twice now, once with a small group when it was "less busy" aka we only had to wait 5 minutes.  The other time was with a party of 8 for a birthday dinner.

I should preface that I just lived in NJ for the last 5 years and I've never had any pizza better than the thin crust at DeLorenzo's Tomato Pies (sorry NY - you don't even compare).  My boss (a NJ native) took me here since he said it's the closest he's found to pizza back there.

The time we went was this summer.  We shared the tricolore salad and each got our own pies.  I had a summer special that had ricotta and sliced cherry tomatoes on it.  It was AMAZING.  Not quite DeLorenzos, but good enough to not make me care.  The boss also let me in on the secret that you have to order the extra sauce on side (it really does take the pizza from very good to amazing).  

The second time we went back there was a much longer wait, but you can order wine inside and drink it out front while waiting, and one of the waitresses kept bringing out the breadsticks for us to munch on.  About 45 minutes later we were seated outside.  I must say, I preferred outside a great deal cause it's always SOOOO hot in there, and I'm the kind of person that's always cold.

We shared some tricolore salads and each had our own pizza.  I got the prosciutto pie, which wasn't great.  It just didn't have a lot of flavor (or sauce - it was kind of dry despite my drenching it with a side order) and I kind of wished I had tried something else.  Everyone else loved their pizzas (mainly margharita and salsiccia).

I'll still be coming back though.  Service is always quick and friendly and the food comes out quick and is consistent.  Good wine list and beers to boot.  Not too pricey for the size of the pizzas and how tasty it is.  Just get there early since they won't take reservations.
author: Kirsten M.

description:
The pizza here is good, please don't get me wrong. I like it and will most definitely order many more pies from here in the future, but for me the appetizers here always over shadow the pizza before its even arrived at the table.

On a recent visit Abby and I had the four cheese pizza with arugula, which was really good (much prettier arugula than on A16's pizzas). However, the mussels that we started with, along with the fried young favas, were utterly delicious!

The time before that  we had a so so Margaretia pizza, but a totally mouth watering appetizer of grilled fennel.

When it's in season the roasted cauliflower with calabrian chilies is also a must order item.

And as I said the pizzas are still pretty good themselves. Abby and I have especially enjoyed the Sausge pizza (the pig should be proud) and the Brocoli rabb pizza with toasted tomatoes. The only fault of them is that the crust can tend to be a bit too soft and floppy on the bottom, I like it a bit crispier down below.

Add to this that its always easy to grab a drink while you wait, the wine list is very affordably priced, and the fact that they have Sudwerk on tap, and you have your self a four star review!
author: Alex D.

description:
I could have easily given 5 stars but the music was too loud,Not really necessary.
The food though is 5  stars. Been there now 3 times and it was excellent every time. The specials are on the board and the house cured anchovies are sooo good. It is hard to recommend one over the other.
Pizzas are light and tasty, service is always friendly. Have not tried dessert yet. Wine selection is very good also.
author: Maria C.

description:
So glad they finally opened a location in the hood. It's just as good as their location in the Mission without having to drive anywhere and deal with parking... or lack therefor of.

I don't know if I would wait 2 hours (like some reviewers have mentioned) just to eat here (or anywhere for that matter), but the food and service are always top-notch. I've always had friendly service and good pie.

Oh, and to all of the ass-hats that say their pizza is too greasy, that's not grease you fucktard. They drizzle olive oil over it. Grow some taste buds! 
At least your idiocracy made it on to a t-shirt.
author: Thömas F.

description:
The pizza is just like in Italy! Naples style and one of the servers (possibly the owner?) told us she went to Naples to learn how to make the pizza just as they do. I prefer pizza with more sauce but Delfina is true to Naples style.

My only complaint was that we waited 40 minutes for a table...which I was assured was normal in SF. 

We unfortunately also didn't eat the pizza right when it came hot out of the oven (I have to sheepishly admit we ran down the street to Bi-Rite really quickly to buy a few pints since we waited so long to be seated at the pizzeria that we knew we wouldn't make it in time before Bi-Rite closed.)

But I appreciated how often they filled our water (love SF water...so clean and tasty!) and considering how many tables there are how many people were waiting to be seated, the staff did a good job managing the masses.

I also appreciate that they helped keep our ice cream in the fridge for us...although we were warned that if we forgot it, they wouldn't be held liable and would gobble it up!!!
author: Sabrina L.

description: Perfect meal for two petite gals is to split the insalata tricolore and the margarita pizza... and of course, then frizzante wine :)
author: Kate B.

description: This is my favorite pizza place full stop.  Chicago, New York, and New Haven can keep their famous this-and-that, and I'll pick Delfina over their best any day of the week and twice on Sundays.  The only downside is that we no longer live close enough to get the pizza to go - the wait for a table can be atrocious.  Oh well, its worth it.
author: Randy R.

description:
A friend got takeout from this place the other day.

When the box was opened I really wasn't impressed. I mean, it looks so simple, and small, and I thought to myself: "Great, one more overpriced gourmet pizza place"

However, open inserting said pizza into my mouth, the awesome that is Delfina has sold me. It doesn't look like much, but this shit is tasty.
author: Rhett G.

description: Absolutely LOVE Pizzeria Delfina. Excellent margherita pizza and phenomenal service- the meatballs aren't bad either!
author: Mary C.

description:
This is great pizza I could have 5 stared it but it is expensive for pizza!

My roomie and I shared 2 pizzas and got some wine- I have to say the cheapest wine was still pretty damn tasty! 

Anyway the crust here is the best part somehow it is super thin on the pizza part but on the end it raised up and delicious- 2 pizzas for 2 girls was for sure too much food but at least we got some leftovers :) 

I like the atmosphere and the locations is quite convenient but be aware get here early cause this place fills up quickly!
author: Janae L.

description: I love the food at Delfina. The staff is so nice. The only problem, which really affects how much I like the place, is the music. They make it so loud during dinner that you can't talk or hear the people you are with. If you ask them to turn it down, they lower the volume for 5 minutes, and then turn it back up at least as loud, maybe louder. I take my kids there and it happens every time. Without the noise problem, I would give it 4 or 5 stars.
author: M H.

description:
I went there with girlfriend and another friend.  Place was super packed with a long ass waiting list. Since we heard so much about this place, why not wait?

Don't get me wrong food here is good, not super great.  

Had the Margherita pizza Salsiccia pizza, Insalata Tricolore and the meatballs.

I liked everything I had there, but nothing stood out.  I would give it 3 1/2 stars at the highest.  Good food and place is super clean and nice looking restaurant.  

If there's a alternative to another high end pizzeria, I would choose Little Star Pizza on Divisadero St.
author: Peter L.

description:
Always packed and you'll probably have to wait for a bit.  

Cute interior - very quaint but definitely a little pressed for space (I definitely feel like I'm rubbing elbows with my neighbor but a very local feel.  It's both fortunate and unfortunate that the pizzas are so good (nice crispy thin crust, fresh ingredients) that I can eat an entire small by myself...  My favorite, without a doubt, is the housemade sausage pizza with peppers and onions - soooo good!!!  I'll be back, but I hate having to wait and smell their amazing pizzas while I'm starving....
author: Stephanie P.

description:
The Breakdown:
-Plenty of Metered Street parking around the area
-To be put on waitlist, put your name down near the front of the door on the chalkboard
-No reservations taken

I had high hopes for this place, especially since it was an hour and a half long wait to be seated. I got here at 6:45pm to get a seat for my 5 girls who were coming and we weren't seated until 7:30ish. We decided to order the calamari appetizer and 3 pizzas (Margherrita-$13, Proscuitto Pie- $17, and the one with the two eggs-$15). I was disappointed in all three pies. They were all tasty but lacking in toppings! The Margherita only had 3 pieces of basil. The one with the two eggs came out exactly as I had hoped for, but darn it I wish that for $15 that there was more to it. The Proscuitto was actually really good but became really salty and i wished they had better toppings to balance it out with. The calamari appetizer was also a fail. We thought we were ordering fried calamari but it turned out to be another dish. Though it was our fault for assuming it was fried, the dish really could have had more than 3 finger sized pieces for $10. 

Won't be back, too overrated for me. I'm most definitely sure I can find tastier pizza at a more reasonable price without the wait.
author: Connie C.

description:
SUPER OVERPRICED PIZZA. Better a day old. 

The margherita pizza was flavorless.
The three cheese was slightly better. 

Dani's pizza in NY totally blows this out of the water. 

Overall, totally sad that it didn't leave a better impression.
author: carmen l.

description:
We were very excited to dine here, given the reviews. Everything we had was good: the Margherita, the burratta, and  the sauteed Spicy Cauliflower. The pigs ears were disappointing though-lacked seasoning.  The portions were the most disappointing part--there were literally three pieces of cauliflower, enough for each of us to have one.  

Still, if I'm rating this just based on the food, I guess I'd still give it the four stars, but it'd be 2 stars for the portions/price.
author: Ali A.

description: You can bring it back to 5 stars Delfina... just make sure the Fungi Pizza is permanently on the menu. I have been back twice now, missing it both times! Please bring it back :(
author: Raina B.

description:
Everyone else has already said it.  I'd give it six - no, ten - if I could.  I've only lived in this city about two and a half years and already been there more times than I can count. 

If you go (which you should), get the Panna pizza.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Con - if you come during prime time dining hours you will wait a long time. 

Now that that's out of the way, on to the pros: 

Best damn pizza I've had in a long time. I've been to the PD in the Mission at least 5-6 times and have always said the broccoli raab pizza is my favorite pie in the city - the version we had last night at the new Pac Heights location was even better. Was it the added olives? The hunger after an hour long wait? The company? 

The Salsiccia featured housemade fennel sausage, tomato, bell peppers, onions and mozzarella and was really good...it just paled in comparison to the raab. 

Oh, we also had the spicy cauliflower antipasti and it was AMAZING! Who'd a thunk that cauliflower could ever taste that good?!? 

Prices across the board were pretty fair - for two of us we split an antipasti, two pizzas and four glasses of wine and it came out to under $100 including tip. We probably could have ordered only one pizza (we had lots of leftovers) but where's the fun in that? 

So about that wait...yes, it took us an hour from the moment we put our names on the chalkboard to the time we sat down but we were able to get a couple of glasses of wine and wait outside with the rest of the masses. Here's the thing, would you rather wait an hour for a fantastic meal or be seated right away for something not so great? Yeah, that's what I thought.
author: phil h.

description: The ambiance is nice. The pizza was good. Arugula and Prosciutto is my fave. Sign up on a chalkboard and enjoy some Smitten Ice Cream next door after. The perfect follow up.
author: Kristen S.

description:
This pizza is absolute perfection. Tried the margherita and the broccoli raab. Both are great - but nothing can beat the classic margherita. Also tried the fried risotta. And for after the meal, had a latte.

SO SO SO GOOD. Definitely the best pizza in the Bay Area and honestly, maybe even NYC...it's that good. 

Also, great service. Very personable. Restaurant has an overall great vibe and fantastic  decor. 

Currently my fav place in SF.
author: MJ S.

description:
Pizzeria Delfina is simply fantastic! This is perhaps the best place for pizza in the city. The Margherita pizza is delicious (it is topped with  Bufala Mozzarella) and so is the Panna pizza which has more of a cream based sauce. For starters I'd recommend ordering the Warm Marinated Olives! Since there is always a line, I'd recommend planning to get here at 5:45 or 6 to avoid the line or ordering take out. But the long wait sure is worth it. I truly believe that this place really does live up to the hype. I'm glad that this is in my neighborhood!

the pac heights menu: http://www.pizzeriadelfina.com/pacificHeights_menu.html
author: Valerie F.

description:
Overall it was just meh.........

We had the Prosciutto Pie and Salsiccia and it seemed like I needed some extra sauce or salt or something.  It was kind of flavorless in my opinion. 

It was super crowded and the wait was long.  We also got seated outside (they gave us a choice but took it since the wait was long) and it was kinda cold.

The Prosciutto Pie was $17.  I didn't really understand what the whole hype was all about..........
author: Val S.

description: LOVE. Wish I could eat this pizza every day. Their meatballs are divine (and I'm not normally a meatball person), just wish it came with more toast crisps. Been here many times and def will be back!
author: Courtney M.

description:
My friend got there before me, so they didnt seat him.  I got there, two tables became available.  His name was not called.  We were confused.  The guy looked at us.. and was like.. OMG did i skip you.  we said.. yes.  He went over to the just seated table to ask them to get up.  We were like.. wait hold up, its cool, we will wait.  dont make them get up.  the guy was like are you sure... we said, yeah dont worry about it.  we ended up waiting 20 longer.  

You must be thinking... how come I am still giving them 4 stars... because they more than made up for it later on.  First of all, i think the waitress we got was super nice to begin with.  She came over super quick, and we ordered a beer, a diet coke and the tripe salad.  

Got those things, the tripe was sliced thin, you dont really taste any intestinal taste.  they gave us this chill oil that I loved.  I put it on my pizza later one.  

soon after, the waitress came over with another appetizer... "a gift from the kitchen" for us being so nice.  We were like.. cool.  That was a pretty good appetizer too.  The guy came over later and said its kinda like a really good hot pocket.  It was like fried bread filled with cheese and meat placed on a plate of tomato sauce.  

We got two pizzas, one is the sausage and the other is 4 cheese.  both of which, i can say is the best pizza ive had in a long time in SF.  the crust is super thin, but the outer rim is chewy.  Love it.  and the sauce... oh the sauce.... i can drink that sauce... mmmmmm  I guess for me.. its all about the crust and the sauce.  Both of which, is the best ive had in SF.  This place is giving me faith back in SF pizza.

The guy gave me friend a free beer later on too.  I call it karma...
author: Janet S.

description:
Great neighborhood for Pizzeria Delfina... casual but trendy Lower Pac Heights should draw a steady crowd to this 3rd cozy spot in the Delfina family.  My favorite restaurant in the city is Delfina itself and have been very excited to sample their thin crust pies.

The decor is casual and comfortable.  Was never too loud and the bar seats offer a nice pre-meal ogling at the chefs preparing your starters.  Speaking of the bar seats... bravo on providing back support and hooks for your purses.  

Service was pretty shotty... we had a very late afternoon lunch where the dining room really wasn't that crowded.  Our wait staff was very flighty and never seemed to check on us.  We had to flag down others a few times. 

For a starter we ordered a fried dough filled with mozz, sausage and something else.  The names on the menu will always require a translation so I forget what this dish was really called.  It came piping hot as 4 little dough balls on a bed of homemade marinara sauce.  Awesome.  Truly mouthwatering and worthy of a place in the entree section had the portion been doubled.  The mozzarella is fresh and rich as was the tomatoey marinara.  It wasn't greasy either... just nicely crisp.  

For the pizza we ordered the one with clams on top.  It sounded and looked great, until we popped it into our mouths.  Holy cow... salty enough to slightly burn my tongue raw.  What a huge disappointment.  The crust was paper thin, but got very dry when we came to the end piece.  I couldn't guzzle my water fast enough to soothe my mouth.

I have faith that their other pizzas would be better.  I know Delfina offers quality products, and majority of the reviews have been positive.  I'd come back to give it a 2nd chance and for a second stab at those fried dough balls!
author: Chris T.

description:
I have finally found pizza I can enjoy in The States! After studying abroad in Italy for 5 months I learned that I actually liked pizza. Just not the doughy, greasy, stuffed-crust loaded, American crap. Thanks to Delfina's new digs near my apt, I have discovered the traditional thin crust, fresh cheese, light sauce, and non-greasy succulent pizza reminiscent of Italia.

There were three of us and we were not super hungry so we decided to share an appetizer, salad and pizza. We each opted for glass of vino rosso from Delfina's ample wine (by the glass or bottle) list. you can sip a decent glass of wine for $5.50! 

The spicy cauliflower is where we started. Boiled, fried (no batter), olive oil, garlic and chili peppers made this one of my fave veggie side dishes ever! The pizza was a tough decision. Should  we get the 4 formaggi or the margarita? We actually settled on the Napolaneta which was the perfect combo of tomatoes, capers, anchovies and garlic. No cheese unless you sprinkle some parm on top. It was so good and not overwhelming in the slightest way....I would even venture to say this was a healthy pizza. 

Our waitress, Sarah, was great and Delfina is a wonderful choice for a casual dinner without breaking the bank.....and it's seriously delicious.
author: Theresa T.

description:
THE BEST PIZZA cooked to perfection!  Had the prociotto and the insalata tricolore.
All served very timely and really really good pizza.
Will definitely come back when Im in town.  Better neighborhood than the mission location too.
author: Melissa S.

description:
The pizza here is meh. 

Ordered a margarita for take out... it was kinda of tasteless and there were only 3 sad little basil leaves on it.  It was also a bit skimpy on the cheese side.  Plus, it took 5-10 minutes of me standing at the register to get someone's attention to pay and pick up my pizza.  

Maybe sit down is better, but if the taste and service level I experienced is any indication then I'm not sure.  I'll update if I experience different.  But as of right now... I don't get what all the hype is about.
author: Ms. M. M.

description:
Pizzeria Delfina, you have my undying affection. 
you + me = 4eva

When we showed up to the new Pacific Heights location, the place was poppin'! Off the chain, y'all. We put our names on the chalk board, ordered a glass of wine and waited outside for our names to be called. I love that they allow you to drink wine on the sidewalk while you wait. How Euro, or at the very least, charming.

Once inside, there's a gorgeous mural of the Bay Bridge on the left wall, some tables and my favorite -- the long counter on the right, where you can sit and watch the sous chefs work their magic. For someone like myself who's into food, but doesn't quite understand how it all comes together, watching the chefs is like being a tourist visiting the Galapagos for the first time. You don't quite understand what's going on and resort to embracing the mystery of it all.

My favorite, the tricolore salad, tasted like sunshine, with bright lemony flavors over raddichio, endive and arugula. Next up, the fennel was fresh, charred just a bit and drizzled with an exquisite olive oil. Drum roll for the main event, please... pizza with pork jowls, which our server described as tasting a little but like "candied bacon." Omg.
author: Nicole G.

description:
Great pizzas. More expensive than a normal pizza, but not bad.  My date and I were able to split 1 pizza and 1 appetizer for around $30. The apps are to die for.  A great place for a fun date.  Just be sure to drop your name in 1-2 hours early, then grab a drink and come back!

The pizza is seriously amazing though!  Plus they do take-out.
author: Chris L.

description:
Despite a few hiccups Pizzeria Delfina delivers a slice of thin crusted nirvana and delectable tastes.

I haven't anticipated a restaurant more than Pizzeria Deflina. Mainly because I'm lazy and it's in my hood, and because my ass was on the line as the first reviewer for this place. So this review is gonna be deeetailed. Get out the spreadsheet baby.

Let's start with the food. The Tuna Conserva appetizer was a mixture of lightly poached tuna, silky extra-virgin olive oil and creamy cannellini beans beside a bed of watercress topped with a lemony tweeest. It was a pleasant blend of tuna & bean richness with an acidic watercress & dressing foil. I could've only liked it more if the tuna were raw and served with crisps rather than watercress.

Adding more fiber to the meal we sampled the tricolore salad, a mixture of endives, greens and grana padano cheese. It was refreshingly bitter, lightly dressed with EVO and surprisingly complimented the tuna.

Next we shared a sausage pizza. The crust was sooo thin, and crisped to perfection. I couldn't get over the sweet sauce with fresh mozzarella swimming in pools of tomatoey goodness and zingy fennel sausage. While in truth this sauce was a tad salty, it was tempting enough to drink like a soup. And how about that dough - crisp, crackly under the topping, bubbly and chewy at the end. Gimmie some more sauce to dunk that golden handle in, mmmm!

For dessert we sampled pear and caramel gelato. The pear was fragrant and deceptively sweet. The caramel didn't work so well, although it played games with my taste buds - for some reason it tasted like rootbeer float!

I loved all the special touches to the restaurant. It felt unique and well designed. The old Zao's noodle felt awkward and cheap. They did a *great* job on the remodel. PD is warm, inviting with a mural of the Bay on the wall and elegant wood seating and tables. I know I'll come by to eat at the bar sometime soon. The chalk boards by the entrance are clever, and encourage diners to add their scrawl to the mix, keeping the waiting list and wine list clear for the day.

The service was full of smiles and attentive. Small touches like magically refilled water carafes and replaced dropped nakins made my night. The only hiccups were orders got mixed up a couple times - our tricolore salad almost ended up on another table, and we almost got someone's Spicy Cauliflower. Waiting for our check took a bit long too, but considering how packed it was getting around 7pm our servers were pretty efficient. It'd be nice if they turned down the music volume a bit - [John McCain voice] I'mmm getting old and crotchety!

Per my last review, while I didn't end up slathering myself in sauce (even though the taste merits it) or running through the kitchen naked (I'm sure my restraint was appreciated), I can't wait to return again and again. For the quality of food at a fair price PD is a great value. I just wish they served tiramisu!

4.5 * stars
author: Brady K.

description:
I will do some things for great pizza that I wouldn't do otherwise.  For example, in the case of Pizzeria Delfina, I will arrive at the geriatric hour of 5:30 and wait half an hour for a table, and sit way too close to other people than is comfortable to me in normal circumstances.  I will do this because their white pie, the one with the prosciutto, is so so so so so good!  Good Lord, it's good!  

I will not even argue with anyone whether this is New York style pizza or not.  Ok, I will a little.  I think it's more European style than New York style, and if you really want New York style pizza just go to New York, for there is no equal. None.  However, if you want great European style pizza made with fresh, local, house-made ingredients (Fresh-stretched Mozzarella - mmmm!), try Pizzeria Delfina.

Get there early and enjoy a glass of wine on the sidewalk while you wait.  The lady with the chalk is the one to make friends with.
author: Liz S.

description:
Having been to the Mission location a number of times it was time to try the Pac Heights location with my former roommates who had never been [to either].

I should disclose that I grew up in the NY Metro Area though this is not one of those 'in search of best NY-style thin crust' sojourns...

Instead, I was simply underwhelmed by the food coming from such a pedigreed name.  Though the appetizers were tasty, especially the asparagus, the pizzas were ho-hum.  Toppings were unevenly spaced landing only with the cheese in the center third of the pie leading to a large portion of bubbly and over-charred crust.  It tasted fresh made but satisfied like a good frozen pizza (if that actually exists).

Service was good which helped after the 50 min wait on a seemingly quiet Thursday night.  The cute presentation of the herbs is nice but not nearly enough for two, let alone four people.  They are quick to replenish supplies when asked.

On balance, it's not bad if there's no wait, otherwise I'd say skip it and get some good pizza elsewhere-- there's no lack of venues in SF for such.
author: Vinjah A.

description:
We came here last night before a movie.  I got there a bit early and enjoyed some wine at the counter (it's not really a bar!).  It was super busy the whole time I was there  The staff kept rushing about and changing.  They seemed stressed; not calm.  I was not allowed to add our name to the board unless everyone was there.  We ended up sitting at the counter and it was fine.  By this point, I was at my third waiter. and I wasn't there that long!

The Ciro wine was great and it had a relaxing quality.   We shared the hot marinated olives, which were highly recommended by my buddy Sheila who was there the previous week..  They were great and so was the house salad.  We loved the broccoli rabi and prosciutto pizzas.  It's not thin crust but they are very good.

I am not sure I like the chalk board and having to wait for a table.   I would have to have a plan B if I was coming here since with the food options in our great city, standing in line for an hour to eat seems silly.
author: Ayelet B.

description:
So, I've waited a LONG time to finally try P Delfina. My friends and family have been raving about the crust, saying it's one of the best in the city. Well, I tried it today and do not agree. At all.

SERVICE - (2 Stars) It all started off great. We arrived for lunch within a few minutes of opening, were greated by a friendly smile and professional attitude, and promptly seated near the kitchen. Once seated, we were serviced promptly and advised of the special and also a modification to the daily menu. A few minutes later, we placed our order for our salad, two pizzas (pies), and two beverages. About five minutes later, we received our salad. After we finished our shared salad (which took about 6 minutes), the salad serving plate was cleared. But this is when the service started to turn... We had noticed that the table next to us (who had been seated after us, and had their order taken just before ours), had already received their pie, eaten what they could (at a leisurely, Fillmore-District-pace), and had their leftover piece boxed up; Before one of our pies was delivered to our table.

Pies were flying out of the kitchen. I appreciate their team delivery service. The chef yells "RUNNER" and one of the servers acknowledges for presentation to the table.

It was over 15 minutes from the time our salad was cleared until our first pie arrived. Correct me if I'm wrong, but it does not take more than 10 minutes to bake a Delfina pie. I will admit that one of my pies had sausage and I will give them the benefit of doubt that it takes longer to bake a pie with (raw?) sausage, but I don't know if they use raw sausage for their pies. But the other pie had prosciutto. I watched them make it... and that one should not have taken any longer than a meatless pie.

What they should have done was managed my expectations better. They should have advised us when our pies would be at our table, sooner than when they did. (Our server actually said to us that our pies would be out in "two minutes", after we had already waited over 10 minutes; but the pies did not arrive in two minutes). Advice to all restaurants... NEVER LEAVE A PATRON WONDERING WHEN THE NEXT EVENT IS ABOUT TO HAPPEN.

AMBIANCE - (4 Stars) I had a great feeling walking towards our table. It was a fresh, open-air dining area and the kitchen and prep areas were open to people walking towards the back/restrooms. Cool UK alternative music was playing on the audio system and a wide range of customers filled the area with excitement. Our table was clean and presented in a minimalist, yet functional arrangement, complete with tasty breadsticks.

FOOD - (2 Stars) This is where I wish I could give a higher rating. We started off with a "gem?" salad that consisted of romaine hearts and avocado. The dressing was very tasty and had a hint tarragon? I would eat a gigantic bowl of this salad if it were given to me. Then we had the prosciutto pie and also the salsiccia pie. My first bites of both of these pies TASTED AMAZING. But that's where the "amazing" stopped. I ended up eating 5 slices of pie within 10 minutes. Each bite was less enjoyable than the previous, because the pie crust was getting more chewy. By the time I had my last bite, my jaws were really tired. It still tasted good. It was still hot. But the texture just killed the enjoyment.

VALUE - (1 Star) What does $70 get you for lunch for two? Breadsticks, two pies, a salad, a hot tea, a soft drink, and a pile of disappointment. I can get over the chewy crust and give it another shot. But waiting and waiting for food, when others are served quickly really kills it for me.
author: Ray C.

description:
This hyper-trendy pizzeria is surprisingly baby-friendly.  We showed up on a Friday around 12:45, and they did their darnedest to seat us.  Unfortunately, they can't put a high chair at the end of a booth, so we had to wait a while until a table opened up that was big enough for the three of us.  They didn't seem like they were trying to brush us off, though, and apologized profusely for the wait.  Luckily, they have tasty crisp breadsticks on the table when you sit down, so you can distract a fussy toddler right away.

The food is pretty grown-up, but you could probably please a picky eater with the four cheese pizza.  We thoroughly enjoyed the fresh mozzarella and the Salsiccia pizza.  Service is quick, and friendly enough for a hot San Francisco eatery.  


High chairs?  Yep
Changing table?  There's a cabinet in the restroom, and they claimed there was a changing pad to put on top of it, but I couldn't find it.  If you've got a little one, ask and I'm sure they can get it for you.  
Stroller-friendly?  Mostly--they took our stroller and stowed it out of the way, but it's pretty tight quarters in there
Noise level?  High, but babies like it when you sing along with Cake
General baby-friendliness?  Very!
author: Jennifer G.

description: Good pizza, but not as creative/tasty as Beretta, Starbelly etc.  Need more topping combos!  I want to try the actual Delfina restaurant because I hear it's much better.
author: Anna V.

description:
hmmmm... the new hot spot in Pac Heights and the crowd is exactly what you'd expect. I don't understand why you have to wear such a short dress when your legs are really really really not made for it... 

anyway... we decided to try it out a few weekends ago and were pleasantly surprised.

Well let me say that my husband is more the thick dough with a million toppings type of guy but even he liked  Delfina's  pizza. 

They are crispy with great topping combinations and foremost they remind me of the pizza I grew up with in Germany...yumm
author: Doro P.

description:
the warm marinated olives were good.   the pizza was not.  we had the prosciutto pie --  boring.  a cheese pizza with with a little meat and covered with an arugula "salad".  disappointing.   

pat f.
baton rouge,la
author: Pat F.

description:
cons: long wait, about 45 minutes on a Monday night. Also the space is really cramped, which doesn't lend itself for a relaxing dining experience. The space is hectic and uninviting.

pros: the food. the food is amazing. It was worth the wait. We ordered a couple dishes, starting with the meatballs, which were amazing. the two pizzas we had also hit the spot. at the end of all this nothing was left and we wanted more, so we ordered desert. The deserts were some of the best i have had in a while and I'm not a big desert person. We got the brioche and some dough dish. Both were AMAZING.

If the space wasn't so crowded I would come back often. That being said, I might not become a regular, but I will be back again,
author: Bobby P.

description:
Lots of reviews here, so I'll keep mine short:

Went on a Wed night, waited about 20 mins for a table/booth. People were still waiting for tables when we left past 9pm.

They have cool breadsticks and keep a bottle of water on the table so you can refill it yourself - prob a good thing considering how busy they were. 

Anchovies appetizer was delish, so was the margherita pizza. Lots of melting mozzarella. Yummm. Their brioche w/ choco and vanilla gelato (made daily) was excellent. Ended up being about $40 pre-tip.

Sevice was sketchy, our waitress went mia after she took our order. We had to flag down two other waiters to 1. get more of the bread things that came with the anchovies, 2. get the dessert menu, 3. order the dessert. But our og waitress appeared magically when it was time to give us & collect the bill.

Specials on their menu changes frequently. Dunno if it happens a lot, but two of the items on their menu were either sold out or were no longer available. :(
author: Seri T.

description:
This is actually two reviews in one, as my first Pizza Delfina experience in the Mission a few years back was before I was yelping. I know, the horror. I'm correcting that now.

Tonight was a reminder that a healthy yelper can go too far in his or her quest to be healthy. Sometimes you just have to let it go, and enjoy all that the chef intended to be on your plate.

Much to my delight, my dining partner so loved his first time here earlier in the week that he wanted to order the exact same thing - splitting the lemon-infused salad and a prosciutto pizza. My first thought was, well, not a big ham eater, but breaking the routine is good, and as usual, I'd have my half without cheese.

That last part was met with a slightly puzzled look on the waiter, who had to double check if this was even doable. He came back saying it was not, which typically means a few less stars on the review. But with my friend effusing how awesome it was, and me still in a celebratory mood from a four hour dance fest the night before, I said what the heck, let's do it.

It turned out to be a wise, wise choice. What an amazing pizza. We scarfed down the three slices each in no time, and the mix of prosciutto and cheese on what might be the world's best crust was indelible. Two hours later, all I can think about is how I want another round.

A few nice extras - the skinny breadsticks are perfect for munching, and the heat lamps made eating outside on a February night a reality.

And do save room for dessert - the house gelato was marvelous, and I think our choice of chocolate and caramel paired well.

Pizza Delfina is right up there as one of the best pizzas I've ever had. Do enjoy, and to all my fellow healthy yelpers, this one is worth the splurge.
author: Jason B.

description:
A few weeks ago, I had a chance to try Pizzeria Delfina.  After hearing rave reviews from friends, I expected big things from the pizza.  The pizza was certainly good but the cheese and sauce was not as flavorful as my favorite pizza place in the city, Pazzia.  If you like a doughy crust, you might love the crust at Pizzeria Delfina but I prefer a crunchier crust.  There were also a few inexcusable flaws with the pizza that made me want to give the pizza an overall rating of  a two, but that would be too harsh.  The pizza was served warm and not hot.  Also, the pizza was burnt, so it shouldn't have been served to the customer.  I was attending a concert after dinner, so I didn't want to send it back.

If the pizza was served hot and not burnt, the pizza might be more like a 4 rating, but it's just hard to fairly judge a warm burnt pizza.
author: Josh K.

description:
It is absolutely vital to get here early. Although bigger than the location on 18th, this Delfina isn't big enough to accommodate that many hungry diners. Four of us got to the restaurant a little after five. If we had arrived any later, we would have had to wait. Sure, the waiting list is super cute where you write your name on a giant chalkboard that also serves as the drinks menu on the wall near the entrance. But judging from how large that chalkboard is, and how cramped the little entrance is when you stuff 20 adults and kids there, it's really more fun to sit at a table than to wait. 

Being in an adventurous mood, and really a dangerous one, we ordered the Clam Pie and the special Winter Chicories pizza. Clam Pie was very very salty and spicy. You won't even notice or care how many clams were on the pizza at this point. All you can think is what in the world am I eating? 

Winter Chicories, a slightly bitter green, felt like lettuce in texture, kinda slimy and slides off the thin pizza as you bite into it. Not a pretty scene. Glad I wasn't on a date. The sunny side up eggs were good, but the whole thing is just, strange. Perhaps a bit too avant garde for my taste. 

Fortunately we also ordered two good dishes. 4 Formaggi, which I have had at the 18th St location, is delicious as ever. We probably should have just ordered three of those. And the special calamari and chickpeas salad dripping with olive oil is quite tasty. 

Waitress very knowledgeable about wine, and service was efficient. 

There were surprisingly a lot of kids there. I can go on and on about "when I was 5, going out for pizza meant Round Table and not posh Delfina". But we are talking about food here, plus I am really not that old. So I will just shut up now.
author: Candice B.

description:
Get there early and avoid the wait...but if you have to wait, its worth it.

The tricolore salad sounds a bit boring, but it isnt at all, is a great way to start the meal. All of the pizzas are great, but really take advantage of their specials, you will usually find a really great and unique pizza. 

This is definitely the best thin crust pizza I have had in the city.
author: justin b.

description: So darn good! Hubby and I shared the Broccoli Raab pizza. We were told it would be slightly on the bitter side, but I have to say it was incredibly tasty. Our appetizer, the fresh stretched mozzarella was amazing too. It came with a little arugula salad on the side and some crusty buttered bread. Oh and the crunchy breadsticks are perfect to satiate the hunger while you wait in anticipation. The only caveat is the wait time. Almost always crowded so it can take anything from 20 to 45 min to get a table!
author: Natasha I.

description: Yum, yum and yum!  This place is so good and the staff is so friendly and wonderful.  My favorites are the tuna conserva salad and the sausage pizza.  You also can't go wrong with the meatballs.  There is almost always a wait but just write your name on the chalkboard and you'll be called in when a seat opens up.
author: Karen K.

description:
I had a hard time deciding between this place and Little Star.  I decided to try this place first.  The wait was a little painful for a Sunday night, but the great neighborhood and wine eased the pain.  

Once our name was called they pointed us to the counter.  I was pretty irritated that we waited all that time to get a counter seat, but I relented.  In hindsight, it was the best decision.  It was amazing watching the chef prepare every dish.  Decided what you wanted was a snap when you see it right in front of you!  Plus, the chef passed along some samples of items we asked about.

Our meal-
1/2 order of meatballs
tri-colored salad
Margarita & Cheese w/pepperoni pizza's
raspberry & lemon gelato

What a wonderful experience and a great way to spend a Sunday night.
author: jennifer j.

description: I have been to two locations on two separate occasions and this is by far the absolute best Pizza I have ever had. Do your self a favor and get there Mushroom pizza if its on special. I also had a phenomenal House made ball of soft Mozzarella cheese and I cannot stop thinking about it.
author: Josh D.

description:
They're cool, but there's not enough toppings.
Yes, I wanted more anchovies.
The crust is chewy and not in the NY or Ital. way.
Good by the glass list for a pizza place.  It's a scene.
author: Jake H.

description:
This was my first Pizzeria Delfina experience after 1.5 years in SF, and I can safely say I was pretty pleased.  My friends and I went on a Monday night, so the wait was not as horrendous as I've heard it can be sometimes.  The restaurant is in a family-friendly area, so there were a number of families with kids dining around us.  We waited about 30 minutes before being seated in a booth towards the back.  Our waitress was friendly and very helpful with answering questions about the menu (since a lot of it was in simple foodie Italian, it was a tad confusing at times).

I ended up ordering the slow-cooked pork, while my friends had the Broccoli Raab Pizza and the Prosciutto Pie.  We snacked on the delicious bread sticks while we waited.  To drink, I got an Arnold Palmer (half ice tea and half lemonade, which I believe is made fresh)... it was one of the best Arnies I've ever had.  The food arrived after about 10-15 minutes.  My dish was delicious!  My friends enjoyed their pizza as well, and the pies were large enough for half to be taken home for later.

Overall, it was a good place for a meal with friends.  I'll be back... but probably only on a Monday to avoid waiting forever to eat.

D on't go if you don't want to wait... there's almost always a wait here.
E at the pizza... but you might miss out on some great non-pizza dishes like the slow-cooked pork.
L oved the Arnold Palmer... the home-made lemonade was a key ingredient.
F eel free to bring the kids. This restaurant was quite kid-friendly.
I nterior felt homey and welcoming.
N ice weather calls for dining outside of the restaurant.
A lways eat the bread sticks... they are fantastic.
author: Kenny L.

description: I was hanging out near the area and finally decided to try this place for the first time. It is crowded so expect a bit of a wait during peak hours. Pizza was great as expected, with a nice crispy and flavorful thin crust. Thin crusts tend to get soggy quickly, but theirs does not, which makes it better than most. Their duck crostini appetizer was also excellent. Service was friendly, relaxed, and helpful. A very good place overall.
author: Neil F.

description: So I don't go to Delfina b/c I'm craving a delicious pizza.  The pizza isn't bad, it just isn't compelling enough to make me go out of my way.  Same for the meatballs.  I've probably never had anything terrible there but at the end of the day it's one of those places that provides solid food for an okay price and it's all pretty and clean and good looking people eat there.
author: Poppy C.

description:
Clam Pie Pizza, Sausage Fennel Pizza, Fritta Pigs Ears, Rosemary Ice Cream, Blood Orange Salad, Wine......  All were delicious!  
Blondes with attitutde was a sight:)  Most were happy, but a few complained way tooooo much!  "SMACK" "SLAP"!!!!!:D
author: Demanding T.

description: My fiancee and her two small children went to Delfina last Saturday, 07/07/12.  The Fillmore Jazz Fest was on and the restaurant was very busy.  we waited about 45 minutes for a table.  The reviews were good so I expected good food.  The food was excellent.  Especially the calamari salad with garbanzo beans and arugula over a lemon olive oil dresssing.  The Salsiccia pizzza was outstanding.  I was really impressed with our server, Heidi G, 5177.  She was very professional, polite, courteous and very attentive.  I could sense her smile and service were very genuine.  If there were 6 starts I would give that to Heidi.  Overall combined and outstanding experience.
author: Phil H.

description: Some excellent food. Average service. Super busy--so busy that they need a strong manager. Often run out of grissini.  Pizza is delicious.
author: Kenzie D.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants, great pizza and love their apps.  They once had grilled fresh marinated sardines as a special, wish they'd bring that back.  

I am a big fan of the carry out "half baked" pizzas.  10 minutes in your oven and they are as good as being at the restaurant.

The wait can be long, but just get your name on the chalkboard, and go have a cocktail at Elite Cafe around the corner.
author: Andrew R.

description:
Lunch today at the Pac Heights branch of Pizza Delfina.  It was hardly well marked, I felt like I was looking for Bourbon and Branch or something.  (It's the restaurant with the black awning just west of Fillmore on California).

Ordered the Margherita pizza with Bubalis Mozzarella di Bufala.  I like that they give you a little plate with cheese, oregano leaves and crushed red pepper to add to the pizza.  I used all three which improved my pie.

Pizza was very good to great.  Not as excellent as I remember my last pie at their Mission location, but pretty darn good.

There was no line at lunch time.  Sat at one of the 8 seats at the counter.  Service was fine.  

Slight annoyance that the healthy SF charge was just as much as the sales tax on my pizza.  They should just build the cost of the health insurance into the prices on the menu.  When their rent goes up is there going to be a $1 surcharge for high rent?  C'mon.
author: Aaron T.

description:
I am going to make this review short and sweet.  

High Lights!
- Loved the ambiance 
- Loved the staff (the hostess was extremely gracious and helpful even it was uber busy)
- Pizza was delicious
- Server was extremely attentive and had great suggestions with the menu
- On the pricier side but not wallet busting 
- Had to wait about 45 mins to get a table but was able to enjoy a beverage before outside.

Very good spot and would absolutely attend again! Did not get 5 stars as the prices were just a bit to high.  But if I could give 4.5 I would have!!!!
author: Ryan B.

description: Truly one of the Best Pizzas Ive had in San Francisco!  The service is outstanding but the Wine list is a little weak.
author: M J.

description:
I came here for a late lunch on a Monday - and the place was PACKED!  So, beware if you are going during peak lunch or dinner hours because you will be waiting.  

We sat at the bar.  Did you know they have wine on tap?....can I get one of those in my house?

Anyway, on to the food.  

-Artichoke, arugula, ricotta salad - SO GOOD!...and really simple.
-Cheese fried in some dough - I can't remember the proper name and thought they were 'meh.'
-Spicy cauliflower - not spicy, and overcooked
-Proscuitto pizza - the most expenisve pizza on the menu and worth every penny!!  It had arugula with truffle oil and was absolutely dreamy.

This is the perfect place to come with a few friends so you can share a bunch of the dishes - atmosphere is fun and loud, just like a pizza place should be!
author: Megan H.

description: We had a horrendous experience here the other night. I'd only been 1 time before that and thought the pizza was sub-par and frankly too flimsy, but given the reviews and consistent crowds outside I figured I'd give it another shot. To start off, they erased our name from the self-service chalkboard so we sat outside for almost 2 hours until I noticed that they were seating people that had shown up after we had. When I approached the hostess after I figured this out, she unapologetically and rudely responded with "I didn't erase your name but I'll get you a table after I sit this party." SERIOUSLY? If that's your method of tracking your wait list, stay on top of it or take responsibility when you mess up. And the fact she made us wait until the next table opened instead of sitting us before the party she had is absurd. When we did get sat, our waiter was hardly concerned we'd been overseen and it took a good 7 mins for him to even take our order, mostly because he was socializing with his friends that were seated at the table next to us (this went on all night).  We ordered a pizza, mussels and the romaine salad. I asked if we could have the lemon salad dressing instead of the green goddess dressing that usually comes on the salad - simple request in my opinion - and our waiter responded that the kitchen really doesn't like to make substituions. Again, SERIOUSLY? Unless they pre-dress their salad (which would be gross), I can't imagine why this was such a difficult thing to accommodate. So we went with the salad that came with the lemon dressing, which was good, but then they dropped off our pizza (literally - didn't even stop to check if we needed anything) and didn't give us new plates. For a place that charges $16 for a pizza that barely feeds 2 people you'd think they'd give you new plates before they served your main entree. Our waiter then completely forgot our mussels and never came back to ask how things were. So my mom had to get up and go ask another waiter where they were. They arrived a couple minutes later (no apology) and had hardly any broth so many were dried out. To top all of this off, they started playing gangster rap over the loud speaker!!! My mom ended up complaining to the manager, who really was the only saving grace in the entire situation and was extremely sweet. She gave us some extra wine and a dessert on the house and comped our mussels. Still, after tax and the comped mussels, our meal was $90. It was a disaster and I wil never go back. The only reason I'm giving it 2 stars is: 1 for the manager on duty, 1 for the house Barbera in a carafe (delish).
author: Kristin B.

description:
I'm a big fan of these amazing Mission restaurants opening locations in Pac Heights...

Thanks, Delfina, for bringing your amazing pizza closer to my 'hood.

Get there early though, the wait gets pretty awful in true Delfina fashion.
author: Alyssa W.

description:
Came in here with my old roommate who was in town from NYC. since I have unsuccessfully found a pizza worth calling NY style here, I took him along for another test of pizza in SF. we were actually seated pretty fast which was nice. and you cant go wrong as 2 guys eating in a restaurant with nothing but cute waitresses. 
but this was about the pizza. we ordered 2. a prosciutto pizza and a sausage and pepperoni deal. both pizzas were tasty and thin, but the end of the crust, those last bites of yummy bread, just fell short for us. although it is good pizza, it is far from great thin crust, and a bit overpriced i felt. but if you arent from NY and want good pizza, by all means, check it out
author: Rich B.

description:
Awesome pizzeria! Loved the decor/finishes but would recommend toning down the music b/c it was blaring.  Had the procuitto pizza and the fennel sausage pizza - both were amazing & fluffy & thin...just how I like it.

Great service, but then again I went for lunch on Saturday. I hear its crazy busy at night.  Delicious and can't wait to go back.
author: Veronica P.

description:
After months of anticipation and sneaking peeks through the boards that covered the front, Pizzeria Delfina's Pacific Heights location is now open!

Yay!

I would like to say that I wasn't shamelessly waiting at the door at 4pm when they officially opened, but that would be a lie. I'm shameless, what can I say?

Anyway, it's open, it's delicious, it's Delfina! All you Delfina fans that live on this side of the city can rejoice. For those of you who have yet to try them, you are in for a treat.

Just so everyone knows, for penance I had lunch at Dino's.
author: Mark G.

description: Can't complain about this place.  The pizza is marvelous and it's insane how much other good food is also on the menu.  The line moves pretty quickly - the turnaround time is quick.  You just can't go wrong with perfectly done thin crust pizza!
author: Victoria L.

description: The Prosciutto Pie is still the best pizza they have.  And I re-tried the meatballs - better this time around.  Juicier and softer.  Still not as good as Trader Joe's Turkey Meatballs though.  Ha!
author: Linh V.

description: My boyfriend took me here for our anniversary. When we got there, it was full and waited to put our names down. But then realized that we had to sign our name on the chalk and your party number. I wouldn't come here with a bunch of people just because it was small place. Service is good and the food was great yummy! and BREADSTICKS!!!! Can't wait to go back
author: Miles R.

description: The burrata and the meatballs were very good. I was not impressed by the Broccolini pizza. I thought it was too salty and wish it had some sauce. I gave the pizzeria 4 stars because the appetizers were THAT good.
author: David M.

description: I have never been so disappointed with a kitchen/cooks hygiene in a restaurant which portrays the image of being so professional.  When I mentioned my concerns of chefs using dirty hands/fingers to taste food and no "hand washing facilities' close by, the female manager brushed-off my concerns as nothing to worry about - she did not listen to my concerns. Our server was superb, our hostess gracious and frankly the food was delicious, but I just couldn't believe the attitude.
author: Ian B.

description:
I've been eyeing the whole Delfina group of restaurants for awhile and finally managed to stop by it's newer California St. outpost to taste this much hyped pizzeria. Off the bat, I was feeling the vibe and look of the place. Not to sound like I know anything about NYC, but it definitely reminded me of places in SOHO. Contemporary interior, hipster servers and "comfort" foods priced just high enough to make you think "crap, i hope they take credit."

The menu is fairly straight forward although the pizza's aren't as down-home and hearty as I had imagined. As expected, all the menu descriptions were SF-sized with a range of cheeses, italian meats and obscure vegetables that I can't pronounce. Their salads were also just as out there. In the end, we tried the tuna salad and the sausage pizza (no idea what the real names were for either). The salad was overly deconstructed (thanks Top Chef for adding to the vocab) but still tasty. The pizza was also pretty good. Thin crust but deceptively filling and good enough for two. 

Overall, the food and service are great and, minus the $50 tab at the end, its definitely one of those places to add to the repeat visit list. Important to know (and not so obvious for first timers) the waits are long and the sign-in list is maintained on the chalk board. Ignore the people standing at the door and head straight to the board so you don't get dicked over while waiting. Also, gentleman please be careful leaving the bathroom. I don't know why it swings out but I almost knocked out one of the chefs.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description:
good pizza(salsiccia)but don't believe when someone tell u that it's the best in town;it's just not true...
the proscuitto pizza is bland!
service was good.
we tried the ice cream in brioche(w t f?)it's just terrible:a dry bun w/ice cream in the middle?at least warm the brioche!
4 people w/2 mimosa pitchers(very small):$180 before tips!!!
not cheap at all!
author: g. r.

description:
This city is amazing. The 7x7 wonderland of beautiful hills, people, and food, is a world in itself. Everything in the City is never too far away, but never close enough. Go figure. 

The Mission is not more than 15 mins away from anywhere in the city, but that's 15 mins i could cut between my food and my lips. I love how things work out and that I don't have to drive to the other side when my Delfina craving hits. 

My favs: Salsiccia, Broccoli Raab, and Margherita pizza's, Mozzarella in Carozza (fried mozzarella skewers in magic sauce, loves it) - the server said this order changed his life.

While I wouldn't say that the food is life-altering, it is a place I'd want to come back to again and again, especially now that commute time has been cut in half!
author: Deanna T.

description:
Had a special of the day pizza - grilled chicories, mozarella di buffalo, rosemary and pancetta. Pretty rich and tasty - the chicories were pretty bitter though. Probably wouldn't order it again.

The fried brocolini on the other hand - whoo! Skinny little broccoli, fried in a light tempura-like batter and tossed with shaved parmesan. Mmm....

A good value - the pizzas serve 2 no problem...
author: Jennifer C.

description:
Identical to Mission location as far as design, menu, nice staff.

Pretty slow getting your food though.  Verrrry slow even...

Good thing they have $5/glass house wine...
author: Melanie C.

description: We love Delfina for the fresh ingredients, unique specials, delicious pizza and friendly service. Tonight we enjoyed warm citrus olives, baked macaroni with smoked mozzarella, pizza with fennel sausage, red peppers, and onions and roasted white chocolate gelato. Simple, fresh and delicious!
author: Katherine D.

description: Went for lunch with my wife. The service was very good and the soup was great. But the pizzas were not what i was expecting. I understand that they have a gas oven but still i was expecting much more. Nowhere close to the Neapolitan pizzas I've tried in the other restaurants in SF/Italy.
author: N K.

description:
Pac Heights desperately needed this outpost of Delfina.  In my opinion, the only other viable pizza in my part of town was Orgasmica on Fillmore, which seems a little more processed and mass-produced - esp now that I've had Delfina.  It's like the difference between being a grungy law student and being an associate; a definite quality upgrade, while not detracting from tried and true greasy goodness.

Delfina's pizzas are super fresh, which means the ingredients/raw materials are as well.  They're also the perfect size to split - along with a tricolore salad - without being stuffed. Delfina has become my pizza go-to in the 'hood.
author: Emily M.

description:
I used to go the one in the Mission all the time when I lived in Potrero, but now that I'm in Cow Hollow it's nice to have a Delfina closer to home, especially since it's three times the size of the original! 

Went in with four friends last Friday. 

Things we could  have done with out: 

1. The mozzarella salad. The cheese wasn't great and the mixed greens 
     were over salted. 

2. The Margherita pizza. It was bland tasting, lacked basil, and the crust 
     was soggy from the fresh mozzarrella pieces leaking their juice. 

Things we loved: 

1. Being able to drink a bottle of wine out front while we waited to be    
    seated.

2. Our server/the service. 

2. The Salsiccia pizza (homemade fennel sausage? Amazing!)

3. The Twin Girls Satsuma salad ( plump satsuma mandarins, thinly 
     shaved fennel, chunky slivers of white onion, mixed greens, and 
     walnuts all in a lemony champagne vinaigrette. 

4. The prosciutto pizza with fresh arugula on top. 
 
5. The wine list, the friendly by the bottle prices, and the wines! Had three
     great different Italian wines that all went exceptionally well with our 
     meal. 

6. The fried Ciccio. Broccoli, battered with the most delicious, golden 
     perfectly fried batter and then dusted with  light coat of grated
     Parmesan.  

It's worth the wait.
author: Dee I.

description: I got only two words to say about Pizzeria Delfina, "HELLA GOOD"!!! Their pizza is the flat thin crust and so far all the times I went has always been crispy. And no matter how full you are, u gotz to get the desert "Zeppole di San Giuseppe" which is a fried pizza dough with mascarpone pastry cream. It's hella good.
author: Willy L.

description: What did they do?  Maybe I've been to Ragazza too many times now.  I used to love this place.  The margarita pizza I just had was AWFUL.  I thought Pizzeria Inferno had the most tasteless one on the block.  This was not much better.  I'm soooo glad Dino's has reopened.  I'd much rather give him my business.
author: Laura T.

description:
i discovered today that there was another pizzeria delfina besides the location on mission.  parking is always horrendous in the mission and the wait for pizzeria delfina makes you salivate has you see other people devouring their pizza in front of your face.  

parking was relatively easy to find, there is a lot about 100 feet away from pizzeria delfina and we waited for less than 30 minutes for a party of 3.  i think our eyes were definitely bigger than our stomachs and we decided to order 4 pizzas since none of the appetizers looked appealing.

pizza selections of the night (in preferred order)

carbonara (special of the night)- this pizza had awesome flavor which reminded me of eating carbonara pasta in italy.  i've never had egg on a pizza before and the cream sauce complemented the combination of ingredients very well.

margarita- simple but amazing, my second choice of the night.  this pizza has redefined my love for cheese pizza.

prosciutto pizza with arugula- the prosciutto on the pizza was fresh and amazing except for the fact that two pieces of the pizza had no prosciutto on it.  that made it 3/4 prosciutto and argula, and 1/4 argula.

salssiccia-after having a 5 minute conversation on how to pronounce the name of the pizza we decided to order this as well with sausage, fennel, and red peppers.  it was very flavorful and if you like the margarita pizza and are a meat lover, then you should order this one.

i'm not sure how we had room for dessert, but order the copa gelato with chocolate on top.  an absolute must for topping off the night!
author: Carli F.

description:
Just had my 3rd amazing dinner here. By the hoardes of people waiting to be seated, I think it may be obvious now that this place is good. What I can tell you is: 
1. it's worth the wait
2. they are so nice!
3. the meatballs are the best I have ever had in my life.
author: Lisa O.

description:
We came here last night after visiting a friend who had just given birth at CPMC.  I just love the vibe in this area of town.

I have never been to Delfina in the Mission but my girlfriend assured me the pizza is amazing... so true.

We got there around 6:30 and put our name on the list.  Noticed that most of the tables are two tops so we had to wait an extra long time (20-25 minutes or so) for one of the 2 (I think) booths that are available.  I guess this is more of a "date night" place perhaps?  Strange cause I did see a lot of kiddies around.

We finally got seated and I looked over the wine menu -- it was chock full of exotic sounding Italian wines... as a California wine gal, I only recognized one, the sangiovese!  So, I ordered it and it was perfectly juicy & yummy.  We ordered the olives & the blood orange salad to start.  I have never had olives served warm, but I approve!  They were tasty.  The blood orange salad was small, but a nice taster for the 3 of us.  I do wish they had more salad choices... perhaps a chopped salad? 

We ordered the special pizza of the day which included some kind of pork (the server said it was pork "jaw"), shallots, and I can't remember what else but it was delicious.  We also ordered the broccoli raab pizza with olives... cheesy goodness!  We could have easily ordered only one pizza and been fine to share, but it was fun to have leftovers.  I am a fan of the flatbread style pizza - they do a great job of making the crust perfect -- flat style, but substantial enough to feel like you are getting a meal, not just ingredients on a cracker.  I compare it to the pizza at Pizza Antica in Lafayette, but better.  

I kind of wish they would dim the lighting, it felt a bit "cafeteria'- ish.
author: Sheila D.

description:
Very disappointing. The pizza was thick, soggy and chewy, not at all crispy and thin like they make pizza in Naples. Local (in SOMA) is much better. 

Service was not good: the staff made us feel rushed.
author: Esme V.

description:
Wednesday night at 8:15 and we wait for over an hour????  No reservations, but you write your name on a chalkboard.  Fine idea unless the hostess erases your name!
After noticing other parties who arrived after us being seated before us, we inquired as to what what happening.  We were told she would seat us as soon as she seated the other people (who actually said that they had arrived after us).  Our request for swapping the salad dressings on the salad was answered with "they don't like things like that in the kitchen".  Boo Hoo!  One salad on a small oval plate, with three matching plates to serve on.  Our pizza arrived, apparently also to be eaten on the small plates delivered with the salad.  The mussels special was brought to the table as almost an afterthought, with barely any broth -- had they been reheated under the salamander?  Again, luckily we had the small plates to serve the mussels on.

It seemed like a good idea to have a word with the manager.  She was lovely, and apologetic.  She gave us a splash more wine, a free desssert, and comped the mussels.  We did appreciate that.  The surprise?  One 12" pizza, one small salad, two carafes of wine -- $90.  Whew!

Think next time we'll go back to Dino's.
author: pam w.

description:
1) Zao's noodle place has closed. Pizzeria Delfina is HERE serving PacHeights.
2. It is open and SUPER BUSY.

3. Wish it were Delfina Deux...as in more stuff for lunch and dinner that is innovative and fun, but I guess Pizza fans are excited.

4. Well.. it is in the neighborhood and parking stalls are just three doors down for all of $5 bucks in quarters if you are driving...just walk if you can.
METERS in effect even on SUNDAYS...The parking fine is $60, now that pizza meal cost you $120. 

Let me save you some dinerios. You can even take a cab.

Best wishes to the Delfina set up team. 
People in this hood are picky...picccckkkkeeeee! Not as cool as the Mission, Potrero-Hill kinda vibe.
author: miriam b.

description: absolutely LOVED this place.  Great SF atmosphere, and the food is really good.   We actually didn't have to wait but it's probably because we showed up at 2 PM which is definitely after the rush.  Will most definitely go back.  However, I wouldn't recommend for a large party as their space is pretty small.
author: Neda S.

description:
After not being able to find parking in North Beach, my gf and I decided to head over to Fillmore and try Delfina.  On a Friday night at 8, the wait was pretty long but they gave us bread sticks to snack on until our table was ready.

The margherita pizza was good but the meatballs were better.  I would definitely recommend them.

I will definitely go back again.
author: John R.

description:
I can now see why people are willing to wait an hour for this place on any given day or time. The casual, hipster, sophisticated, friendly vibe makes it an enjoyable place to dine at without the pretentious crowd or divey feel environment. The food is great and service is friendly.


The server sold us on these thinly sliced, fried squash flower buds for the appetizer. Very different and light. As we all agreed, it tasted like Trader Joe's veggie chips! LOL

Prosciutto Pie: I love prosciutto! It was a little creamy for my taste though, but still good!

Salsiccia Pizza: Yummy sausage, tomatos, peppers, onions, and fresh mozza with a little spicy kick to it. Yes, I think I'll have another slice please!

Daily Homemade Gelato - mexican lime & strawberry: Citrusy, real fruit flavor. A nice ending to a great meal. 

Montepulciano d'Abruzzo Riparosso - Illuminati = EXCELLENT WINE!
author: Linda C.

description: I found this place very interesting and wanted to come visit. After reading their menu on-line, I noticed it stated," $1.50 per person will be added to each check in support of San Francisco Health Care Security Ordinance" Depending on your total bill and # of your party, an added $1.50 each can really add up and be a large percentage of your bill.  Just another reason why I like to eat at places that don't up charge me a health fee. I would rather directly give a waiter a higher tip, then have the restaurant pocket more $ for assumed Health Care.  Even though I have not eaten at this place, I won't be trying it anytime soon.
author: Michelle A.

description:
thin crust pizza lover here!

pizzeria delfina gets it right. tried the purgatoria (spicy tomato sauce w/ two eggs, pecorino and romano cheese), and it was delicious. i've heard good thinks about pizza + eggs but have always been hesitant to order it afraid of it coming out reminiscent of a breakfast platter. i don't like soggy pizza! great tasting sauce and great amount of cheese/ingredients, since i don't like an overwhelming amount of cheese. the eggs added a pleasant surprise since the romano cheese complimented the flavor of the runny yolk very well, yum.

can't wait to come back and try the others. 

tip: be prepared to wait and don't be surprised about feeling like you're dining with your neighboring tables. place is small and cozy with outdoor seating. super friendly staff too!
author: Sharon L.

description:
i love this pizzeria!  i can't say enough how much i adore this spot in the PH neighborhood.  I have been several times with friends now and have enjoyed everything I eat.  We have tried the following:
chicory pizza
salsiccia  (?) pizza
mushroom pie
brick-cooked chicken
tuna conserva (?)
all of the salads
the gelatos - all so good!  try the panettone flavor
the fritti - i had the green beans
the fried mozzeralla and bread on a skewer is so decadent!

Like I said, I have been there several times and I have never noticed a noise problem.  Just load up on the good wine and speak up!

Also, there is a parking lot a half-block away.  Parking is so easy.

Meatballs and the prosuitto pie are next on my list!
author: miss m.

description: DELICIOUS!  Most likely the best pizza in SF and the best pizza I've ever had.  I love the thin, crispy, flaky crusts, the delicious sauce, and the fresh herbs they give you to put on the pizza.  We ordered the margherita and the one with sausage....both were perfect.  We also ordered an appetizer that was the special of the day...some kind of sauteed cauliflower...it was SOOO unbelievably good...and I don't even like cauliflower that much! I love the atmosphere and look of the place...and the best part is that we went at 2:30PM on a Friday so NO WAIT!
author: Sonal P.

description: If I could, I would eat there everyday. This restaurant was mentioned in GQ magazine as the 3rd best pizza in the U.S. It is never empty, there are always people waiting outside and thats how you know its a good place. Once there you just can't wait for your name to get to the top of the chalkboard. Trust me, you want to wait!
